(1 mg of enoxaparin per kilogram of body weight subcutaneously twice daily (247 patients). The study design allowed outpatients taking low-molecular-weight heparin to go home immediately and hospitalized patients taking low-molecular-weight heparin to be discharged early. All patients received warfarin starting on day 2. Thirteen of 247 patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin (5.3 percent) had recurrent thromboembolism, compared with 17 of 253 patients receiving standard heparin (6.7 percent; P = 0.57; absolute difference, 1.4 percentage points; confidence interval 95 percent). , -3.0 to 5.7). Five patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin had major bleeding, compared with three patients receiving standard heparin. After randomization, patients who received low-molecular-weight heparin spent an average of 1.1 days in the hospital, compared with 6.5 days for the standard heparin group; 120 patients in the low-molecular-weight heparin group did not require hospitalization at all. Low molecular weight heparin can be used safely and effectively to treat patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis at home.

Prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis in hospitalized patients remains underutilized. We hypothesized that use of a computer alert program to encourage prophylaxis may reduce the frequency of deep vein thrombosis among high-risk hospitalized patients. We developed a computer program linked to a patient database to identify consecutive hospitalized patients at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis in the absence of prophylaxis. The program used medical record numbers to randomly assign 1,255 eligible patients to an intervention group, in which the responsible physician was alerted to the patient's risk of deep vein thrombosis, and 1,251 patients to a control group, in which no alert was issued. The physician was required to acknowledge the alert and could then withhold or order prophylaxis, including graduated compression stockings, pneumatic compression shoes, unfractionated heparin, low-molecular-weight heparin, or warfarin. The primary endpoint was clinically diagnosed, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism within 90 days. More patients in the intervention group than in the control group received mechanical prophylaxis (10.0 percent vs. 1.5 percent, P < 0.001) or drug prophylaxis (23.6 percent vs. 13.0 percent, P < 0.001). The primary endpoint occurred in 61 patients (4.9 percent) in the intervention group, compared with 103 (8.2 percent) in the control group; Kaplan-Meier estimates of the probability of freedom from deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days were 94.1 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 92.5 to 95.4 percent) and 90.6 percent (95 percent confidence interval, 88.7 to 92.2 percent), respectively (P< 0.001). Computer stimulation reduced the risk of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism by 41 percent over 90 days (hazard ratio, 0.59; 95 percent confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.81; P = 0.001). The creation of a computer alert program increased physicians' use of prophylaxis and significantly reduced rates of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism among hospitalized patients at risk.

Whether closure of the foramen ovale reduces the risk of stroke recurrence in patients who have had a stroke of unknown origin is unknown. In a multicenter, randomized, open-label trial, with adjudication blinded to endpoint events, we randomly assigned patients aged 18 to 60 years who had a patent foramen ovale (PFO) and had an ischemic stroke of unknown origin to undergo foramen ovale closure. PFO (PFO closure group) or receiving medical therapy alone (aspirin, warfarin, clopidogrel, or aspirin with extended-release dipyridamole; medical therapy group). The primary efficacy endpoint was the combination of recurrent nonfatal ischemic stroke, fatal ischemic stroke, or early death after randomization. Results of the primary outcome analysis from the original trial period have been reported previously; The present analysis of data from the extended follow-up period was considered exploratory. We enrolled 980 patients (mean age 45.9 years) at 69 sites. Patients were followed for an average of 5.9 years. The treatment exposure in the two groups was unequal (3141 patient years in the PFO closure group versus 2669 patient years in the medical therapy group), due to a higher dropout rate in the medical therapy group. In the treatment target population, recurrent ischemic stroke occurred in 18 patients in the PFO closure group and in 28 patients in the medical therapy group, resulting in rates of 0.58 events per 100 patient-years and 1.07 events per 100 patient-years. years, respectively (hazard ratio with PFO closure versus medical therapy, 0.55; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.31 to 0.999; P = 0.046 by log-rank test). Recurrent ischemic stroke of undetermined cause occurred in 10 patients in the PFO closure group and in 23 patients in the medical therapy group (hazard ratio, 0.38; 95% CI, 0.18 to 0.79; P = 0.007). Venous thromboembolism (which included pulmonary embolism events and deep vein thrombosis) was more common in the PFO-closed group than in the medical therapy group. Among adults who had an ischemic stroke of unknown origin, PFO closure was associated with a lower rate of recurrent ischemic strokes compared with medical therapy alone during extended follow-up. (Funded by St. Jude Medical Corporation; RESPECT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00465270.).

Individuals who have had a transient ischemic attack and stroke are at high risk of recurrent stroke and death. While acetylsalicylic acid (ASA, aspirin) has been established and accepted as standard treatment in these patients, recent trials have shown that a combination of ASA and dipyridamole (DP) or clopidogrel may be superior to ASA. Blocking the renin-angiotensin system with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers may also reduce recurrent stroke. The PROFESS (Prevention System to Effectively Avoid Second Strokes) trial was designed to evaluate whether extended-release ASA + DP compared with clopidogrel, and whether telmisartan in addition to usual care for individuals after stroke, will reduce the risk of further strokes. PROFESS is a multicenter, double-blind, randomized trial including 695 sites from 35 countries or regions. Patients over 50 years of age who had an ischemic stroke of less than 120 days of age and who were stable were randomized. The primary outcome of the trial is recurrent stroke, using time-to-event analysis. The most important secondary outcome is stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. Other secondary outcomes include this combination + congestive heart failure, new-onset diabetes, and other specific vascular occlusive events (pulmonary embolus, deep vein thrombosis, peripheral arterial occlusion, transient ischemic attack, cerebral venous thrombosis, or retinal vascular accident not classified). As a stroke), any death, or a subtype of stroke according to the TOAST criteria and the Mini-Mental State Examination score. Safety is evaluated by assessing the risk of major bleeding events. The comparison between ASA + DP and clopidogrel is based on an initial non-inferiority assessment, followed by a superiority assessment, while for telmisartan, we will evaluate its superiority over placebo. With more than 20,000 patients randomized, and using a 2 × 2 factorial design, PROFESS is the largest stroke trial to investigate the prevention of recurrent stroke. The mean age was 66.1 +/- 8.6 years, and 36.0% of patients were female. The median time from qualifying event to randomization was 15 days with 39.9% of patients randomized within 10 days. According to the TOAST criteria, 28.5% of strokes were due to large vessel disease, 52.1% were due to small vessel disease, 1.8% were due to cardioembolism, 2.0% were due to other specified etiology, and 15.5% were due to undetermined etiology. . PROFESS is the largest secondary stroke prevention trial to date and will directly compare two antiplatelet regimens as well as the benefit of telmisartan versus placebo.

The risk of bleeding complications during and after early hip fracture surgery has not been established for patients taking clopidogrel and other anticoagulants. The purpose of this study is to evaluate perioperative bleeding risks and clinical outcomes after early hip fracture surgery in patients taking clopidogrel (Plavix) and other oral anticoagulants. The study design is a retrospective cohort analysis using data extracted from hospital records and government death registries. Regional Medical Center (Level II Trauma). Data on 1118 patients aged ≥60 years who underwent surgical treatment for hip fracture between 2004 and 2008 were reviewed. Eighty-two patients undergoing late surgery (>3 days after admission) were excluded. Patients taking clopidogrel were compared with those not taking clopidogrel. In addition, patients taking clopidogrel only were compared with groups of patients taking clopidogrel and aspirin, aspirin only, warfarin only, or no anticoagulants. Seventy-four of 1036 patients (7%) were taking clopidogrel, although the control groups included 253 patients taking aspirin alone, 90 patients taking warfarin, and 619 patients not taking anticoagulants. No statistically significant differences were observed between patients taking clopidogrel and those not taking clopidogrel in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirements, final blood count, hematoma evacuation, hospital length of stay (LOS), or mortality. While they are in the hospital or after one year. A higher American Society of Anesthesiologists score was seen in the clopidogrel and warfarin groups (P = 0.05 for each), an increased LOS in the clopidogrel group (P = 0.05), and a higher rate of deep vein thrombosis in those patients taking warfarin (P = 0.05). 0.05). Clopidogrel alone versus aspirin versus both aspirin and clopidogrel, versus no anticoagulant versus warfarin, showed no significant differences in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirements, final blood counts, bleeding, perioperative complications, or mortality. Patients undergoing early hip fracture surgery who take clopidogrel, aspirin, or warfarin (with an internationally regulated normalized ratio) are not at increased risk of bleeding, bleeding complications, or death. Comorbidities and American Society of Anesthesiologists scores were significantly higher in the clopidogrel group, which may lead to increased postoperative visual loss in this group.

Several newer anticoagulants are in clinical development. Two of them recently, Dabigatran etexilate/Pradaxa. Rivaroxaban/Xarelto has marketing authorization in Europe and Canada for the prevention of thromboembolic events after major orthopedic surgery such as total hip and knee replacement. Results of phase III clinical studies in thromboprophylaxis in major orthopedic surgery are highlighted and discussed in detail. Ongoing phase II and III clinical trials are evaluating its effectiveness in the prevention and secondary treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, in the long-term prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation and in combination with aspirin and clopidogrel in patients with aspirin and clopidogrel. With acute coronary syndromes. Several other anticoagulant small molecules, including a new generation of low-molecular-weight heparin, are currently in various stages of clinical development. In addition to oral administration, newer anticoagulants have a more balanced benefit/risk ratio and a wider therapeutic window. They have a rapid onset of action, a predictable anticoagulant effect and do not require routine laboratory monitoring. They have minor interactions with food and drugs, including interactions with cytochrome P450 and P.gp. They are highly specific, target a single clotting factor, and can carry a similar or lower bleeding risk compared to older anticoagulant agents. Finally, it can be used in a wide range of patients, especially patients with advanced cancer, the elderly without any dose adjustment, regardless of the patient's age, sex or body weight or in patients with mild renal impairment. It is hoped that its use in the general world will confirm the promising results of clinical trials.

Allopurinol, a drug commonly prescribed to treat gout and hyperuricemia, is a frequent cause of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCAR), which include drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis. Adverse events are unpredictable and carry significant morbidity and mortality. To identify genetic markers for allopurinol-SCAR, we performed a case-control association study. We enrolled 51 allopurinol-SCAR patients and 228 control subjects (135 allopurinol-tolerant subjects and 93 healthy subjects from the general population), and genotyped 823 SNPs in genes associated with drug metabolism and immune response. The initial screen revealed a strong association between allopurinol-SCAR and SNPs in the MHC region, including BAT3 (encoding HLA-B associated transcript 3), MSH5 (mutS Homolog 5), and MICB (MHC class B polypeptide-binding sequence) ( P) < 10(-7)). We next identified HLA loci A, B, C, and DRB1 alleles. The HLA-B*5801 allele was present in all 51 (100%) patients with allopurinol-SCAR, but only in 20 (15%) of the 135 tolerant patients [odds ratio, 580.3 (95% confidence interval, 34.4-9780.9 ); corrected P value = 4.7 × 10(-24)] and in 19 (20%) of 93 healthy subjects [393.51 (23.23-6665.26); Corrected P value = 8.1 × 10(-18)]. HLA A*3303, Cw*0302, and DRB1*0301 alleles were in linkage disequilibrium and formed an extended haplotype with HLA-B*5801. Our results indicated that allopurinol-SCAR is strongly associated with genetic predisposition in Han Chinese. In particular, the HLA-B*5801 allele is an important genetic risk factor for this life-threatening condition.

Develop evidence-based recommendations for the management of gout. The multidisciplinary guideline development group consisted of 19 rheumatologists and one expert in evidence-based medicine representing 13 European countries. Key propositions on governance were generated using a Delphi consensus approach. The research evidence was systematically searched for each proposal. Where possible, effect size (ES), number needed to treat, relative risk, odds ratio, and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio were calculated. The quality of evidence was graded according to the level of evidence. Strength of recommendation (SOR) was assessed using EULAR analog and ordinal scales. 12 major propositions were generated after three rounds of Delphi. The proposals included both pharmacological and non-pharmacological treatments and addressed the control of acute gout symptoms, urate-lowering therapy (ULT), and prevention of acute attacks. The importance of patient education, adverse lifestyle modification (weight loss in obesity, reduced alcohol consumption, low animal purine diet) and treatment of comorbidities and associated risk factors is emphasized. Recommended medications for acute attacks were oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), oral colchicine (ES = 0.87 (95% CI, 0.25 to 1.50)), or joint aspiration and corticosteroid injections. ULT is indicated in patients with recurrent acute attacks, arthropathy, tophi, or radiographic changes of gout. The long-term effectiveness of allopurinol for lowering urate levels was confirmed (ES = 1.39 (0.78 to 2.01)). If allopurinol toxicity occurs, options include other xanthine oxidase inhibitors, allopurinol desensitization, or increased uric acid. Benzbromarone uric acid is more effective than allopurinol (ES = 1.50 (0.76 to 2.24)) and can be used in patients with mild to moderate renal insufficiency but may be hepatotoxic. When gout is associated with the use of diuretics, diuretics should be discontinued if possible. To prevent acute attacks, colchicine 0.5-1 mg daily or NSAIDs (with gastric protection if necessary) are recommended. 12 key recommendations for the management of gout have been developed, using a combination of research-based evidence and expert consensus. The evidence was evaluated and an SOR was provided for each proposal.

Febuxostat, a new selective nonpurinyl xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is a potential alternative to allopurinol for patients with hyperuricemia and gout. We randomly assigned 762 patients with gout and blood urate concentrations of at least 8.0 mg per deciliter (480 μmol per liter) to receive either febuxostat (80 mg or 120 mg) or allopurinol (300 mg) once daily for 52 weeks; 760 received study medication. Prophylaxis against gout attacks was provided with naproxen or colchicine during weeks 1 through 8. The primary endpoint was a serum urate concentration of less than 6.0 mg per deciliter (360 μmol per liter) at the last three monthly measurements. Secondary endpoints included a reduction in the incidence of gout attacks and in the area of ​​tophi. The primary endpoint was reached in 53% of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 62% of those receiving 120 mg febuxostat, and 21% of patients receiving allopurinol (P < 0.001 to compare each febuxostat group with the allopurinol group). . Although the incidence of gout attacks diminished as treatment continued, the overall incidence during weeks 9 to 52 was similar in all groups: 64% of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 70% of those receiving 120 mg febuxostat. , and 64% of those receiving 120 mg of febuxostat. Receiving allopurinol (P = 0.99 for 80 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol; P = 0.23 for 120 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol). The mean reduction in tophi area was 83 percent in patients receiving 80 mg of febuxostat and 66 percent in those receiving 120 mg of febuxostat, compared with 50 percent in those receiving allopurinol (P = 0.08 for 80 mg of febuxostat versus allopurinol; P =0.16 for 120 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol). More patients in the high-dose febuxostat group than in the allopurinol group (P = 0.003) or the low-dose febuxostat group discontinued the study. Four of the 507 patients in the two groups died on febuxostat (0.8 percent) and none of the 253 patients in the allopurinol group died. All deaths were due to causes that the investigators (while still blind to treatment) considered unrelated to the study medications (P = 0.31 for comparison between the combined febuxostat and allopurinol groups). Febuxostat, at a daily dose of 80 mg or 120 mg, was more effective than allopurinol at the commonly used fixed daily dose of 300 mg in lowering serum urate. Similar reductions in gout flares and tophi area occurred in all treatment groups.

The prototypical xanthine oxidase (XO) inhibitor, allopurinol, has been the cornerstone of the clinical management of gout and associated conditions of hyperuricemia for several decades. More recent data suggest that XO also plays an important role in various forms of vascular ischemia and other types of tissue and vascular injuries, inflammatory diseases, and chronic heart failure. Allopurinol and its active metabolite oxypurinol have shown great promise in treating these conditions both in laboratory animals and in small-scale human clinical trials. Although some of the beneficial effects of these compounds may not be related to XO inhibition, the encouraging results have sparked great interest in developing new additional series of XO inhibitors for various therapeutic indications. Here we provide a critical overview of the effects of XO inhibitors in various pathophysiological conditions and also review the various emerging therapeutic strategies offered by this approach.

To evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in people with primary fibromyalgia, with or without coexisting major depressive disorder. This study was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted at 18 outpatient research centers in the United States. A total of 207 subjects meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for primary fibromyalgia were enrolled (89% female, 87% white, mean age 49 years, 38% with current major depressive disorder). After single-blind placebo treatment for 1 week, subjects were randomly assigned to receive duloxetine 60 mg twice a day (n = 104) or placebo (n = 103) for 12 weeks. Co-primary outcome measures were the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) total score (score range 0–80, with 0 indicating no effect) and FIQ pain score (score range 0–10). Secondary outcome measures included mean pain threshold at pain point, number of pain scores, FIQ fatigue, fatigue on awakening, stiffness scores, Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI-Severity), and Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-Improvement) scale. Brief Pain Inventory (Short Form), Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36, Quality of Life Depression Scale, and Sheehan Disability Scale. Compared with subjects treated with placebo, duloxetine-treated subjects improved significantly (P = 0.027) on the FIQ total score, with a treatment difference of -5.53 (95% CI -10.43, -0.63), but not significantly more on the FIQ score. Pain recurred (P = 0.130). Compared with subjects treated with placebo, subjects treated with duloxetine had significantly greater reductions in the average Brief Pain Inventory pain intensity score (P = 0.008), the average Brief Pain Inventory pain intensity score (P = 0.004), and the number Pain score (P = 0.002), FIQ stiffness score (P = 0.048), and there was a significantly greater improvement in the mean pain threshold of the pain score (P = 0.002), CGI severity score (P = 0.048), and PGI improvement ( P = 0.033), and several quality of life measures, duloxetine treatment showed improvement in fibromyalgia symptoms and pain severity regardless of underlying major depressive disorder status (n = 92). 92) showed significantly greater improvement on most efficacy measures, while males treated with duloxetine (n=12) failed to improve significantly on any efficacy measure. The effect of treatment on significant pain reduction in females was independent of the effect on mood or anxiety Given safely and well-tolerated in this 12-week randomized controlled trial (with a 1-week placebo phase), duloxetine was an effective and safe treatment for several symptoms associated with fibromyalgia in people with and without the disorder. Major depression, especially for women. , which had significant improvement in most outcome measures.

This was a 12-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in 354 female patients with primary fibromyalgia, with or without coexisting major depressive disorder. Patients (90% Caucasian; mean age, 49.6 years; 26% with current major depressive disorder) received duloxetine 60 mg once daily (QD) (n = 118), or duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (BID) (n = 116), or placebo (n = 120). The primary outcome was the average pain intensity score on the Brief Pain Inventory. Response to treatment was defined as > or = 30% reduction in this outcome. Compared with placebo, both duloxetine-treated groups improved significantly (P < 0.001) in their average pain intensity score on the Brief Pain Inventory. A significantly higher proportion of patients treated with duloxetine had a > or = 30% reduction in this outcome (duloxetine 60 mg QD (55%; P < 0.001); duloxetine 60 mg BID (54%; P = 0.002); placebo ( 54%; P = 0.002); The effect of duloxetine treatment on pain reduction was independent of the effect on mood and the presence of major depressive disorder. Compared with patients who took placebo, patients treated with duloxetine 60 mg QD or duloxetine 60 mg twice daily had significantly greater improvement in the Brief Pain Inventory residual pain severity and interference scores, the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire, the Clinical Global Impression of Disease Severity, and the Impression Patient's global assessment of improvement, and many quality of life measures. Both doses of duloxetine were administered safely and well tolerated. In conclusion, both duloxetine 60 mg QD and duloxetine 60 mg BID were effective and safe in the treatment of fibromyalgia in female patients with and without major depressive disorder.

The primary objectives of this study were to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine for reducing pain intensity in fibromyalgia patients with and without coexisting major depressive disorder. This was a 6-month, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. In total, 520 patients meeting the American College of Rheumatology criteria for fibromyalgia were randomly assigned to duloxetine (20 mg/day, 60 mg/day, or 120 mg/day) or placebo, given once daily for 6 months ( After 3 months, the duloxetine group (20 mg/day) was titrated to 60 mg/day). Co-primary outcome measures were the average Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) pain intensity score and the Patient Global Impressions of Improvement (PGI-I) score. Safety was assessed by treatment-induced adverse events, changes in vital signs, laboratory, and ECG measurements. Compared with patients treated with placebo, those patients treated with duloxetine 120 mg/day significantly improved on combined primary outcome measures after 3 months (change in BMI score [-2.31 vs -1.39, P<0.001] and PGI-I [ -] 2.89 vs. 3.39, P = 0.004]) and after 6 months (change in BPI [-2.26 vs -1.43, P = 0.003] and PGI-I [2.93 vs. 3.37, P = 0.012]). Compared with placebo, treatment with duloxetine 60 mg/day resulted in significant improvement in the combined primary measures at 3 months and the blood pressure index at 6 months. Duloxetine has been effective in patients with and without major depressive disorder. There were no clinically significant differences between treatment groups in changes in vital signs, laboratory measurements, or ECG measurements. Study results show that duloxetine at doses of 60 mg/day and 120 mg/day appears safe and effective in patients with fibromyalgia.

Duloxetine is a balanced serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor licensed for the treatment of major depressive disorders, stress urinary incontinence, and the management of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A number of trials have been performed to investigate the use of duloxetine in neuropathic and nociceptive painful conditions. This is the first update of a review first published in 2010. To evaluate the benefits and harms of duloxetine for the treatment of painful neuropathy and different types of chronic pain. On 19 November 2013, we searched the Cochrane Neuromuscular Group Specialist Register, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHSEED, MEDLINE, and EMBASE. We searched ClinicalTrials.gov for ongoing trials in April 2013. We also searched reference lists of publications identifying trials of duloxetine for the treatment of painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain. We selected all randomized or quasi-randomized trials of any combination of duloxetine used to treat painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain in adults. We used standard methodological procedures expected by the Cochrane Collaboration. We identified 18 trials, which included 6407 participants. We found 12 such studies in the literature looking for this update. Eight studies included a total of 2728 participants with painful diabetic neuropathy and six studies included 2249 participants with fibromyalgia. Three studies included participants with depression and painful physical symptoms and one included participants with central neuropathic pain. Studies were mostly at low risk of bias, although large dropouts, inclusion methods, and almost every study conducted or sponsored by the drug manufacturer increase the risk of bias in some areas. Duloxetine at a dose of 60 mg daily is effective in the short-term treatment of painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy, with a risk ratio (RR) for ≥50% pain reduction at 12 weeks of 1.73 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.08). The relevant NNTB is 5 (95% CI 4 to 7). Duloxetine at a dose of 60 mg daily is also effective in treating fibromyalgia over 12 weeks (RR for pain reduction ≥ 50% 1.57, 95% CI 1.20 to 2.06; NNTB 8, 95% CI 4 to 21) and over 28 weeks (RR NNTB 8, 95% CI 5 to 14) as well as for painful somatic symptoms in depression (RR 1.58, 95% CI 1.10 to 2.27). There was no effect on central neuropathic pain in one small, high-quality trial. In all cases, adverse events were common in both the treatment and placebo arms but more common in the treatment arm, with a dose-dependent effect. Most adverse effects were minor, but 16% of participants stopped taking the medication due to adverse effects. Serious adverse events were rare. There are sufficient amounts of moderate quality evidence from eight studies conducted by the manufacturers of duloxetine that doses of 60 mg and 120 mg daily are effective in treating pain in diabetic peripheral neuropathy but that lower daily doses are not. There is no need for further experiments. In fibromyalgia, there is less good evidence that duloxetine is effective at doses similar to those used in diabetic peripheral neuropathy and with a similar magnitude of effect. The effect in fibromyalgia may be achieved through greater improvement in mental symptoms compared to physical pain. There is low to moderate quality evidence that pain relief is also achieved in pain associated with depressive symptoms, but an NNTB of 8 in fibromyalgia and depression is not an indicator of significant efficacy. Further trials (preferably independent investigator-led studies) are needed in these indications to reach the optimal amount of information to make convincing decisions about effectiveness. Minor side effects are common and are more common with duloxetine 60 mg and especially with 120 mg daily, more than 20 mg daily, but serious side effects are rare. Improved direct comparisons between duloxetine with other antidepressants and with other drugs, such as pregabalin, which have already been shown to be effective in treating neuropathic pain, would be appropriate. Unbiased economic comparisons would aid decision making further, but there is no high-quality study that includes economic data.

Peripheral artery disease is a manifestation of systemic atherosclerosis with associated adverse cardiovascular and extremity events. Data from previous trials have indicated that patients receiving clopidogrel monotherapy have a lower risk of cardiovascular disease compared with those receiving aspirin. We wanted to compare clopidogrel with ticagrelor, a powerful antiplatelet agent, in patients with peripheral artery disease. In this double-blind, event-based trial, we randomly assigned 13,885 patients with symptomatic PAD to receive monotherapy with ticagrelor (90 mg twice daily) or clopidogrel (75 mg once daily). Patients were eligible if they had an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.80 or less or had undergone previous lower extremity revascularization. The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, or ischemic stroke. The primary safety endpoint was major bleeding. Median follow-up was 30 months. The average age of patients was 66 years, and 72% were men; 43% were enrolled on the basis of ABI and 57% on the basis of previous revascularization. The mean baseline ABI in all patients was 0.71, 76.6% of patients had claudication, and 4.6% had critical limb ischemia. The primary efficacy endpoint occurred in 751 of 6930 patients (10.8%) who received ticagrelor and in 740 of 6955 (10.6%) who received clopidogrel (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.92 to 1.13; P = 0.65). . In each group, acute limb ischemia occurred in 1.7% of patients (hazard ratio, 1.03; 95% CI, 0.79 to 1.33; P=0.85) and major bleeding in 1.6% (hazard ratio, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.84 to 1.43). ; P = 0.49). In patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease, ticagrelor has not been shown to be superior to clopidogrel in reducing cardiovascular events. Major bleeding occurred at similar rates between patients in the two trial groups. (Funded by AstraZeneca; EUCLID ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01732822.).

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) affects approximately 20% of adults over the age of 55 years and is a strong predictor of myocardial infarction, stroke, and death from vascular causes. The goals of treatment are to prevent future major coronary and cerebrovascular events and improve leg symptoms. To review the best evidence for medical treatment of peripheral artery disease. MEDLINE and the Cochrane Database were searched from 1990 to November 2005 for randomized trials and meta-analyses of medical treatments for peripheral artery disease. References from these articles were also searched. Search terms, individually or in combination, included: peripheral arterial disease, peripheral artery disease, PAD, randomized controlled trial, randomized controlled trial, and meta-analysis. Particular attention has been directed toward randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses of clinically relevant medical treatments for peripheral artery disease. Outcome measures included leg symptoms (intermittent claudication and walking distance), death, and major coronary and cerebrovascular events. Leg claudication symptoms, walking distance, and quality of life can be improved by smoking cessation (doctor's advice, nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion), a structured exercise program, statins, cilostazol, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. The risk of major coronary and cerebrovascular events can be reduced by lowering blood pressure with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs, use of statins, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel, and possibly by smoking cessation. The large and increasing burden of peripheral artery disease, and its local and systemic complications, can be reduced by lifestyle modification (smoking cessation, exercise) and medical treatments (nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, antihypertensive drugs, statins, and antiplatelet drugs).

Incomplete inhibition of platelet thromboxane synthesis, as measured by elevated urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. We aimed to determine the external validity of this association in aspirin-treated patients enrolled in the Clopidogrel for High Atherosclerosis Risk and Ischemia Stabilization, Management and Avoidance (CHARISMA) trial and to determine whether there are any modifiable factors or interventions that lead to lowering urate. Dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations can thus reduce cardiovascular risk. 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations were measured in 3261 aspirin-treated patients at least 1 month after they were randomized to placebo or clopidogrel. Baseline urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations in the highest quartile were associated with an increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death compared with the lowest quartile (adjusted hazard ratio 1.66, 95% CI 1.06 to 2.61, P = 0.03). . Increasing age, female sex, history of peripheral artery disease, current smoking, and treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or oral hypoglycemia were independently associated with increased urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, while aspirin dose > or = 150 mg/d, history of treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, history of hypercholesterolemia, and statin therapy were associated with lower concentrations. Randomization to clopidogrel (versus placebo) did not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients in the highest quartile of urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) levels. In patients treated with aspirin, urinary concentrations of 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) are a valid, externally modifiable determinant of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death in patients at risk for atherothrombotic events.

This guideline focuses on anticoagulant drug therapies for the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease as well as for the relief of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in people with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The methods for this guideline follow those described in the Methodology for the Development of Anticoagulant Therapy and Thromboprophylaxis: Anticoagulant Therapy and Thrombosis Prophylaxis, Ninth Edition: Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Chest Physicians in this supplement. Our top 20 recommendations are as follows. In patients aged ≥ 50 years with asymptomatic peripheral artery disease or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we suggest aspirin (75-100 mg/day) without treatment (Grade 2b) for the primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (including patients before and after peripheral artery bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), we recommend long-term aspirin (75-100 mg/day). or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Grade 1A). We recommend that warfarin not be used in addition to aspirin in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (grade 1b). For patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stenting, we suggest single antiplatelet therapy rather than dual therapy (grade 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we suggest adding cilostazol (100 mg per day) to aspirin (75-100 mg per day) or clopidogrel (75 mg per day) (Grade 2C). In patients with critical limb ischemia and rest pain who are unable to undergo revascularization, we suggest the use of prostanoids (grade 2C). In patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgery to treat peripheral arterial thrombosis (Grade 1B). Recommendations continue to favor individualized antiplatelet therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in most patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis. Additional treatments to relieve extremity symptoms should be considered only after exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and evaluation of peripheral artery revascularization.

This guideline focuses on anticoagulant drug therapies for the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease as well as for the relief of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in people with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The methods for this guideline follow those described in the Methodology for the Development of Anticoagulant Therapy and Thromboprophylaxis: Anticoagulant Therapy and Thrombosis Prophylaxis, Ninth Edition: Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Chest Physicians in this supplement. Our top 20 recommendations are as follows. In patients aged ≥ 50 years with asymptomatic peripheral artery disease or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we suggest aspirin (75-100 mg/day) without treatment (Grade 2b) for the primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (including patients before and after peripheral artery bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), we recommend long-term aspirin (75-100 mg/day). or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Grade 1A). We recommend that warfarin not be used in addition to aspirin in patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (grade 1b). For patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stenting, we suggest single antiplatelet therapy rather than dual therapy (grade 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we suggest adding cilostazol (100 mg per day) to aspirin (75-100 mg per day) or clopidogrel (75 mg per day) (Grade 2C). In patients with critical limb ischemia and rest pain who are unable to undergo revascularization, we suggest the use of prostanoids (grade 2C). In patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgery to treat peripheral arterial thrombosis (Grade 1B). Recommendations continue to favor individualized antiplatelet therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in most patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis. Additional treatments to relieve extremity symptoms should be considered only after exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and evaluation of peripheral artery revascularization.

Bleeding, a common complication of treatment for acute myocardial infarction (AMI), is associated with worse outcomes. The contemporary model of major bleeding associated with AMI treatment can stratify patients at high risk of bleeding and is essential for adjusting AMI practice and outcomes. Using the Acute Coronary Intervention and Treatment Outcomes Network-Get Guidelines database (ACTION Registry-GWTG), an in-hospital major bleeding risk model was developed in a cohort of patients with ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction and non-ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction. High segment - myocardial infarction. The model used only baseline variables and was developed (n = 72,313) and validated (n = 17,960) in patients with AMI (at 251 US centers from January 2007 to December 2008). The 12 most statistically and clinically significant variables were combined in the final regression model. Calibration plots are shown, and model discrimination is shown across the derivation and validation sets, as well as across the major subsets. The major bleeding rate in the overall population was 10.8%. The 12 factors associated with major bleeding in the model were heart rate, baseline hemoglobin, female sex, baseline serum creatinine, age, ECG changes, heart failure or shock, diabetes, peripheral artery disease, body weight, and systolic blood pressure. And home warfarin. Uses. The model discriminated risks well in the derivation (C-statistic = 0.73) and validation (C-statistic = 0.71) cohorts. The risk score for major bleeding corresponded well to significant bleeding: very low risk (3.9%), low risk (7.3%), moderate risk (16.1%), high risk (29.0%), and very high risk (39.8%). In conclusion, the ACTION Registry-GWTG hospital major bleeding model stratifies the risk of major bleeding using variables at presentation and enables risk-adjusted bleeding outcomes for quality improvement initiatives and clinical decision making.

The combination of anticoagulant therapy and antiplatelet therapy is more effective than antiplatelet therapy alone in the initial and long-term management of acute coronary syndromes but increases the risk of bleeding. Antiplatelet therapy is often combined with oral anticoagulants in patients who have an indication for warfarin therapy (eg, atrial fibrillation) and who also have an indication for antiplatelet therapy (eg, coronary artery disease) but the suitability of such an approach is not yet resolved. Anticoagulation appears to be as effective as antiplatelet therapy in the long-term management of acute coronary syndrome, stroke, and possibly peripheral artery disease, but causes more bleeding. Therefore, in those patients who develop atrial fibrillation, a switch from antiplatelet therapy to anticoagulants may be all that is needed. The combination of anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy has been shown to provide additional benefit compared with anticoagulants alone in patients with prosthetic heart valves. The combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is not as effective as oral anticoagulants in patients with atrial fibrillation, while the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is more effective than oral anticoagulants in patients with coronary stenting. Whether the benefits of triple therapy outweigh the risks in patients with atrial fibrillation and coronary stenting requires evaluation in randomized trials.

Vascular disease is included in the risk scoring system for predicting stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (AF). This post-hoc analysis of ROCKET AF aims to determine the absolute rates of stroke and bleeding, and the relative efficacy and safety of rivaroxaban versus warfarin in patients with and without peripheral artery disease (PAD). Peripheral artery disease was defined in the case report form as the presence of intermittent claudication, amputation due to arterial insufficiency, endovascular reconstruction, bypass surgery, percutaneous extremity intervention, or previously documented abdominal aortic aneurysm. The ROCKET AF trial was a double-blind, double-dummy, randomized controlled trial comparing rivaroxaban with warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism. A total of 839 (5.9%) patients in ROCKET AF had PAD. Patients with and without peripheral artery disease had similar rates of stroke or systemic embolism [HR: 1.04, 95% CI (0.72, 1.50), P = 0.84] and major or non-major clinically relevant bleeding (NMCR) [HR : 1.11, 95%) CI (0.96, 1.28), P = 0.17], respectively. The effectiveness of rivaroxaban when compared with warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism was similar in patients with peripheral artery disease (HR: 1.19, 95% CI: 0.63-2.22) and those without peripheral artery disease (HR: 0.86, CI). 95%: 0.73-1.02). Interaction F = 0.34). There was a significant interaction of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding in patients with peripheral artery disease treated with rivaroxaban compared with warfarin (HR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.06-1.86) compared with those without peripheral artery disease (HR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.06-1.86). 1.03, 95% CI: 0.95-1.11). Interaction P = 0.037). Patients with peripheral artery disease in ROCKET AF did not have a statistically significantly higher risk of stroke or systemic embolism compared with patients without peripheral artery disease, and there were similar efficacy results in patients treated with rivaroxaban and warfarin. In PAD patients, there was a greater risk of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding with rivaroxaban compared with warfarin (interaction P = 0.037). Further investigation is warranted to validate this subgroup analysis and determine optimal treatment in this high-risk group of atrial fibrillation patients with PAD.

The management of warfarin therapy is complicated by the large inter-patient variability in response to the drug. Variants in the gene that encodes vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1) may affect response to warfarin. We performed a retrospective study of European American patients receiving long-term warfarin maintenance therapy. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to determine the effect of VKORC1 haplotypes on warfarin dose. We determined VKORC1 haplotype frequencies in African American, European American, and Asian American populations and VKORC1 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression in human liver samples. We identified 10 common VKORC1 non-coding single-nucleotide polymorphisms and deduced five major haplotypes. We defined the low-dose haplotype group (A) and the high-dose haplotype group (B). The mean (+/-SE) maintenance dose of warfarin differed significantly between the three haplotype group groups, at 2.7 +/- 0.2 mg per day for A/A, and 4.9 +/- 0.2 mg per day for A/B, and 6.2 +/- 0.3 mg daily for B/B (P < 0.001). VKORC1 haplotype groups A and B explained approximately 25 percent of the variation in dose. Asian Americans had a higher proportion of group A haplotypes, and African Americans had a higher proportion of group B haplotypes. VKORC1 mRNA levels vary according to haplotype group. VKORC1 haplotypes can be used to stratify patients into low-, medium-, and high-dose warfarin groups and may explain differences in dose requirements between patients of different ancestry. The molecular mechanism of warfarin dose response appears to be regulated at the transcriptional level.

Coumarin derivatives such as warfarin represent the treatment of choice for long-term treatment and prevention of thromboembolic events. Coumarin targets blood clotting by inhibiting vitamin K multiprotein reductase (VKOR). This complex recycles vitamin K 2,3-epoxide to vitamin K hydroquinone, an essential cofactor for the post-translational gamma carboxylation of many blood clotting factors. Despite extensive efforts, the components of the VKOR complex have not been identified. The complex has been proposed to be involved in two genetic human diseases: vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor deficiency type 2 (VKCFD2; Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) 607473), and resistance to coumarin-type anticoagulant drugs (warfarin). Resistivity, WR; OMIM 122700). Here we identify, using binding information from three species, subunit 1 of the vitamin K epoxide reductase gene (VKORC1), which encodes a small transmembrane protein of the endoplasmic reticulum. VKORC1 contains missense mutations in both human disorders and in a warfarin-resistant mouse strain. Overexpression of wild-type VKORC1, but not VKORC1 carrying a VKCFD2 mutation, results in a marked increase in VKOR activity, which is sensitive to warfarin inhibition.

Current dosing algorithms do not take into account genetic and environmental factors to determine the warfarin dose. This study investigated the contribution of age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and body size to warfarin dose requirements. The study included 297 patients with stable anticoagulation with a target international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0 to 3.0. Genetic analyzes for CYP2C9 (*2 and *3 alleles) and VKORC1 (polymorphism -1639) were performed and intravenous INR and plasma R- and S-warfarin concentrations were determined. Mean daily warfarin dose requirements were highest in patients with the CYP2C9 homozygous wild-type, compared with those with the *2 and *3 variant alleles (P < .001) and highest in patients with the VKORC1 genotype. (position -1639) GG compared with those with the GA genotype and the AA genotype (P < .001). The average daily dose requirement of warfarin decreased by 0.5 to 0.7 mg per decade between ages 20 to 90 years. Age, height, and CYP2C9 genotype contributed significantly to S-warfarin clearance and complete warfarin clearance, whereas only age and body size significantly contributed to R-warfarin clearance. A multivariable regression model including the variables age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and height produced the best model for estimating warfarin dose (R2 = 55%). Based on the data, a new warfarin dosing regimen was developed. The dosing regimen was validated in a second group of patients receiving warfarin therapy.

Initiating warfarin therapy using trial-and-error dosing is difficult. Our goal was to develop and validate a pharmacokinetic algorithm. In the derivation cohort of 1015 participants, independent predictors of therapeutic dose were: VKORC1 -1639/3673 G>A polymorphism (-28% per allele), body surface area (BSA) (+11% per 0.25 m(2)) , CYP2C9(*)3 (-33% per allele), CYP2C9(*)2 (-19% per allele), Age (-7% per decade), Target International Normalized Ratio (INR) (+11% per 0.5 units increase), amiodarone use (-22%), smoker status (+10%), race (-9%), and current coagulopathy (+7%). This pharmacokinetic equation explained 53–54% of the variance in warfarin dose in the derivation and validation cohorts (n = 292). For comparison, clinical equation explained only 17-22% of dose variance (P < 0.001). In the validation cohort, we prospectively used a drug dosing algorithm in patients who initiated warfarin therapy, two of whom had major bleeding. To facilitate the use of these pharmacological and clinical algorithms, we have developed a non-profit website, http://www.WarfarinDosing.org.

Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying individuals most at risk of harm from certain drugs. Routine adoption of pharmaceutical tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The present review aims to systematically review published economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at preventing or reducing the occurrence of adverse drug reactions. We conducted a systematic literature review of economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms relating to drug tests, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were screened independently by two reviewers. Articles considered to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened for abstract and full texts. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58:01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19. (Before treatment with clopidogrel). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptobutene, azathioprine, and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (for informing genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate), and Factor V Leiden testing (before treatment with methotrexate). For oral contraception). Testing for A1555G is not cost-effective before prescribing aminoglycosides. Our systematic review identified strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of pre-treatment genotyping with a number of common drugs. However, further analyzes and/or strong clinical evidence are necessary to make recommendations to others.

This article summarizes the discussions of the third European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Conference in Biomedicine on Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, held in June 2010 in Spain. It focused on practical applications in routine medical practice. We provide practical recommendations for ten different clinical situations, both approved and unapproved by regulatory bodies. We suggest some notes that may accompany the results of these tests, which indicate the best medication and doses that should be prescribed. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, and HLA-B*5701. -. Flucloxacillin, SLCO1B1-statins and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. We hope that these practical recommendations will help clinicians, biologists, scientists, and other health care professionals describe, perform, and interpret these genetic tests.

Serious adverse drug reactions represent the sixth leading cause of death in the United States, are the leading cause of post-marketing drug withdrawal and represent costs in the billions of US dollars each year in all developed countries. Some of these serious adverse drug reactions can be avoided by systematic screening for drug genetic risk factors. Over the past few years, regulatory agencies have introduced pharmacogenomic labeling for many drugs, but although prior genetic testing remains recommended or recommended, it is rarely mandatory due to poor evidence-based medical knowledge. Recently published ongoing randomized controlled pharmacogenomic trials will gradually make genotyping tests, such as tests for HLA-B*5701 (abacavir), TPMT (6-mercaptopurine), CYP2C9 plus VKORC1 (warfarin), and CYP3A5 (tacrolimus), mandatory. The parallel development of pharmacogenomic bedside tests will certainly lead to the establishment of gene-based prescriptions in routine medical practice.

Pharmacogenomics seeks to explain interindividual variation in response to drugs due to genetic variation. Although technological advances have provided us with easy and relatively cheap methods for genotyping, the promise of personalized medicine has not yet met our high expectations. Successful results achieved in the field of pharmacogenomics to date are, but not limited to, HLA-B*5701 screening to avoid hypersensitivity to the antiretroviral abacavir, thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) genotyping to avoid thiopurine toxicity, and CYP2C9 and CYP2C9. . VKORC1 genotyping for optimal dosing of the anticoagulant warfarin. However, there are few pharmacological examples that have entered clinical practice in the treatment of complex diseases. Unfortunately, the lack of reproducibility of observational studies involving many genes and diseases appears to be a common pattern in pharmacogenomics studies. In this article we address some methodological and statistical issues in study design, gene and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) selection, and data analysis that should be considered in future pharmacogenomics research. First, we discuss some issues related to the design of epidemiological studies, specific to pharmacogenomics research. Second, we describe some of the pros and cons of the candidate gene approach (including gene and SNP selection) and the genome-wide scanning approach. Finally, traditional and several innovative approaches have been proposed to analyze large pharmacogenomic datasets that address the issues of multiplexing and systems biology in different ways.

Cytochrome P450 2C19 (CYP2C19) is the major (or partial) cause of significant differences in the pharmacokinetics of a number of clinically important drugs. On the basis of their ability to metabolize (S)-mephenytoin or other CYP2C19 substrates, individuals can be classified as extensive metabolizers (EMs) or poor metabolizers (PMs). Eight different alleles (CYP2C19*2 to CYP2C19*8) that predict PMs have been identified. The distribution of EM and PM genotypes and phenotypes shows wide differences between ethnicities. Non-genetic factors such as enzyme inhibition and induction, aging, and liver fibrosis can also modify CYP2C19 activity. In emergency settings, approximately 80% of doses of the proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) omeprazole, lansoprazole, and pantoprazole appear to be eliminated by CYP2C19, whereas CYP3A is more important in cases of PMs. Exposure to these drugs has been observed to be five-fold higher in PMs compared to EMs for CYP2C19, and further increases occur during inhibition of alternative metabolic pathways catalyzed by CYP3A in PMs. As a result, PMs of CYP2C19 have more effective acid suppression and better healing of duodenal and gastric ulcers during treatment with omeprazole and lansoprazole compared with EMs. The pharmacoeconomic value of CYP2C19 genotyping remains unclear. Our calculations suggest that genotyping for CYP2C19 could save approximately $5,000 for every 100 Asians tested, but nothing for Caucasian patients. However, genotyping for common alleles of CYP2C19 before initiating proton pump inhibitors for the treatment of reflux disease and H. pylori infection is a cost-effective tool to determine the appropriate duration of treatment regimens and dosing. Altered CYP2C19 activity does not appear to increase the risk of adverse drug reactions/proton pump inhibitor interactions. Phenytoin plasma concentrations and toxicity have been shown to be increased in patients taking CYP2C19 inhibitors or who have variant alleles, and because of its narrow therapeutic range, genotyping for CYP2C19 in addition to CYP2C9 may be needed to optimize the dose of phenytoin. The risk of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity may be increased in patients whose CYP2C19 and/or CYP2D6 activities are diminished. CYP2C19 is a key enzyme in the activation of proguanil to cycloguanil, but there are no clinical data to suggest that PMs of CYP2C19 are at greater risk for malaria prophylaxis or treatment failure. Diazepam clearance is clearly diminished in PMs or when CYP2C19 inhibitors are co-prescribed, but clinical consequences are generally minimal. Finally, several studies have attempted to determine relationships between CYP2C19 genotype and phenotype and susceptibility to diseases caused by xenobiotics, but none of these studies have been convincing.

Voriconazole is the treatment of choice for aspergillosis and a new treatment option for candidiasis. Liver disease, age, CYP2C19 gene polymorphisms, and comedic medications affect the metabolism of voriconazole. Significant differences in voriconazole pharmacokinetics may be associated with reduced efficacy or toxicity. This study was conducted to evaluate the utility of measuring voriconazole blood levels with individual dose adjustments. A total of 181 measurements using high-pressure liquid chromatography were performed during 2388 treatment days in 52 patients. Considerable variation in blood voriconazole levels has been observed, ranging from <or=1 mg/L (minimum inhibitory concentration at which 90% of isolates are susceptible to most fungal pathogens) in 25% of cases to >5.5 mg/L. L (level possibly associated with toxicity) in 31% of cases. Non-response to treatment was more common in patients with voriconazole levels < or = 1 mg/L (6 [46%] of 13 patients, including 5 patients with aspergillosis, 4 of whom were treated orally at a median dose of 6 mg/L). kg per day) compared with those with voriconazole levels > 1 mg/L (15 [12%] of 39 patients; P = .02). Blood levels >1 mg/L were achieved after voriconazole dose increases, with complete resolution of infection in all six cases. Among 16 patients with low blood voriconazole levels >5.5 mg/L, 5 patients (31%) developed encephalopathy, including 4 patients treated intravenously with a mean voriconazole dose of 8 mg/kg daily, while no None of the patients with levels < or = 5.5 mg/L presented with neurotoxicity (P = 0.002). Chemotherapy with omeprazole may have contributed to voriconazole accumulation in 4 patients. In all cases, discontinuation of treatment resulted in rapid and complete neurological recovery. Voriconazole therapeutic drug monitoring improves the efficacy and safety of treatment in critically ill patients with invasive fungi.

Many drugs, including proton pump inhibitors and some antidepressants, are metabolized by the polymorphic enzyme cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2C19. A significant portion of the broad-spectrum metabolites do not reach appropriate drug levels, and our goal was to investigate any genetic background. The 5'-flanking region of the CYP2C19 gene from subjects with rapid omeprazole metabolizers was sequenced, and the phenotype-genotype associations of CYP2C19 in Swedish (n = 107) and Ethiopian (n = 126) were analyzed in large-scale metabolizers. The relationship between the omeprazole metabolism ratio (omeprazole/5-hydroxy omeprazole in plasma 3 hours after drug administration) with the area under the plasma concentration-time curve has been used in prediction studies. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays were performed using human nuclear protein extracts. Liver reporter vector transfections were performed into CD1 mice. We identified a novel allele (CYP2C19*17) carrying -806C>T and -3402C>T, with a frequency of 18% in both Swedes and Ethiopians and 4% in Chinese subjects. In Swedes, the rate of metabolism of omeprazole was higher in subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.50 [interquartile range, 0.37-0.73]) than in those homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0.25 [interquartile range, 0.15-0.33]) ( P = .010). In Ethiopians, a similar difference in the S/R-mephenytoin ratio was observed between individuals homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.20 [interquartile range, 0.12-0.37]) and those homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0.05 [interquartile range, 0.05] 0.03). -0.06]) (P = 0.013). Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific binding of human hepatic nuclear proteins to a motif carrying -806T but not -806C. Reporter vector experiments demonstrated increased transcriptional activity of the CYP2C19*17 allele in vivo in mice. Projections revealed that CYP2C19*17 homozygotes would achieve 35% to 40% lower area under the plasma concentration-time curve values ​​than CYP2C19*1 homozygotes taking standard doses of omeprazole. CYP2C19*17 has the potential to cause therapeutic failure with drug therapy, for example, with proton pump inhibitors and antidepressants.

Human CYP2Cs are an important subfamily of P450 enzymes that metabolize approximately 20% of clinically used drugs. There are four members in the subfamily, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, and CYP2C18. Of these, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19 are of clinical importance. CYP2Cs also metabolize some endogenous compounds such as arachidonic acid. Every member of this subfamily has been found to be genetically polymorphic. The best known of these polymorphisms is in CYP2C19. Poor metabolizers (PMs) of CYP2C19 represent approximately 3-5% of Caucasians, a similar percentage of African Americans and 12-100% of Asian groups. The polymorphism affects the metabolism of the anticonvulsant agent mephenytoin, proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole, the anxiolytic agent diazepam, some antidepressants, and the antimalarial drug proguanil. Toxic effects can occur in patients with PM exposed to diazepam, and the effectiveness of some proton pump inhibitors may be greater in PM than EM at low doses of these drugs. There are a number of mutant alleles that can be detected by genetic testing. CYP2C9 metabolizes a wide range of drugs including the anticoagulant warfarin, antidiabetic agents such as tolbutamide, anticonvulsants such as phenytoin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The incidence of functional polymorphisms is much lower, estimated at 1/250 in Caucasians and lower in Asians. However, the clinical consequences of these rare polymorphisms can be severe. Severe, life-threatening bleeding events have been reported in CYP2C9 PM patients exposed to warfarin. Phenytoin has been reported to cause severe toxicity in PMs. New polymorphisms have been discovered in CYP2C8, which metabolizes Taxol (paclitaxel). Genetic testing is available for all known CYP2C alleles.

Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying individuals most at risk of harm from certain drugs. Routine adoption of pharmaceutical tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The present review aims to systematically review published economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at preventing or reducing the occurrence of adverse drug reactions. We conducted a systematic literature review of economic evaluations of drug tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms relating to drug tests, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were screened independently by two reviewers. Articles considered to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened for abstract and full texts. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58:01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19. (Before treatment with clopidogrel). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptobutene, azathioprine, and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (for informing genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate), and Factor V Leiden testing (before treatment with methotrexate). For oral contraception). Testing for A1555G is not cost-effective before prescribing aminoglycosides. Our systematic review identified strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of pre-treatment genotyping with a number of common drugs. However, further analyzes and/or strong clinical evidence are necessary to make recommendations to others.

This article summarizes the discussions of the third European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Conference in Biomedicine on Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, held in June 2010 in Spain. It focused on practical applications in routine medical practice. We provide practical recommendations for ten different clinical situations, both approved and unapproved by regulatory bodies. We suggest some notes that may accompany the results of these tests, which indicate the best medication and doses that should be prescribed. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, and HLA-B*5701. -. Flucloxacillin, SLCO1B1-statins and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. We hope that these practical recommendations will help clinicians, biologists, scientists, and other health care professionals describe, perform, and interpret these genetic tests.

During HIV infection and/or antiretroviral therapy (ART), monocytes and macrophages exhibit a wide range of dysfunctions that significantly contribute to HIV pathogenesis and treatment-related complications. However, the molecular components that contribute to these imbalances remain elusive. We therefore applied a parallel approach of genome-wide microarray analysis and focused gene expression profiling on monocytes from patients at different stages of HIV infection and/or ART to further characterize these dysfunctions. Processes involving apoptosis, cell cycle, lipid metabolism, proteasome function, protein trafficking and transcriptional regulation have been identified as areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection. Individual genes potentially contributing to these monocyte imbalances included several novel factors. One of these is the adipocytokin NAMPT/visfatin, which we have shown is able to inhibit HIV at an early step in its life cycle. Approximately half of the identified genes were restored to control levels under ART, while the other genes represented persistent dysregulation. In addition, several candidate biomarkers (particularly CCL1 and CYP2C19) have been proposed for the development of abacavir hypersensitivity reaction. Previously described areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection were confirmed, and new themes were identified. Furthermore, individual genes associated with these imbalances and disorders associated with ART have been identified. These genes form a useful basis for further functional studies regarding the contribution of monocytes/macrophages to HIV pathogenesis. One of these genes, NAMPT/visfatin, represents a potential new restriction factor for HIV.

Pharmacogenomic studies contribute to our understanding of interindividual differences in response to antiretroviral drugs. Genetic polymorphisms in histocompatibility complex genes predict the likelihood of hypersensitivity reactions in people prescribed abacavir, and possibly nevirapine. Recent studies have shown that polymorphisms in the CYP2B6 gene are associated with higher efavirenz plasma concentrations and increased CNS side effects. Polymorphisms in the MDR1 gene that encodes the drug pump, P-glycoprotein, may predict nevirapine-associated hepatotoxicity and long-term virological response to efavirenz. CYP2C19 polymorphisms predict nelfinavir plasma levels and possibly the risk of virologic failure on this drug. The European Mitochondrial Haplogroup may predict an increased risk of peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors. Expanding and refining knowledge regarding associations between human genetics and response to antiretroviral drugs may eventually allow treatment to be personalized based on genotyping. This article summarizes a presentation on HIV therapeutics and pharmacogenomics given by David W. Haas, MD, at the International AIDS Society USA session in Atlanta in March 2005.

Many long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) are natural ligands for non-ruminant peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG), which, along with their adipogenic target genes, are upregulated in bovine mammary tissue during lactation. Thus, PPARG may represent an important control point in bovine milk lipid synthesis. We tested the expression of the adipogenic gene network via quantitative PCR for 19 genes in bovine mammary epithelial cells cultured with 16:0, 18:0, cis-9 18:1, trans-10 18:1, trans-10, cis-12 18: 2[t10c12 conjugated linoleic acid (CLA)], 20:5, ethanol (control), and the PPARG agonist rosiglitazone (ROSI). Triplicate cultures were maintained for 12 h with 50 mM ROSI or 100 mM LCFA. Combined responses between 16:0 and 18:0 relative to control included significantly greater expression of INSIG1 (+298%, +92%), AGPAT6 (+137%, +169%), FABP3 (+755%, +338%), and FABP4 (+171%, 157%). This was coupled with greater intracellular lipid droplet formation and mRNA for ACSS2, LPIN1, SCD and SREBF2 in response to 16:0, and greater DGAT1 and THRSP at 18:0. Trans-10 18:1 and t10c12 CLA reduced the expression of FASN (-60%, -31%), SCD (-100%, -357%), and SREBF1 (-49%, -189%). Moreover, t10c12 CLA upregulated the expression of ACSS2, FABP3, INSIG1, SREBF2 and THRSP. Expression of SREBF1 was lower with cis-9 18:1 (-140%) and 20:5 (-125%) compared to control. This latter LCFA also reduced the expression of SCD, SREBF2, and LPL. No effects of LCFA or ROSI on PPARG were observed, but ROSI upregulated (+39% to +269%) the expression of ACACA, FASN, LPIN1, AGPAT6, DGAT1, SREBF1, SREBF2, and INSIG1. Thus, these genes are putative PPARG target genes in bovine mammary cells. This is the first report demonstrating the direct effect of trans-10 18:1 on adipogenic gene expression of bovine mammary cells. Coordinated regulation of adipogenic gene networks in response to ROSI and saturating LCFA provides support for PPARG activation in the regulation of bovine milk lipid synthesis.

In adipose tissue, muscle, liver, and macrophages, signaling by the nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPAR-γ) is one of the determinants of insulin sensitivity and this receptor mediates the insulin-sensitizing effects of thiazolidinediones (TZDs). Because PPAR-γ is also expressed in neurons, we generated mice with neuron-specific Pparg knockout (brain Pparg knockout (BKO)) to determine whether neuronal PPAR-γ signaling contributes to weight gain or insulin sensitivity. During feeding with a high-fat diet (HFD), food intake was reduced and energy expenditure was increased in Pparg-BKO mice compared to Pparg(f/f) mice, resulting in reduced weight gain. Pparg-BKO mice also responded better to leptin administration compared to Pparg(f/f) mice. When treated with the TZD rosiglitazone, Pparg-BKO mice were resistant to rosiglitazone-induced hyperphagia and weight gain, and compared with rosiglitazone-treated Pparg(f/f) mice, only marginally improved glucose metabolism. Hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemic clamp studies showed that the increase in hepatic insulin sensitivity induced by rosiglitazone treatment during HFD feeding was completely abolished in Pparg-BKO mice, an effect associated with the failure of rosiglitazone to improve insulin receptor signal transduction in the liver. We conclude that weight gain induced by high-density feeding depends in part on the effect of neuronal PPAR-γ signaling to reduce thermogenesis and increase food intake. Neuronal PPAR-γ signaling is also required for the hepatic insulin-sensitizing effects of TZDs.

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR gamma) is an important regulator of lipid and glucose homeostasis and cellular differentiation. Studies on many cell types in vitro and in vivo have demonstrated that activation of PPAR gamma can reduce cell proliferation. Here we show that activation of PPAR gamma is sufficient to reduce the proliferation of cultured insulinoma cell lines. We created a model with mice in which expression of the PPARG gene in beta cells was knocked out (beta gamma KO mice), and these mice were found to have significant islet hypertrophy on a chow diet. Interestingly, the normal expansion of beta cell mass that occurs in control mice in response to high-fat feeding is markedly impaired in these animals. Despite this change in beta cell mass, no effect on glucose homeostasis was observed in beta gamma KO mice. In addition, while thiazolidinediones enhanced insulin secretion from cultured wild-type islets, administration of rosiglitazone to insulin-resistant control and beta-gamma KO mice revealed that PPAR gamma in beta cells is not required for the antidiabetic actions of these compounds. These data demonstrate an important physiological role for PPAR gamma function in beta cell proliferation and also suggest that the mechanisms controlling beta cell hypertrophy in obesity differ from those regulating basic islet cell mass.

Nocturnin (NOC) is a circadian-regulated protein associated with the yeast family of transcription factors involved in cellular response to nutrient status. In mammals, NOC functions as a deadenylase but lacks a transcriptional activation domain. It is highly expressed in bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs), hepatocytes, and adipocytes. In BMSCs exposed to PPAR-gamma (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma) rosiglitazone, Noc expression was enhanced 30-fold. Previously, we reported that Noc(−/−) mice had low body temperature, were protected from diet-induced obesity, and most importantly showed an absence of the circadian rhythm Pparg on a high-fat diet. Consistent with its role in influencing the allocation of BMSCs, Noc(-/-) mice have reduced bone marrow adiposity and higher bone mass. In the same context, overexpression of NOC promotes adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 cells but negatively regulates osteogenesis in MC3T3-E1 cells. NOC and the mutant form, which lacks deadenylase activity, bind to PPAR-gamma and markedly enhance PPAR-gamma transcriptional activity. Both WT and mutant NOC facilitate nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma. Importantly, NOC-mediated nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma is blocked by a short peptide fragment of NOC that prevents its physical interaction with PPAR-gamma. The inhibitory effect of this NOC peptide was partially reversed by rosiglitazone, suggesting that the effect of NOC on nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma may be independent of ligand-mediated PPAR-gamma activation. In summary, Noc plays a unique role in regulating mesenchymal stem cell lineage allocation by modulating PPAR-gamma activity through nuclear translocation. These data demonstrate a unique mechanism by which a nutrient-responsive gene affects BMSCs differentiation, adipogenesis, and ultimately body composition.

In this study we sought to test the hypothesis that genetic factors may influence antidepressant response to fluoxetine. The research focused on seven candidate genes in the serotonergic pathway involved in serotonin synthesis, transport, recognition and degradation. Our clinical sample consisted of 96 individuals with unipolar major depression treated with fluoxetine with response variables assessed after a 12-week trial. Patient data were also collected to investigate the pattern of response to medications. Using a high-throughput single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping platform and capillary electrophoresis, we genotyped patients at 110 SNPs and four repeat polymorphisms located in seven candidate genes (HTR1A, HTR2A, HTR2C, MAOA, SLC6A4, TPH1, and TPH2). Statistical tests performed included locus and haplotype linkage tests, and linkage disequilibrium (LD) estimation. Little evidence of population stratification was observed in the sample containing 20 random SNPs using the genomic control procedure.
