The three gene signatures of periostin, chloride channel annexin 1 (CLCA1), and Serpin β2 (SERPINB2) in the airway epithelial brush are used to classify asthma into high-TH2 and low-TH2 endophenotypes. Little is known about the utility of sputum genotyping as a molecular phenotyping method. We sought to determine whether genotyping in sputum cells could identify T(H)2-high and T(H)2-low asthma subtypes. In induced sputum cell pellets from 37 asthma patients and 15 healthy control subjects, PCR was used to profile gene expression of the epithelial cell signature of IL-13 activation (periostin, CLCA1, and SERPINB2), and Th2 genes (IL4, IL5, and IL13). ), and other genes associated with Th2 airway inflammation. Gene expression levels of CLCA1 and periostin, but not SerpinB2, were significantly higher than normal in the sputum cells of people with asthma. Expression levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 were also significantly increased in asthma patients and were significantly correlated within individual subjects. By combining the expression levels of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 into a single quantitative measure (“average T(H)2 gene”), 26 (70%) of the 37 asthma patients had T(H) 2- High asthma, which is characterized by severe asthma symptoms and increased eosinophilia in the blood and sputum. Mean values ​​of the TH2 gene tend to be stable when initial values ​​are very high or very low but fluctuate above or below the maximum height of T(H)2 when initial values ​​are average. Transcripts of IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 can be easily detected in sputum cells of asthma patients, and their expression levels can be used to classify asthma into high-T(H)2 and low-T(H)2 endophenotypes.

Chitin is an essential structural polysaccharide for fungal pathogens and parasites, but its role in human immune responses remains largely unknown. It is the second most abundant polysaccharide in nature after cellulose, and its derivatives are widely used today for medical and industrial purposes. We analyzed the immunomodulatory properties of purified chitin particles derived from the opportunistic human fungal pathogen Candida albicans, resulting in selective secretion of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. We have identified NOD2, TLR9, and mannose receptors as essential fungal chitin recognition receptors for the induction of this response. Chitin reduces LPS-induced inflammation in vivo and thus may contribute to the resolution of the immune response once the pathogen is defeated. Fungal chitin also causes eosinophilia in vivo, enhancing its ability to induce asthma. Polymorphisms in specific chitin receptors, NOD2 and TLR9, predispose individuals to inflammatory conditions and dysregulated expression of chitinases and chitinase-related proteins, whose activity is essential for the generation of IL-10-stimulating innate chitin molecules in vitro, has also been linked to inflammatory conditions and asthma. Chitin recognition is therefore critical for immune homeostasis and likely has an important role in infectious and allergic diseases.

Interactions with microbial pathogens are critical for the maturation of the immune system. Nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 1 (NOD1) protein is a cytosolic receptor that senses a muropeptide found predominantly in Gram-negative bacterial peptidoglycan. NOD1 is located on chromosome 7p14-p15, a region that has been linked to atopy. Recently, NOD2 polymorphisms have been closely associated with atopy-related traits. Within a large German adult population (n = 1417), a case-control group for atopic eczema (n = 454), and a large cohort of parent-offspring triads with atopic eczema (189 triads), we evaluated 11 NOD1 polymorphisms for associations with atopic patterns. . Methods Subjects were classified through standardized questionnaires and interviews, skin examination, and blood IgE measurements. Genotyping was performed using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time of flight mass spectrometry. Analyzes revealed a significant association between NOD1 haplotype and atopic eczema in the population-based cohort ( P = .004) and case-control group ( P = .003). Another NOD1 haplotype was associated with lower total IgE ( P = .008). In addition, significant associations with total serum IgE levels were observed for the rs2907748 ( P = .006), rs2907749 ( P = .012), and rs2075822 ( P = .018) polymorphisms. These polymorphisms were significantly associated with atopic eczema and asthma in familial association analyzes ( P = .001-.043). Seven polymorphisms showed significant transmission distortion of total IgE levels (P values ​​<.0001-.029). These data suggest that genetic variants within NOD1 are important determinants of atopy susceptibility.

Nucleotide and oligomerization domain-like receptors (NLRs) are highly conserved cytosolic pattern recognition receptors that perform critical functions in scanning the intracellular environment for the presence of infections, harmful substances, and metabolic disturbances. Sensing of these danger signals by NLRs leads to their oligomerization into large molecular scaffolds and rapid deployment of effector signaling cascades to restore homeostasis. While some NLRs function by recruiting and activating inflammatory caspases to inflammasomes, others trigger inflammation via alternative pathways including nuclear factor-κB, mitogen-activated protein kinase, and regulatory factor pathways. The critical role that NLRs play in development and physiology is demonstrated by their pronounced effects on human diseases. Mutations in the genes encoding NLRP3 or NLRP12 lead to hereditary periodic fever syndromes, while mutations in CARD15 encoding NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease or Blau syndrome. Genome-wide association studies (GWASs) have identified a number of risk alleles involving NLR genes in a range of diseases including allergic rhinitis, multiple sclerosis, inflammatory bowel disease, asthma, multibacillary leprosy, vitiligo, premature menopause, and osteoporosis. Loss of density in older women. Animal models have allowed the characterization of basic effector mechanisms in a number of conditions. In this review, we highlight the functions of NLRs in health and disease and discuss how characterization of their molecular mechanisms provides new insights into therapeutic strategies for managing inflammatory diseases.

In wealthy, developed parts of the world, there has been a steady and simultaneous increase in at least three groups of diseases: (1) allergies, (2) inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD; such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis), and (3) autoimmune (such as... Type 1 diabetes and multiple sclerosis). Because the medical world is so divided, it will be some time before the relationship between these increases is noticed and understood. There is now evidence that the concurrent increase in these immune dysregulatory diseases is at least in part due to dysfunction of regulatory T cells (Treg). This paper provides an overview of relevant work in each of these areas of medicine (although with a focus on allergic disorders), and concludes that increased Treg failure is a consequence of diminished exposure to certain microorganisms that are “old friends.” Because of its constant presence throughout mammalian evolution. These organisms, which include saprophytic mycobacteria, helminths, and lactobacilli, are recognized by the innate immune system as harmless and as adjunctive to Treg induction. Polymorphisms in components of the innate immune system, such as TLR2 and NOD2, appear to define subgroups of the population that will develop immune regulatory disorders when living in the modern environment. An additional role played by these “old friends” and Treg may be to maintain the levels of IL-10 secreting regulatory macrophages and antigen-presenting cells, which are depleted in asthma and Crohn's disease. These concepts lead to new treatments based on harmless organisms or their components. Phase 1 and 2 clinical trials have yielded some statistically significant results, and phase 2 trials are still in progress.

The action of tissue transglutaminase (TGase) on specific glutamine residues bound to protein plays a crucial role in many biological processes. Here we provide evidence for a novel role for this enzyme in HLA-DQ2 (and DQ8)-associated enteropathy and celiac disease (CD). Intestinal inflammation in CD is accelerated by exposure to wheat gliadin in the diet and is associated with increased mucosal TGase activity. This enzyme has also been identified as the main target of CD-associated anti-Indomysium autoantibodies, and is known to accept gliadin as one of its few substrates. We examined the possibility that TGase may be involved in modulating gliadin-specific T cell reactivity. This could establish a link between previous reports on the role of TGase in CD and the prevailing view of CD as a T-cell-mediated disorder. We found a specific effect of TGase on T cell recognition of gliadin. This effect was limited to gliadin-specific T cells isolated from intestinal CD lesions. We have demonstrated that TGase mediates its effect through a regulated and specific deubiquitination of gliadin. This immunoprecipitation creates an epitope that efficiently binds to DQ2 and is recognized by gut-derived T cells. The generation of epitopes via enzymatic modification is a novel mechanism that may be relevant to tolerance breaking and the initiation of autoimmune diseases.

Wheat, rye and barley proteins trigger celiac disease, a type of autoimmune disorder of the digestive system, in genetically susceptible people. Because the disease may be underdiagnosed, we estimated the prevalence of the disease and tested the hypothesis that serum antibody assays can be used to detect untreated celiac disease and that positive results are associated with specific HLA haplotypes. Serum samples were collected from 3654 students (age range 7–16 years) in 1994 and screened in 2001 for endogenous and tissue transglutaminase antibodies. HLA typing was also performed on stored blood samples. All people with positive antibodies were asked to undergo a small bowel biopsy in 2001. Of the 3,654 people, 56 (1.5 percent) had positive antibody tests, as defined in 2001. The results of the two antibody tests were identical to an extent big. As of 1994, none of the subjects had received a clinical diagnosis of celiac disease, but 10 who had positive tests for both antibodies in serum obtained in 1994 had received the diagnosis between 1994 and 2001. Of the other 36 subjects with tests Positive for antibodies who consented to undergo a biopsy In 2001, 27 people had evidence of celiac disease on the biopsy. Thus, the biopsy-estimated prevalence was 1 case in 99 children. All but two of the people with the antibodies had either the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotype. The prevalence of the combination of antibody positivity and HLA haplotype associated with celiac disease was 1 in 67. The presence of serum tissue transglutaminase and endogenous autoantibodies is suggestive of small bowel abnormalities suggestive of celiac disease. There is a good correlation between antibody positivity and specific HLA patterns. We estimate that the prevalence of celiac disease among Finnish schoolchildren is at least 1 case in 99 children.

The vast majority of patients who are wheat gluten protein intolerant due to celiac disease (CD) are human histocompatibility leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2(+), and the remaining few typically express HLA-DQ8. These two class II molecules are mainly responsible for presenting gluten peptides to gluten-specific T cells which are only found in the intestine of CD patients but not in controls. Interestingly, tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-mediated deglutaminase plays an important role in the recognition of this food antigen by intestinal T cells. Here we have used recombinant antigens to demonstrate that the intestinal T cell response to α-gliadin in adult CD focuses on two DQ2-restricted immunogenic peptides that overlap a seven-residue fragment of gliadin. We have shown that tTG converts glutamine residues within this fragment into glutamic acid and that this process is essential for T cell recognition. Gluten-specific T cell lines from 16 different adult patients responded to one or both of these deamidated peptides, suggesting that these epitopes are highly relevant to the pathogenesis of the disease. Binding studies showed that deamidated peptides showed increased affinity for DQ2, a molecule known to preferentially bind peptides and which contains negatively charged residues. Interestingly, modified glutamine is internalized into different pockets of DQ2 for different epitopes. These results suggest modifications to anchor residues lead to improved major histocompatibility complex (MHC) affinity, and altered conformation of the peptide-MHC complex may be a critical factor leading to T cell responses to gliadin and intolerance to oral gluten. CD.

Although prescriptions for a gluten-free diet to treat gastrointestinal symptoms in individuals who do not have celiac disease are increasing, there is little evidence to suggest that gluten is the culprit. The goals of this study were to determine whether eating gluten can cause symptoms in non-celiac individuals and to examine the mechanism. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled rechallenge trial was performed in patients with irritable bowel syndrome in whom celiac disease was ruled out and whose symptoms were controlled on a gluten-free diet. Participants received either gluten or placebo in the form of two slices of bread plus one bagel per day with a gluten-free diet for up to 6 weeks. Symptoms were assessed using a visual analogue scale and signs of intestinal inflammation, injury, and immune activation were monitored. A total of 34 patients (aged 29-59 years, 4 men) completed the study according to protocol. Overall, 56% had human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 and/or HLA-DQ8. Adherence to diet and supplements was very high. Of the 19 patients (68%) in the gluten group, 13 reported that symptoms were not adequately controlled compared with 6 of 15 (40%) who took placebo (P = 0.0001; generalized estimating equation). On the visual analog scale, patients were significantly gluten-free at 1 week for overall symptoms (P = 0.047), pain (P = 0.016), bloating (P = 0.031), satisfaction with stool consistency (P = 0.024), and fatigue. (p = 0.001). Antibodies to gliadin were not induced. There were no significant changes in stool lactoferrin, celiac antibody levels, hypersensitivity C-reactive protein, or intestinal permeability. There were no differences in any endpoint in individuals with or without DQ2/DQ8. There may be a “non-celiac gluten intolerance,” but no evidence of the mechanism has been elucidated.

Genomic typing for HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 was performed for 50 patients with dermatitis herpetiformis and 290 healthy blood donors. Genes encoding DQ (alpha 1*0501, beta 1*02) were carried by 43 (86%) patients and 72 (25%) controls. Of the remaining seven patients, six (12% of all patients) carried genes encoding the DQ dimer (alpha 1*03, beta 1*0302). These HLA associations are very similar to those observed in patients with celiac disease. We therefore conclude that dermatitis herpetiformis and celiac disease are associated with the same HLA-DQ alpha beta variant.

The role of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 heterodimer (DQA1*0501-DQB1*0201) in presenting gluten peptides to effector T cells has been well documented in celiac disease (CD). Because HLA-DQ2 is carried on DR3 haplotypes due to linkage disequilibrium, such haplotypes are more frequently encountered in patients with autoimmune diseases. This study analyzed 35 north Indian children younger than 15 years of age who were diagnosed with CD according to the ESPGAN criteria, which included histological changes in duodenal biopsies, clinical response to gluten withdrawal, and the presence of anti-endothelin antibodies. HLA class I and class II alleles were identified by PCR-specific primers, sequence-specific oligonucleotide probes, and reverse transcriptase molecular techniques. Statistically significant positive association of disease with HLA-DRB1*03 (94.2% vs. 22.1% in controls, chi(2) = 73.4, p = 7.54E-11), and negative association with DRB1*15 (chi(2) ) = 7.4 , p = 6.5E-03) and DRB1*13 alleles were observed. HLA-DQB1*0201 was observed in all 35 patients (100%), while the presence of DQ2 heterodimer alpha(0)beta(0) occurred in 97.1% of CD patients (31.4% in double dose, 65.7% in single dose) It revealed a significant deviation from healthy controls (chi(2) = 102.08, p = 7.56E-11). Further analysis revealed the involvement of several DR3+ve haplotypes with CD in Indians, of which A26-B8-DR3 was the most common DR3 haplotype among patients (34.28%, chi(2) = 40.57, p = 2.65E- 10) followed by Ax-B21-DR3 (11.4%) (chi(2) = 13.8, p = 2E-04) and the classic Caucasian haplotype A1-B8-DR3 (5.7%). The former two haplotypes are characteristic of Asian Indians and are involved in the development of CD. We conclude that the high-risk DR3 haplotypes that play a critical role in the development of CD are unique to Asian Indians. Detailed analysis of these haplotypes in Indian patients with autoimmune diseases may help in understanding the influence of other involved genes within the major histocompatibility complex.

From 1991 to 1998, we vaccinated 4835 neonates against hepatitis B virus (HBV) and monitored their humoral response to the recombinant vaccine. In a sample of 184 of these children, we studied the association between HLA class I and II genomic polymorphisms and humoral response to vaccine and the association between immune response and disease. A subgroup of 96 children also underwent HLA class III typing (C4A and C4B). Four levels of humoral response have been identified, each with peculiar major histocompatibility complex (MHC) restriction. Different HLA products appear to act as agonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02) or antagonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02, and HLA-DRB1(*)11, DQB1(*)0301) in lowering humorality. Response to hepatitis B virus vaccine. The group of responders was characterized by a lack of “non-responder” alleles rather than by the presence of specific “responder” alleles. Tolerance to hepatitis B virus peptides may have clinical implications and may be a marker in children who have a genetic risk for autoimmune diseases. In fact, many poor responders carried two to four HLA-DQ alpha beta variants leading to insulin-dependent diabetes and celiac disease. Two true non-responders suffered from allergies and two slow responders had transient episodes of hyperglycemia.

The possibility that genetic susceptibility to celiac disease (CD) is influenced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene polymorphisms has been repeatedly raised. To date, this has only been investigated in case-control studies and results have been contradictory. In order to avoid any potential ethnic mismatch between patients and controls, we approached this issue by studying 71 celiac families, establishing parental haplotypes and comparing CD haplotypes versus control haplotypes (so-called AFBAC or affected family controls). We used DNA-based approaches to screen HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 alleles, TNFalpha promoter polymorphisms, and TNFa and b microsatellites. A guanine to adenine polymorphism at position -308 in the TNFalpha gene promoter region was found to be associated with CD where the TNF-308A allele appeared significantly in frequency in CD haplotypes, and this was shown to be independent of the association between CD and DRB1 alleles. *0301,DQA1*0501,DQB1*0201. Our results suggest that at least one other gene, in addition to the known association of CD with HLA class II, has a susceptibility role to this disease. This must be either TNFalpha or another polymorphic gene at the telomeric end of the HLA class III region.

Multiple sclerosis is a common disease of the central nervous system in which the interplay between inflammatory and neurodegenerative processes usually results in intermittent neurological disorder followed by a progressive accumulation of disability. Epidemiological studies have shown that genetic factors are primarily responsible for the significant increase in disease recurrence in relatives of affected individuals, and systematic attempts to identify links in multiplex families have confirmed that variation within the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) exerts the greatest influence. Individual influence on risk. Modestly powered genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled the identification of more than 20 additional risk loci and shown that multiple variants exerting modest individual effects have a major role in disease susceptibility. Most of the genetic architecture underlying susceptibility to the disease remains to be determined, and is expected to require analysis of sample sizes that exceed the numbers currently available for individual research groups. In a collaborative GWAS study including 9772 cases of European origin collected by 23 research groups working in 15 different countries, we replicated almost all previously proposed associations and identified at least 29 new susceptibility loci. Within the MHC we have refined the identity of the HLA-DRB1 risk alleles and confirmed that variation in the HLA-A gene underlies the independent protective effect attributable to the class I region. Immuneologically relevant genes are overrepresented among those genes close to the identified loci, especially T helper cell differentiation in MS pathogenesis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system in which a restricted cellular immune response is observed. In order to determine whether these T-cell responses are likely to be antigen-specific particularly with respect to myelin basic protein (MBP), we analyzed T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangements directly from MS brain plaques, using reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction. transcribed messenger RNA (RNA), and compared them with TCR clones for MBP-specific T cells described previously from an MS and experimental allergic encephalomyelitis murine model. Rearranged V beta 5.2 genes were detected in the brains of all patients with HLA DRB1*1501, DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401. Beta V beta 5,2-D beta-J sequences in MS brain plaques revealed five isoforms. One common element was identical to that described for the VDJ region of the V beta 5.2 T cell clone. This clone was from an MS patient that was HLA DRB1*1501, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401, and was cytotoxic toward targets containing the MBP peptide. 89-106 (Ref. 1). The deduced amino acid sequence of the VDJ rearrangement, Leu-Arg-Gly, has also been described in murine T cells cloned from experimental allergic encephalomyelitis lesions, which is specific for the MBP peptide 87-99 (ref. 2). VDJ sequences with this MBP loop specificity account for a significant fraction (40%) of TCR V beta 5.2(D)N rearrangements in MS lesions. The ability of rat T cells with these VDJ sequences to cause experimental allergic encephalomyelitis and the prevalence of such sequences in human demyelinated lesions suggest that T cells with rearranged TCRs may be critical in MS.

There is a striking gradient in the prevalence of multiple sclerosis (MS), but exceptions in Mediterranean Europe and northern Scandinavia, and some systematic reviews, suggest that the gradient may be an artifact. The authors sought to evaluate the relationship between MS prevalence and latitude through meta-regression. Studies were obtained from online databases, reference mining, and author referral. Prevalence estimates were age-standardized for the European population in 2009. Analyzes were performed by random-effects meta-regression, weighted with the inverse of the within-study variance. The authors included 650 prevalence estimates from 321 peer-reviewed studies; Of these, 239 were standardized by age, and 159 provided sex-specific data. The researchers found a significant positive association (change in prevalence by degree of latitude) between age-standardized prevalence (1.04, p<0.001) and latitude that diminished at higher latitudes. Adjusting for year of spread strengthened the association with latitude (2.60, p<0.001). The inverse gradient was reversed in the Italian region when adjusting for MS-associated HLA-DRB1 allele distributions. Adjusting for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies did not significantly change the gradient in Europe. Adjusting for some potential sources of bias did not affect the observed associations. This most comprehensive review of MS prevalence to date confirmed a statistically significant positive relationship between MS prevalence and latitude globally. The exceptions to phasing in the Italian region and northern Scandinavia are likely the result of genetic, behavioral and cultural differences. The persistence of a positive gradient in Europe after adjustment for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies strongly supports the role of environmental factors that vary with latitude, the most prominent candidates being ultraviolet radiation (UVR)/vitamin D.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex trait in which allelic variation in the MHC class II region exerts the strongest influence on genetic risk. Epidemiological data in MS provide strong evidence that environmental factors act at the population level to influence the unusual geographic distribution of this disease. Increasing evidence points to sunlight or vitamin D as a major environmental factor in its aetiology. We hypothesized that this environmental filter might interact with inherited factors and sought responsive regulatory elements in the MHC class II region. Sequence analysis identified a single MHC vitamin D response element (VDRE) to the promoter region of HLA-DRB1. Sequencing of this promoter in more than 1000 chromosomes of HLA-DRB1 homozygotes showed absolute conservation of the putative VDRE over HLA-DRB1*15 haplotypes. In contrast, there was striking variation among non-MS haplotypes. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific recruitment of vitamin D receptors to the VDRE in the HLA-DRB1*15 promoter, which was confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments using lymphoblasts homozygous for HLA-DRB1*15. Transient transfection using a luciferase reporter assay demonstrated a functional role for this VDRE. B cells transiently transfected with the HLA-DRB1*15 gene promoter showed increased expression upon stimulation with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (P = 0.002) that was lost when the VDRE was deleted or with the homologous “VDRE” sequence found in non-HLA haplotypes. -DRB1 associated with MS. Flow cytometric analysis showed a specific increase in cell surface expression of HLA-DRB1 upon vitamin D addition only in lymphoblasts bearing HLA-DRB1*15. This study further points to vitamin D as a strong environmental candidate in MS by demonstrating direct functional interaction with a key locus that determines genetic susceptibility. These findings support a relationship between the main epidemiological and genetic features of this disease with major practical implications for studies of disease mechanism and prevention.

Throughout the usual LDL cholesterol range in Western populations, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, in such populations, reducing LDL cholesterol may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely independent of initial cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40-80 years) with coronary artery disease, other arterial-occlusive disease or diabetes were randomly allocated to receive simvastatin 40 mg daily (median compliance: 85%) or placebo Matched (average statin use without study: 17%). ). Analyzes are first performed for specific events, comparing all participants assigned to simvastatin versus all participants assigned to placebo. These “intention-to-treat” comparisons evaluate the effects of about two-thirds (85% minus 17%) taking a statin during the scheduled 5-year treatment period, which resulted in a mean difference in low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (About two-thirds of the effect of actual use of 40 mg of simvastatin daily). Primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analyses) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subgroup analyses), with subcategories for cancer and other major morbidity. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1,328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 simvastatin assigned vs. 1,507 [14.7%] among 10,267 placebo assigned; P = 0.0003), due to a very significant relative reduction of 18%. (SE 5) in coronary mortality (587 [5.7%] vs. 707 [6.9%]; P = 0.0005), and a marginally significant reduction in other vascular deaths (194 [1.9%] vs. 230 [2.2%]; P = 0.07), and a non-significant reduction in non-vascular mortality (547 [5.3%] versus 570 [5.6%]; P = 0.4). There were highly significant reductions of about a quarter in the first event rate for nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] versus 1212 [11.8%]; P < 0.0001), for nonfatal or fatal stroke (444 [4.3%]). vs 585 [5.7%]; p<0.0001), and for coronary or non-coronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a significant 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19-28) reduction in event rate (2033 [19.8%] versus 2585 [25.2%] of affected individuals; p < 0.0001 ). During the first year, the reduction in major vascular events was not significant, but was subsequently very large during each separate year. The relative reduction in event rate was similar (and significant) in every subgroup of participants studied, including: those who were not diagnosed with coronary artery disease and who had cerebrovascular disease, had peripheral artery disease, or They had diabetes; Men and women separately; Those aged 70 or over at entry; And - especially - even those with LDL cholesterol less than 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL), or total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefits of simvastatin were additional to those of other cardiac treatments. The excess annual risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or on hospitalization for any reason other than vascular. Adding simvastatin to existing therapies safely results in significant additional benefits for a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentrations. An assignment of 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the rates of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. After accounting for non-compliance, actual use of this system would likely reduce these rates by about a third. Hence, among the many types of high-risk individuals studied, taking simvastatin for 5 years would prevent about 70-100 people per 1000 from suffering at least one of these major vascular events (and longer treatment should to more benefits). The magnitude of the 5-year benefit is based primarily on these individuals' overall risk of major vascular events, not on blood lipid concentrations alone.

Although treatment of myocardial overload effectively reduces death resulting from the development of heart failure, it is not known whether remission of progressive coronary artery disease resulting from lipid-lowering therapy will prevent the onset and consequences of heart failure in patients with no previous symptoms. For heart failure. In the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study, 4444 patients with coronary heart disease without evidence of heart failure were randomized to placebo (n = 2223) or simvastatin 20-40 mg (n = 2221) and followed for more than 5 years. Among patients who received placebo, 228 (10.3%) were diagnosed with heart failure during follow-up evaluation compared with 184 (8.3%) of patients who received simvastatin (P < .015). The mortality rate was 31.9% in the placebo group and 25.5% in the simvastatin group among patients who developed heart failure. These compare with 9.2 and 6.6%, respectively, among patients without heart failure. There were 45 hospitalizations for acute heart failure in the placebo group and 23 in the simvastatin (NS) group. Patients who developed heart failure were more likely to have recurrent myocardial infarction and to have a history of diabetes, peripheral artery disease, and hypertension compared to patients who did not develop congestive heart failure. Long-term prophylaxis with simvastatin reduces the incidence of heart failure in a group of patients with coronary heart disease without previous evidence of congestive heart failure.

Idelalisib is a potent and selective phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase-delta inhibitor approved for the treatment of relapsed chronic lymphocytic leukemia, follicular B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma and small lymphocytic lymphoma Top notch medicine. In dose-ranging studies, idelalisib exposure increased in a less than dose-proportional manner, possibly due to limited absorptive solubility. The approved starting dose is 150 mg twice daily and is supported by extensive exposure-response evaluation, allowing dose reduction to 100 mg twice daily for specific toxicities. As there were no clinically relevant food effects, idelalisib could be administered without regard to food and was therefore dosed accordingly in the primary efficacy/safety study. Idelalisib is metabolized primarily by aldehyde oxidase (AO) and to a lesser extent by cytochrome P450 (CYP) 3A. Coadministration with ketoconazole 400 mg once daily, a strong CYP3A inhibitor, resulted in an approximately 79% increase in the area under the idelalisib plasma concentration-time curve (AUC). Coadministration with the strong inducer rifampin resulted in a 75% decrease in idelalisib exposure (AUC), therefore, coadministration with strong inducers should be avoided. GS-563117 is the inactive primary circulating metabolite of idelalisib, formed primarily through AO. Unlike idelalisib, GS-563117 is a mechanism-based inhibitor of CYP3A. Therefore, idelalisib 150 mg administered twice daily increased midazolam AUC by 5.4-fold. Clinically, idelalisib is not an inhibitor of the transporters P-glycoprotein, breast cancer resistance protein, organic anion transporting polypeptide (OATP) 1B1, or OAPT1B3. In the population pharmacokinetic model, no meaningful effect on idelalisib pharmacokinetics was found for any of the covariates tested. Idelalisib exposure was increased by approximately 60% in patients with moderate/severe hepatic impairment; no relevant changes were observed in severe renal impairment. This article reviews the comprehensive pharmacology program, including drug-drug interaction studies as well as mechanistic and special population studies, to provide a comprehensive understanding of idelalisib clinical pharmacokinetics and its impact on clinical safety and efficacy.
cot: Understanding the potential application of Idelalisib in breast cancer would require data or studies that specifically address its impact on the pathogenic mechanisms or therapeutic outcomes in breast cancer models or patients. Without such information, one cannot conclusively evaluate its usefulness against breast cancer based on the provided text alone. The text is valuable for understanding Idelalisib's general pharmacological profile but not sufficient to assess its potential benefits in breast cancer therapy.

abstract: Episcleritis and scleritis are relatively rare eye diseases commonly associated with rheumatic diseases including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In order to explore the clinical and laboratory characteristics of SLE-related episcleritis and scleritis, we report 4 cases admitted to the Department of Rheumatology and Immunology of Peking University People's Hospital from September 2005 to July 2016 and diagnosed with episcleritis secondary to SLE or Hospitalized patients with scleritis. Demographic, clinical, and laboratory characteristics as well as treatment options and prognosis are summarized; the literature was reviewed. Among them, 3 were female and 1 was male. The average age was (49.0±23.8) years, and the average duration of SLE at the onset of episcleritis or scleritis was (2.1±1.4) years. In addition to ocular involvement, patients also developed mucocutaneous manifestations, serositis, lupus nephritis, and interstitial pneumonia; in the past, 1 patient developed arthritis, 2 patients developed Raynaud's phenomenon, and 2 patients developed hematological involvement. . All patients had high titers of antinuclear antibodies (ANA). Anti-double-stranded DNA (ds-DNA) antibody titers were elevated in 2 patients. Three patients were positive for antinucleosome antibodies (ANuA), whereas 1 patient was undetectable. Complement levels decreased in 3 patients. All patients had a Systemic Lupus Erythematosus Disease Activity Index (SLEDAI) score of more than 4 points (range, 7-16), indicating active disease. Eye symptoms include pain, redness, and watering of the eyes. Ophthalmological examination revealed 3 cases of episcleritis and 1 case of scleritis. Among the 4 patients, 2 patients developed ocular complications such as vision loss and uveitis. All patients were treated with systemic corticosteroids plus hydroxychloroquine; 3 patients were treated with immunosuppressants (cyclophosphamide in 2 patients and leflunomide in 1 patient). All 4 patients received topical steroid treatment, 1 patient received periocular injection of triamcinolone acetonide, and 1 patient received topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) treatment. No episcleritis or recurrence of scleritis was observed during the follow-up period. In summary, scleritis and episcleritis, although uncommon, may occur in patients with autoimmune rheumatic diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus. The occurrence of episcleritis and scleritis may indicate active disease of systemic lupus erythematosus. Patients need to be aware of ocular complications. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are associated with good visual outcomes at follow-up.
cot: While leflunomide is mentioned as part of the treatment regimen for one of the patients, the text does not delve into its effectiveness or mechanism of action specifically in the context of treating Raynaud's phenomenon. Raynaud's phenomenon is noted as a condition experienced by some of the patients in the past, but there is no detailed analysis or discussion on whether leflunomide—or any other treatment mentioned—was directly aimed at alleviating or targeting the key pathogenic mechanisms of Raynaud's.    To evaluate whether leflunomide could be effective for Raynaud's, one would look for specific discussions on its impact on vascular function, endothelial health, or other relevant pathophysiological aspects of Raynaud's. Such details would provide insight into whether leflunomide could offer therapeutic benefits or slow disease progression for Raynaud's patients.    In conclusion, while the text is informative regarding the treatment of ocular manifestations in SLE patients and mentions leflunomide as part of a treatment regimen, it does not offer sufficient evidence or discussion to evaluate leflunomide's efficacy in treating Raynaud's phenomenon. Further research or texts focusing specifically on Raynaud's and the use of leflunomide in that context would be necessary for such an evaluation.

abstract: Prescription omega-3-acid ethyl ester (PO-3A) has been tested as a treatment for patients with coronary artery disease (CAD), cardiac arrhythmias, and heart failure. Some evidence suggests that PO-3A may exert its effects by inhibiting platelets. We tested the hypothesis that PO-3A may inhibit platelet activity in patients with stable CAD, with antiplatelet activity beyond that of aspirin and statins. Thirty patients with CAD and triglycerides greater than 250 mg/dl received aspirin (70-160 mg/day) and a statin (simvastatin equivalent dose: 5-40 mg/day ) treatment, randomized 1:1:1 to Omacor™ 1 g/day (DHA/EPA ratio 1.25:1.0), Omacor 2 g/day, or placebo for 2 weeks. Platelet testing, including aggregation assay, flow cytometry, and cassette analyzer readings, was performed at baseline and at 1 and 2 weeks after PO-3A treatment. ADP-induced platelet aggregation (p = 0.037), GP IIb/IIIa antigen (p = 0.031) and activity (p = 0.024), and P-selectin (p = 0.041) were significantly reduced after PO-3A, ​​whereas platelet/endothelial cells Cell adhesion molecules (p = 0.09), vitronectin receptor (p = 0.16), platelet monocyte microparticle formation (p = 0.19) and the VerifyNow IIb/IIIa test (p = 0.27) showed only non-significant trends , showing reduced platelet activity. Finally, collagen- and arachidonic acid-induced aggregation, PFA-100 device closure time, and thrombospondin (CD36), GP Ib (CD42b), LAMP-3 (CD63), LAMP-1 (CD107a), CD40- Expression of ligands (CD154), GP37 (CD165) and PAR-1 receptor intact (SPAN 12) and cleaved (WEDE-15) epitopes were not affected by 2 weeks of PO-3A. Short-term treatment with PO-3A produced modest reductions in platelet activity biomarkers compared with placebo, independent of dose and after 1 week, despite concurrent aspirin and statin treatment. The effects of PO-3A are unique, distinct from other known antiplatelet agents, and suggest potential pleiotropic effects. These preliminary randomized data require confirmation from prospective studies.
cot: The results indicate that short-term therapy with PO-3A leads to a modest reduction in certain markers of platelet activity, suggesting that these omega-3-acid ethyl esters have a unique effect on platelet function beyond the antiplatelet properties of aspirin and statins. The significant reductions observed in ADP-induced platelet aggregation, GP IIb/IIIa antigen and activity, and P-selectin after PO-3A therapy, compared to a placebo, highlight a potential mechanism through which PO-3A could offer benefits in the context of heart disease.    Platelets play a critical role in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis and thrombosis, which are central to the development and progression of CAD. By reducing platelet activation and aggregation, PO-3A might help to lower the risk of thrombotic events, such as myocardial infarction, thereby potentially slowing the progression of heart disease.    The text mentions that the effects observed call for confirmation in prospective studies, indicating that while the findings are promising, further research is needed to fully understand the therapeutic potential and implications of PO-3A in heart disease. Nonetheless, this study contributes valuable evidence to the discussion on the benefits of omega-3-acid ethyl esters in heart disease, especially regarding their unique antiplatelet properties and potential role in therapeutic strategies beyond conventional treatments.

abstract: This review provides an overview of recent advances related to the molecular mechanisms and pathways of aquaporin 2 (AQP2) water channel transport. AQP2 is a fascinating protein whose sorting signals can be interpreted by different cell types to achieve apical or basolateral membrane insertion in regulatory and constitutive trafficking pathways. In addition to the well-known cAMP-mediated stimulation of AQP2 membrane insertion by vasopressin, other signaling and transport events can lead to AQP2 membrane accumulation through cAMP-independent mechanisms. These include 1) increases in cGMP mediated by sodium nitroprusside (nitric oxide donor), atrial natriuretic factor, and L-arginine (via nitric oxide synthase); 2) changes in the actin cytoskeleton Destruction; 3) Inhibition of the clathrin-mediated endocytic arm of the AQP2 recycling pathway through dominant negative motility expression and membrane cholesterol depletion. Recent data have also shown that AQP2 constitutively circulates in epithelial cells, can be inserted into different membrane domains in different cell types both in vitro and in vivo, and that these pathways can be modulated by factors including hyperosmolarity. The role of accessory proteins, including small GTPases and soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor proteins, in AQP2 membrane insertion is also being revealed. Understanding the cAMP-independent mechanism of AQP2 membrane insertion is particularly relevant for therapeutic bypass of mutated, dysfunctional vasopressin receptors in patients with X-linked nephrodiabetes insipidus.
cot: While sodium nitroprusside is mentioned, it serves as a nitric oxide donor rather than directly illustrating an interaction of sodium with AQP2 expression or trafficking. Therefore, the text does not provide evidence or discussion specifically related to sodium modulating AQP2 expression directly.    To evaluate the original question regarding sodium's interaction with AQP2 expression, one would look for research directly investigating the impact of sodium levels on AQP2 expression, trafficking, or function. This could include studies on how sodium concentration affects AQP2's cellular localization, stability, or activity, none of which are directly addressed in the given text.

abstract: The coexistence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and heart failure (HF) with reduced (HFrEF) or preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) is common (30-40% of patients) and is associated with a higher risk of HF hospitalization, all-cause Mortality and cardiovascular (CV) mortality. The most important causes of HF in T2DM are coronary artery disease, arterial hypertension, and the direct deleterious effects of T2DM on the myocardium. T2DM is often unrecognized in patients with heart failure and vice versa, which emphasizes the importance of actively looking for both diseases in clinical practice. There are no specific restrictions on the treatment of heart failure in T2DM. Subgroup analysis of trials of heart failure treatments in the general population suggests that all heart failure treatments are equally effective regardless of T2DM type. Regarding the treatment of T2DM in patients with heart failure, most current guidelines recommend metformin as the first-line option. Sulfonylureas and insulin have been traditional second- and third-line therapies, although their safety in heart failure is unclear. Neither glucagon-like propeptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists nor dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4) inhibitors reduced the risk of hospitalization for heart failure. In fact, the DPP4 inhibitor saxagliptin is associated with a higher risk of hospitalization for heart failure. Thiazolidinediones (pioglitazone and rosiglitazone) are contraindicated in patients with heart failure (or at risk for heart failure). In recent trials, the sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitors empagliflozin and canagliflozin both showed significant reductions in heart failure hospitalizations in patients with established CV disease or at risk for CV disease. Several ongoing trials should provide insight into the effectiveness of SGLT2 inhibitors in HFrEF and HFpEF patients without T2DM.
cot: To evaluate whether there exists an interaction between metformin and the gene DPP4, information is needed on pharmacogenetic studies, biochemical interactions, or clinical trials that specifically investigate how metformin might influence DPP4 gene expression or enzyme functionality. Such information would involve detailed discussions on the mechanisms of action of metformin that could potentially impact the DPP4 pathway.  In conclusion, while the text is useful for understanding the broader clinical implications of using various diabetes treatments in heart failure patients, it does not address the specific query about an interaction between metformin and the gene DPP4. For that, a different source or text focusing specifically on pharmacogenetic interactions or the molecular effects of metformin on DPP4 would be required.

abstract: Doxorubicin is a potent cancer chemotherapy drug, but its use is limited due to its potential cardiotoxicity. Semaglutide (SEMA) is a new glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) analog that has received widespread attention in the treatment of diabetes. However, growing evidence highlights its potential therapeutic benefits on cardiac function. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to examine the efficacy of semaglutide in ameliorating doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity. Doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity is an established model for studying cardiac function. Study of cardiac function through transthoracic echocardiography and invasive hemodynamic monitoring. The results showed that semaglutide could significantly improve doxorubicin-induced cardiac dysfunction. RNA sequencing revealed that Bnip3 is a candidate gene that attenuates the protective effect of semaglutide in doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity. To determine the role of BNIP3 against semaglutide in doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity, BNIP3 with adeno-associated virus serotype 9 (AAV9) expressing cardiac troponin T (cTnT) promoter was injected into C57/BL6J The tail veins of mice overexpress BNIP3, especially in the heart. Overexpression of BNIP3 prevented semaglutide-induced improvements in cardiac function. In vitro experiments show that semaglutide reduces the expression of BNIP3 in mitochondria and improves mitochondrial function through the PI3K/AKT pathway. Semaglutide improves doxorubicin-induced mitochondrial and cardiac dysfunction through the PI3K/AKT pathway by reducing the expression of BNIP3 in mitochondria. Improvements in mitochondrial function reduce doxorubicin-mediated cardiac injury and improve cardiac function. Therefore, semaglutide is a potential therapy to reduce acute cardiotoxicity induced by doxorubicin.
cot: The text provided is indeed useful for evaluating the interaction between the drug semaglutide and the gene BNIP3. It describes a study focused on the effects of semaglutide, a GLP-1 analog, in ameliorating cardiotoxicity induced by the chemotherapeutic agent doxorubicin. Key findings include:  Evidence of Interaction: RNA sequencing identified BNIP3 as a candidate gene that may impair the protective effect of semaglutide on doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity. This suggests a genetic interaction where BNIP3 expression potentially modifies the effectiveness of semaglutide in this context.  Experimental Verification: Further experiments involving overexpression of BNIP3 in mice showed that increased levels of BNIP3 prevented semaglutide from improving cardiac function, which indicates that BNIP3 expression is inversely related to the cardioprotective effects of semaglutide.  Mechanistic Insights: The text also mentions that semaglutide, through the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway, reduces BNIP3 expression in mitochondria, which in turn improves mitochondrial function. This reduction in BNIP3 expression is directly linked to semaglutide's ability to mitigate mitochondrial and cardiac dysfunction.  Therapeutic Implications: The conclusion that semaglutide ameliorates doxorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity via a pathway that includes modulation of BNIP3 expression offers valuable insights into both the therapeutic mechanism of semaglutide and the role of BNIP3 in cardiac health.  Overall, the text clearly demonstrates that there is an interaction between semaglutide and the BNIP3 gene, with semaglutide modulating the expression of BNIP3 to exert its therapeutic effects. This interaction is relevant for understanding how semaglutide can be used to potentially mitigate cardiac injury in clinical settings involving doxorubicin treatment. The study details provided would be critical for any further research into the pharmacodynamics of semaglutide and its broader applications in cardiac therapeutics.

abstract: The GBA gene encodes the lysosomal enzyme glucocerebrosidase (GCase), which maintains glycosphingolipid homeostasis. Approximately 5-15% of Parkinson's disease patients have mutations in the GBA gene, making it the most important genetic risk factor for Parkinson's disease (PD). Clinically, GBA-related PD is identical to sporadic PD, except for an earlier age of onset (AAO), more frequent cognitive impairment, and more rapid progression. Mutations in GBA may be associated with both loss-of-function and gain-of-function mechanisms. A key hallmark of PD is the presence of intraneuronal protein inclusions called Lewy bodies, which are primarily composed of alpha-synuclein. Mutations in the GBA gene may lead to loss of GCase activity and lysosomal dysfunction, which may impair α-synuclein metabolism. GCase deficiency models show dysfunction of the autophagolysosomal pathway and subsequent α-synuclein accumulation. This dysfunction also leads to abnormalities in lipid metabolism, including accumulation of glycosphingolipids, glucosphingosine, and glucosphingosine. Certain mutations cause GCase to misfold and remain in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), activating stress responses including the unfolded protein response (UPR), which may lead to neurodegeneration. In addition to these mechanisms, GCase deficiency has also been associated with mitochondrial dysfunction and neuroinflammation, which are implicated in the pathogenesis of PD. This review discusses pathways associated with GBA-PD and highlights potential therapeutic approaches that may target GCase and prevent neurodegeneration.
cot: The text provided is highly useful for evaluating whether there exists an interaction between Parkinson's disease (PD) and the gene GBA. Here are several reasons supporting its usefulness:  Clear Connection Between GBA Mutations and PD: The text specifies that approximately 5-15% of PD patients have mutations in the GBA gene, establishing it as a significant genetic risk factor for Parkinson's disease. This direct association underlines the importance of the GBA gene in the context of PD.  Detailed Mechanistic Insights: The text describes how mutations in the GBA gene may lead to loss of glucocerebrosidase (GCase) activity and subsequent lysosomal dysfunction. This dysfunction is crucial as it impairs alpha-synuclein metabolism, a key process in the pathogenesis of PD. Alpha-synuclein is the primary component of Lewy bodies, which are characteristic of PD. This provides a mechanistic link between GBA mutations and the pathological features observed in PD.  Biological Consequences of GBA Mutations: The review further explains that GBA mutations can result in both loss- and gain-of-function mechanisms. It details how these mutations can cause GCase to misfold and be retained in the endoplasmic reticulum, triggering stress responses such as the unfolded protein response (UPR) and potentially contributing to neurodegeneration. This expands on the ways in which GBA mutations can influence cellular health and PD pathology.  Association with Clinical Features of PD: It is mentioned that GBA-associated PD is clinically similar to sporadic PD but with distinct features like an earlier age at onset, more rapid progression, and more frequent cognitive impairment. This differentiation is critical for understanding the clinical impact of GBA mutations in PD patients.  Therapeutic Implications: The text highlights potential treatments targeting GCase to prevent neurodegeneration, which not only underscores the interaction between GBA and PD but also suggests practical applications of this knowledge in developing therapeutic strategies.

abstract: Psoriasis is a common chronic skin disease. Pathologically, it is characterized by epidermal dysplasia, inflammatory cell infiltration, and increased angiogenesis in the dermis. Abnormal expression of E3 ubiquitin ligases and dysregulation of the protein ubiquitination system have been implicated in the pathogenesis of psoriasis. To investigate the potential role of S-phase kinase-related protein 2 (Skp2), an E3 ligase and oncogene, in psoriasis. Quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction, Western blot, immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescent staining of psoriasis vulgaris patients and imiquimod (IMQ)-induced mouse models and cultured endothelial cells (EC) Skin samples were evaluated for gene expression and protein levels. Protein interactions, substrate ubiquitination, and degradation were examined in human umbilical vein EC using coimmunoprecipitation, Western blotting, and cycloheximide chase assays. Angiogenesis was measured in vitro using human dermal microvascular ECs (HDMEC) to understand BrdU incorporation, migration, and tube formation. In vivo angiogenesis assays include chick chorioallantoic membrane, Matrigel plug assay, and quantification of vasculature in mouse lesions. Skp2 gene global knockout (KO) mice and endothelium-specific conditional KO mice were used. Skp2 is increased in skin samples from psoriasis patients and mice with IMQ-induced lesions. Immunofluorescence double staining showed that Skp2 manifestations were closely related to the hypervascularity of the focal dermal papillae. In HDMEC, Skp2 overexpression was enhanced, whereas Skp2 knockdown inhibited EC proliferation, migration, and tubular structure formation. Mechanistically, phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) inhibits the phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Akt pathway and is considered a novel substrate for Skp2-mediated ubiquitination. Selective inhibitors of Skp2 (C1) or Skp2 small interfering RNA significantly reduce vascular endothelial growth factor-triggered PTEN ubiquitination and degradation. Furthermore, Skp2-mediated ubiquitination depends on phosphorylation of PTEN by glycogen synthase kinase 3β. Skp2 gene deficiency alleviated IMQ-induced psoriasis in a mouse model. Importantly, tamoxifen-induced endothelium-specific Skp2 KO mice showed significant improvement in psoriasis symptoms and reduced papillary angiogenesis. Furthermore, topical application of the Skp2 inhibitor C1 was effective in preventing experimental psoriasis. The Skp2/PTEN axis may play an important role in psoriasis-related angiogenesis. Therefore, targeting Skp2-driven angiogenesis may be a potential approach to treat psoriasis.
cot: The text provided is highly useful for evaluating whether there exists an interaction between the disease psoriasis and the gene SKP2. Here's an argument supporting its usefulness:  Direct Investigation of Skp2 in Psoriasis: The study's objectives clearly focus on examining the role of S-phase kinase-associated protein 2 (Skp2), an E3 ubiquitin ligase, in the pathogenesis of psoriasis. Skp2 is studied in both human and animal models, providing a comprehensive view of its function and effects in the context of this disease.  Increased Expression in Disease Context: The results show that Skp2 expression is increased in skin samples from patients with psoriasis as well as in an imiquimod (IMQ)-induced mouse model of psoriasis. This upregulation in disease contexts suggests a potential pathogenic role of Skp2 in psoriasis.  Link to Psoriasis-Associated Angiogenesis: Skp2 is associated with excessive vascularity in the lesional dermal papillae, indicating a specific role in the angiogenic aspect of psoriasis pathology. The text details how Skp2 overexpression enhances endothelial cell (EC) proliferation, migration, and tube-like structure formation, which are key components of angiogenesis.  Mechanistic Insights Involving Skp2 and PTEN: The study identifies PTEN, a known tumor suppressor and inhibitor of the PI3K/Akt pathway, as a novel substrate for Skp2-mediated ubiquitination. This interaction leads to the degradation of PTEN, further implicating Skp2 in the molecular pathways that exacerbate psoriasis, particularly through the modulation of angiogenic processes.  Therapeutic Implications and Genetic Confirmation: Use of Skp2 inhibitors and genetic knockout models (both global and endothelial-specific) demonstrate that reducing Skp2 activity or expression can significantly ameliorate psoriasis symptoms and reduce disease-associated angiogenesis. These findings not only support the role of Skp2 in psoriasis but also highlight its potential as a therapeutic target.  Broad Experimental Approaches: The combination of gene expression analysis, protein interaction studies, and functional assays in cell culture and in vivo, along with the use of both pharmacological inhibitors and genetic models, provides a robust set of evidence linking Skp2 with psoriasis pathology.  In conclusion, the text is not only useful but also critical in providing detailed evidence of an interaction between psoriasis and the gene SKP2. It elucidates a specific biological pathway involving Skp2 that contributes to disease mechanisms, offering potential targets for therapeutic intervention. The clear demonstration of increased Skp2 activity in psoriasis lesions and its role in promoting pathological angiogenesis via PTEN degradation underlines the importance of Skp2 as a molecular link in the progression of psoriasis.

abstract: Some studies suggest that the gut microbiome may be linked to dementia. However, the causal relationship between the gut microbiota and different types of dementia and whether cytokines act as mediators remain unclear. Large-scale identification of gut microbiota, cytokines, and five types of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease (AD), frontotemporal dementia (FTD), dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), vascular Summary information from genome-wide association studies (GWAS) in dementia (VD) and Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD). We used Mendelian randomization (MR) to study causal relationships between gut microbiota, cytokines, and five dementia disorders. Inverse variance weighting (IVW) was adopted as the main statistical method. In addition, we also explored whether cytokines act as mediators in the pathway from gut microbiota to dementia. There were 20 positive and 16 negative causal relationships between genetic predispositions in the gut microbiota and dementia. In addition, there were five positive causal relationships and four negative causal relationships between cytokines and dementia. Cytokines do not act as intermediary factors. Gut microbiota and cytokines are causally linked to five types of dementia, while cytokines do not appear to be mediators of the gut microbiota-to-dementia pathway.
cot: The piece of text provided is not useful for evaluating whether there exists an interaction between the disease dementia and the gene "IVW". Here are several points that clarify why the text does not serve this purpose:  Misinterpretation of "IVW": The text uses the term "IVW" in the context of statistical analysis, specifically referring to "Inverse Variance Weighting". IVW is a method used in Mendelian randomization (MR) studies to estimate the causal effect of an exposure on an outcome across multiple genetic instruments. It is not a gene, but rather a statistical technique.  Focus of the Study: The primary focus of the study is on the causal relationships between gut microbiota, cytokines, and various types of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal dementia, dementia with Lewy bodies, vascular dementia, and Parkinson’s disease dementia. The study aims to explore if cytokines mediate the relationship between gut microbiota and dementia, using genetic data from GWAS and MR.  No Mention of Gene IVW: There is no discussion or mention of a gene called "IVW" in the context of genetics or molecular biology within the text. Therefore, the text cannot be used to assess any interaction involving a gene named "IVW" and dementia because "IVW" in this context refers to a methodological approach, not a genetic entity.  Conclusion Misalignment: Since "IVW" refers to a method rather than a gene, the conclusions drawn from using this method (causal relationships between microbiota, cytokines, and dementia types) do not provide information about genetic interactions specific to a gene influencing dementia.  In summary, the text is useful for understanding the application of Mendelian randomization in exploring causal links between gut microbiota, cytokines, and dementia but it does not provide any insight into interactions between dementia and a gene called "IVW" simply because "IVW" is not a gene but a statistical method used in the analysis. Thus, the text cannot be used to evaluate genetic interactions involving a gene with that name in relation to dementia.

abstract: Selective depletion of B cells using rituximab results in sustained clinical improvement in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, an open-label study shows. To confirm these observations, we conducted a randomized, double-blind, controlled study. We randomly assigned 161 patients with active rheumatoid arthritis despite methotrexate therapy to receive one of four treatments: oral methotrexate (≥10 mg weekly) (control); Rituximab; Ximab (1000 mg on days 1 and 15); rituximab plus cyclophosphamide (750 mg on days 3 and 17); or rituximab plus methotrexate. Response, as defined by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) criteria, was assessed at weeks 24 (primary analysis) and 48 weeks (exploratory analysis). At week 24, the proportion of patients with a 50% improvement in disease symptoms according to ACR criteria (the primary endpoint) was 43% in the rituximab-methotrexate combination group (43%, P=0.005) and rituximab- It was significantly higher in the cyclophosphamide combined treatment group (43%, P=0.005). Across all rituximab-treated groups, a significantly higher proportion of patients achieved a 20% improvement in disease symptoms according to ACR criteria (65% to 76% vs. 38%, P < or = 0.025) or had an EULAR response (83% to 85%) % vs. 50%, P< or =0.004). All ACR responses in the rituximab-methotrexate group were maintained at week 48. Most adverse events occurred with the first rituximab infusion: serious infection occurred in 1 patient (2.5%) in the control group and 4 patients (3.3%) in the rituximab group at 24 weeks A serious infection occurs. Peripheral blood immunoglobulin concentrations remained within the normal range. In patients with active rheumatoid arthritis receiving methotrexate, a single course of two infusions of rituximab (alone or in combination with cyclophosphamide or continuous methotrexate) was administered at weeks 24 and Disease symptoms were significantly improved at week 48.

Rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by persistent synovitis, systemic inflammation, and autoantibodies (particularly rheumatoid factor and citrullinated peptides). Fifty percent of the risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis is due to genetic factors. Smoking is a major environmental risk. In industrialized countries, rheumatoid arthritis affects 0·5-1·0% of adults, with 5-50 new cases per 1 million per year. The disease is most common in women and older adults. Uncontrolled active rheumatoid arthritis can lead to joint damage, disability, reduced quality of life, and cardiovascular and other comorbidities. Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are key treatments that reduce synovitis and systemic inflammation and improve function. The main DMARD is methotrexate, which can be combined with other such drugs. Biologics may be used when arthritis is uncontrolled or when DMARDs are causing toxic effects. Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors were the first biologic, followed by abatacept, rituximab, and tocilizumab. Infections and high costs limit the prescribing of biologics. Long-term remission induced by intensive short-term therapy selected based on biomarker profiles is the ultimate goal.

Recent insights into rheumatoid arthritis (RA) require updates to the European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) RA management recommendations. A large international working group based its decisions on evidence from 3 systematic literature reviews, developing 4 overarching principles and 12 recommendations (compared to 3 and 14, respectively, in 2013). These recommendations relate to conventional synthetic (cs) disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) (methotrexate (MTX), leflunomide, sulfasalazine); glucocorticoids (GC); biologic (b) DMARDs (oncology Necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegol, etanercept, golimumab, infliximab), abatacept, rituximab, tocilizumab, clazakizumab, sarilumab and sirukumab as well as biosimilars (bs) DMARDs) and targeted synthetic drugs (ts) ) DMARDs (Janus kinase (Jak) inhibitors tofacitinib, baricitinib). Monotherapy, combination therapy, treatment strategies (targeted therapy), and the goals of sustained clinical remission (defined by the American College of Rheumatology (ACR)-EULAR Boolean or index criteria) or low disease activity are discussed. Cost aspects were taken into consideration. As a first strategy, the task force recommended MTX (rapid escalation to 25 mg/week) plus short-term GC, with the goal of >50% improvement within 3 months and achievement within 6 months. If that fails, layering is recommended. If there are no adverse prognostic markers, switching to or adding another csDMARD (plus short-term GC) is recommended. In the presence of adverse prognostic markers (autoantibodies, high disease activity, early erosion, failure of 2 csDMARDs), any bDMARD (current practice) or Jak inhibitor should be added to the csDMARD. If that fails, it is recommended to use any other bDMARD or tsDMARD. If the patient continues to be in remission, bDMARDs can be tapered. For each recommendation, the level of evidence and working group agreement are provided, both of which are mostly very high. These recommendations are intended to inform rheumatologists, patients, national rheumatology societies, hospital officials, social security agencies, and regulatory agencies about the latest EULAR consensus on the management of RA and aim to achieve optimal outcomes with current therapies.

In this article, the 2010 European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR) recommendations on the use of synthetic and biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (sDMARDs and bDMARDs, respectively) in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are updated. The 2013 update was developed by an international working group whose decisions were based primarily on evidence from three systematic literature reviews (one each on sDMARDs, including glucocorticoids, bDMARDs, and the safety of DMARD therapy). ;The search also covered treatment strategies. The experts discussed and summarized the evidence presented during a consensus and voting process. Levels of evidence and recommendations are derived, and the level of agreement (strength of recommendations) is determined. 14 recommendations were developed (compared to 15 in 2010). Some of the 2010 recommendations were removed and some were revised or split. These recommendations cover general aspects such as the use of targeted therapies to achieve remission or low disease activity, as well as the need for shared decision-making between rheumatologists and patients. More specific projects involve initiating DMARD therapy using a conventional sDMARD (csDMARD) strategy in combination with glucocorticoids and then adding bDMARD or another csDMARD strategy (after stratification based on the presence or absence of adverse risk factors) if the treatment goal is 6 Not reached within 3 months (or no improvement within 3 months). Tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (adalimumab, certolizumab pegol, etanercept, golimumab, infliximab, biosimilars), abatacept, tocilizumab and rituximab in certain conditions are generally considered to have similar efficacy and safety profiles. If the first bDMARD strategy fails, any other bDMARD can be used. These recommendations also point to tofacitinib as a targeted sDMARD (tsDMARD) recommended for use after the use of at least one bDMARD, where licensed. Biosimilars have also been addressed. These recommendations are intended to inform rheumatologists, patients, national societies of rheumatology, and other stakeholders about the latest EULAR consensus on the use of sDMARDs, glucocorticoids, and bDMARDs in the treatment of RA. They are based on evidence and expert opinion and aim to improve outcomes for patients with RA.

Traditional nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) produce a range of toxic effects, particularly gastrointestinal (GI) effects, due to inhibition of cyclooxygenase (COX)-1. Whether COX-2-specific inhibitors are associated with fewer clinical gastrointestinal toxic effects is unknown. To determine whether celecoxib, a COX-2 specific inhibitor, is associated with a lower incidence of significant upper gastrointestinal toxicities and other adverse effects compared with traditional NSAIDs. The Celecoxib Long-Term Arthritis Safety Study (CLASS), a double-blind, randomized controlled trial, was conducted from September 1998 to March 2000. A total of 8,059 patients (>/= 18 years) with osteoarthritis (OA) or rheumatoid arthritis (RA) were enrolled in the study, of whom 7,968 received at least 1 dose of study drug. A total of 4573 patients (57%) received treatment for 6 months. Patients were randomly assigned to receive celecoxib, 400 mg twice daily (2 and 4 times the maximum dose for RA and OA, respectively; n = 3987); ibuprofen, 800 mg three times daily ( n = 1985); or diclofenac, 75 mg twice daily (n = 1996). Aspirin is allowed for cardiovascular disease prevention (</=325 mg/d). Incidence of prospectively defined symptomatic upper gastrointestinal ulcers and ulcer complications (bleeding, perforation, and obstruction) and other adverse effects during 6 months of treatment. For all patients, the annual incidence rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and with symptomatic ulcers for celecoxib compared with NSAIDs were 0.76% vs 1.45% (P =.09) and 2.08% vs 3.54%, respectively. (P =.02). In patients not taking aspirin, the annual incidence rates of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and symptomatic ulcers with celecoxib compared with NSAIDs were 0.44% vs 1.27% (P = .04) and 1.40, respectively. % vs 2.91% (P =.02). In patients taking aspirin, the annual incidence of upper gastrointestinal ulcer complications alone and with symptomatic ulcers was 2.01% versus 2.12% for celecoxib versus NSAIDs (P = .92 ) and 4.70% vs 6.00% (P =.49). Chronic gastrointestinal blood loss, gastrointestinal intolerance, hepatotoxicity, or nephrotoxicity were less likely to occur in patients treated with celecoxib than in patients treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. There was no difference in cardiovascular event rates between celecoxib and NSAIDs, regardless of aspirin use. In this study, celecoxib was associated with lower rates of symptomatic ulcers and ulcer complications and other clinically important toxicities at doses greater than clinically indicated compared with standard doses of NSAIDs. . The reduction in upper gastrointestinal toxicity was most pronounced in patients who were not concurrently taking aspirin. Jama. 2000;284:1247-1255

Prostaglandin (PG)E2 is a potent mediator of pain and inflammation, and high levels of this lipid mediator are observed in many disease states. Until now, efforts to control pain and treat diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis by inhibiting PGE2 production have relied on nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin. However, these drugs inhibit the synthesis of all prostaglandins. To produce biologically active PGE2, PGE synthase catalyzes the isomerization of PGH2 to PGE2. Recently, several PGE synthetases have been identified and cloned, but their role in inflammation is unclear. To study the physiological role of a single PGE synthase, we generated a mouse strain lacking microsomal PGE synthase 1 (mPGES1) on an inbred DBA/1lacJ background by targeted homologous recombination. mPGES1-deficient (mPGES1-/-) mice were viable, fertile, and developed normally compared with wild-type controls. However, mPGES1-/- mice showed significantly reduced inflammatory responses compared with mPGES1+/+ mice in multiple assays. Here, we identify mPGES1 as a PGE synthase that contributes to the pathogenesis of collagen-induced arthritis, a disease model of human rheumatoid arthritis. We also show that mPGES1 is responsible for the production of PGE2, which mediates acute pain during the inflammatory response. These findings suggest that mPGES1 provides a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases and pain associated with inflammatory states.

SC-58635 (celecoxib) is an anti-inflammatory analgesic that acts through selective inhibition of cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) and is not expected to cause typical gastrointestinal (GI), renal and platelet-related symptoms, to study the efficacy and safety of SC-58635 (celecoxib) and side effects related to inhibition of the COX-1 enzyme. Four Phase II trials were conducted: a 2-week efficacy trial in osteoarthritis, a 4-week efficacy trial in rheumatoid arthritis, a 1-week endoscopic study of gastrointestinal mucosal effects, and a A 1-week study on the effects on platelet function. Two arthritis trials determined that SC-58635 dose levels were consistently effective in treating signs and symptoms of arthritis and were different from placebo on standard arthritis scales. In the upper endoscopy study, 19% (6 of 32 subjects) of subjects who received naproxen developed gastric ulcers compared with those who received SC-58635 or placebo. No gastric ulcers occurred. Platelet effect studies showed that SC-58635 had no meaningful effect on platelet aggregation or thromboxane B2 levels, whereas aspirin caused significant reductions in 2 of 3 platelet aggregation measurements and thromboxane B2 levels. In all 4 trials, SC-58635 was well tolerated and had a safety profile similar to placebo. SC-58635 achieves analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects in arthritis through selective COX-2 inhibition without showing any evidence of 2 of the toxic effects of COX-1 inhibition associated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Gastric acid suppression with famotidine, a histamine H2 receptor antagonist, protects against gastric damage in normal subjects receiving a short course of aspirin or naproxen. The efficacy of famotidine in preventing peptic ulcer disease in patients receiving long-term nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is unknown. We studied two doses of famotidine (20 mg and 40 mg orally twice daily) compared with placebo for the prevention of rheumatoid arthritis in 285 patients without peptic ulcers who were receiving long-term NSAID therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. Efficacy of peptic ulcer. Patients underwent clinical assessment and endoscopic examination at baseline and after 4, 12, and 24 weeks of treatment. Evaluators were blinded to treatment assignment. The primary endpoint was the cumulative incidence of gastric or duodenal ulcers at 24 weeks. The cumulative incidence of gastric ulcers was 20% in the placebo group, 13% in the 20 mg twice daily famotidine group (P = 0.24 compared with placebo), and 8% in the 40 mg famotidine group. % twice daily (P = 0.03 vs. placebo). The proportion of patients who developed duodenal ulcers was significantly lower in the famotidine group at both doses than in the placebo group (13% in the placebo group and 4% in the low-dose famotidine group [P = 0.04], high dose famotidine group was 2%). Both doses of famotidine were well tolerated. High-dose famotidine therapy significantly reduces the cumulative incidence of gastric and duodenal ulcers in patients with arthritis receiving long-term NSAID therapy.
