Vitamin K antagonists are highly effective in preventing stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation but have some limitations. Apixaban, a new oral direct factor Xa inhibitor, has been shown to reduce the risk of stroke in similar populations compared with aspirin. In this randomized, double-blind trial, we compared apixaban (5 mg twice daily) with warfarin in 18,201 patients with atrial fibrillation and at least one additional stroke risk factor (Target international normalized ratio, 2.0 to 3.0). The primary outcome was ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke or systemic embolism. The trial was designed to test non-inferiority and the main secondary objectives were to test superiority in the primary outcome and rate of major bleeding and all-cause mortality. Median follow-up time was 1.8 years. The primary outcome occurred at a rate of 1.27% per year in the apixaban group and 1.60% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio for apixaban, 0.79; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.66 to 0.95 ; P<0.001 is non-inferiority; P=0.01 is superiority). The rate of major bleeding was 2.13% per year in the apixaban group compared with 3.09% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.60 to 0.80; P<0.001), as well as mortality from any cause, respectively. were 3.52% and 3.94% (hazard ratio, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.80 to 0.99; P=0.047). The rate of hemorrhagic stroke was 0.24% per year in the apixaban group and 0.47% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.51; 95% CI, 0.35 to 0.75; P<0.001). The incidence of stroke was 0.97% per year in the warfarin group and 1.05% per year in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.92; 95% CI, 0.74 to 1.13; P=0.42). In patients with atrial fibrillation, apixaban was superior to warfarin in preventing stroke or systemic embolism, with less bleeding and lower mortality. (Funded by Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pfizer; ARISTOTLE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00412984.).

Patients with acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation have a high rate of major vascular events despite current treatments. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of the antiplatelet drug clopidogrel combined with aspirin in the treatment of such patients. We randomly assigned 12,562 patients presenting within 24 hours of symptom onset to receive clopidogrel (300 mg immediately, then 75 mg once daily) (6259 patients) or placebo (6303 patients) plus aspirin Treatment lasts from 3 to 12 months. The first primary outcome—a composite of death from cardiovascular causes, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or stroke—occurred in 9.3% of patients in the clopidogrel group and 11.4% of patients in the placebo group (compared with clopidogrel, Relative risk placebo, 0.80; 95% confidence interval, 0.72 to 0.90; P<0.001). The second primary outcome (first primary outcome or refractory ischemia) occurred in 16.5% of patients in the clopidogrel group and 18.8% of patients in the placebo group (relative risk, 0.86; 95% confidence interval, 0.79 to 0.94) P<0.001). The proportion of patients with in-hospital refractory or critical ischemia, heart failure, and revascularization surgery was also significantly reduced with clopidogrel. Significantly more patients in the clopidogrel group than in the placebo group experienced major bleeding (3.7% vs. 2.7%; relative risk, 1.38; P=0.001), but there was no significant increase in life-threatening bleeding (2.2% [adjusted] vs. 1.8%; P=0.13) or hemorrhagic stroke (0.1% vs. 0.1%). The antiplatelet drug clopidogrel is beneficial in patients with acute coronary syndrome without ST-segment elevation. However, patients receiving clopidogrel are at increased risk for major bleeding.

To determine the effect of antiplatelet therapy in patients at high risk for occlusive vascular events. Collaborative meta-analysis (systematic overview). Randomized trials of antiplatelet therapy versus a control or one antiplatelet therapy versus another antiplatelet therapy in high-risk patients (with acute or preexisting vascular disease or some other predisposing condition) that are Results will be available until September 1997. The only difference lies in the antiplatelet treatment regimen. There were 287 studies involving 135,000 patients comparing antiplatelet therapy with controls and 77,000 patients comparing different antiplatelet therapy regimens. "Serious vascular event": nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, or vascular death. Overall, among these high-risk patients, dispensing antiplatelet therapy reduced the combined outcome of any serious vascular event by about one-quarter; nonfatal myocardial infarction by one-third, and nonfatal stroke by four-quarters. 1 in 1, and vascular mortality was reduced by 1 in 6 (with no apparent adverse effect on other deaths). Among patients with prior myocardial infarction, the absolute risk of serious vascular events was reduced by 36 cases (SE 5) among those treated for two years; among patients with acute myocardial infarction, the risk was 36 per 1,000 treated for one month. There were 38 (5) cases; among patients with previous stroke or transient ischemic attack, 36 (6) cases per 1,000 patients treated for two years; and among patients with acute stroke treated for three weeks, 36 (6) cases per 1,000 patients treated for two years. 9 (3) per 1,000; among other high-risk patients, 22 (3) per 1,000 treated for two years (stable angina (P=0.0005), peripheral arterial disease (P=0.004 ) and atrial fibrillation (P=0.01), respectively). In each high-risk category, the absolute benefits far outweighed the absolute risks of severe extracranial hemorrhage. Aspirin is the most extensively studied antiplatelet drug, and doses of 75-150 mg daily are at least as effective as higher daily doses. The effect of daily doses below 75 mg is less certain. Compared with aspirin, clopidogrel reduced serious vascular events by 10% (4%), which was similar to the 12% (7%) reduction observed with its analogue ticlopidine. Adding dipyridamole to aspirin did not significantly further reduce vascular events compared with aspirin alone. In patients at high risk for immediate coronary artery occlusion, the short-term addition of an intravenous glycoprotein IIb/IIIa antagonist to aspirin further prevented 20 (4) vascular events per 1000 (P<0.0001) but resulted in 23 cases of serious (but rarely fatal) extracranial hemorrhage per 1,000 people. , patients with unstable or stable angina, previous myocardial infarction, stroke or cerebral ischemia, peripheral arterial disease or atrial fibrillation. Low-dose aspirin (75-150 mg daily) is an effective antiplatelet regimen for long-term use, but in acute situations an initial loading dose of at least 150 mg aspirin may be required. Adding a second antiplatelet drug to aspirin may yield additional benefit in certain clinical situations, but more research on this strategy is needed.

Many clinical trials have evaluated the benefit of long-term use of antiplatelet agents in reducing the risk of clinical thrombotic events. Aspirin and ticlopidine have been shown to be effective, but both have potentially serious side effects. Clopidogrel is a new thienopyridine derivative similar to ticlopidine and an inhibitor of adenosine diphosphate-induced platelet aggregation. CAPRIE was a randomized, double-blind, international trial to evaluate the effectiveness of clopidogrel (75 mg once daily) and aspirin (325 mg once daily) in reducing the risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular disease. Their relative efficacy in terms of risk of composite outcomes including sexual death; their relative safety was also assessed. The study population included a subset of patients with atherosclerotic vascular disease manifesting as recent ischemic stroke, recent myocardial infarction, or symptomatic peripheral arterial disease. Patients were followed for 1 to 3 years. Over 3 years, a total of 19,185 patients were recruited, with more than 6,300 patients per clinical subgroup, and a mean follow-up time of 1.91 years. The outcome cluster included 1960 first events, and the intent-to-treat analysis showed that patients receiving clopidogrel had a 5.32% risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death per year, compared with 5.32% for patients receiving aspirin. The risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction or vascular death is 5.83%. These ratios reflected a statistically significant (p = 0.043) relative risk reduction of 8.7% in favor of clopidogrel (95% Cl 0.3-16.5). The corresponding treatment analysis showed a relative risk reduction of 9.4%. There are no major differences in terms of security. Serious adverse reactions reported in the clopidogrel and aspirin group included rash (0.26% vs 0.10%), diarrhea (0.23% vs 0.11%), upper gastrointestinal discomfort (0.97% vs 1.22%), and intracranial hemorrhage (0.33% vs 0.47%) and gastrointestinal bleeding (0.52% vs 0.72%). Significant neutropenia (< 1.2 x 10(9)/L) occurred in 10 patients (0.10%) in the clopidogrel group and in 16 (0.17%) in the aspirin group. Long-term use of clopidogrel in patients with atherosclerotic vascular disease is more effective than aspirin in reducing the combined risk of ischemic stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. The overall safety profile of clopidogrel is at least as good as that of moderate-dose aspirin.

Lower blood concentrations within the range of LDL cholesterol common in Western populations are associated with lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Therefore, in this population, lowering LDL cholesterol may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely independent of initial cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 British adults (40-80 years) with coronary heart disease, other occlusive arterial disease, or diabetes were randomly assigned to receive simvastatin 40 mg daily (mean compliance: 85%) or matching placebo (mean non- Study statin use: 17%) ). The analysis was the first occurrence of a specific event and compared all participants assigned simvastatin to all participants assigned placebo. These "intention-to-treat" comparisons evaluated the effects of taking statins during a predetermined 5-year treatment period in approximately two-thirds (85% - 17%) of the population, resulting in an average difference in LDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (approximately Two-thirds of the effectiveness of 40 mg of simvastatin daily). The primary outcomes were mortality (for overall analysis) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for subcategory analysis), with ancillary assessments of cancer and other major morbidities. All-cause mortality was significantly lower (1328 of 10,269 simvastatin-treated patients [12.9%] versus 1507 of 10,267 placebo-treated patients [14.7%]; p=0.0003), The reason was a significant 18% reduction in coronary mortality (SE 5). 1.9%] vs 230 [2.2%]; p=0.07) and significantly fewer non-non-vascular deaths (547 [5.3%] vs 570 [5.6%]; p=0.4). The first-event rate of nonfatal myocardial infarction or death from coronary heart disease was significantly lower by approximately one-quarter (898 [8.7%] vs 1212 [11.8%]; p<0.0001), as was the rate of nonfatal or fatal stroke ( 444 [4.3%] vs 585 [5.7%]; p<0.0001), and coronary or noncoronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, the event rate was significantly reduced by 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19-28) (2033 affected individuals [19.8%] vs 2585 affected individuals [25.2%]; p <0.0001). The reduction in major vascular events was not significant in the first year but became significant in each subsequent year. The proportional reductions in event rates were similar (and significant) in each participant subcategory studied, including: participants without diagnosed coronary heart disease, with cerebrovascular disease, peripheral artery disease, or diabetes; men and women ; persons under 70 years of age or over 70 years of age at the time of entry; most notably, even those with LDL cholesterol less than 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL) or total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg /dL) people. The benefits of simvastatin are superior to those of other cardioprotective treatments. The annual additional risk of myopathy with this regimen is approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer rates or hospitalization for any other nonvascular cause. Adding simvastatin to existing treatment can safely provide substantial additional benefit to a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentration. A daily dose of 40 mg of simvastatin reduced the incidence of myocardial infarction, stroke, and revascularization by about a quarter. Actual use of the scheme is likely to reduce these rates by about a third, after accounting for non-compliance. Thus, among the multiple types of high-risk individuals studied, 5 years of simvastatin could prevent about 70-100 per 1,000 from suffering at least one of these major vascular events (and longer treatment should yield further benefits). The size of the 5-year benefit depends primarily on these people's overall risk of major vascular events, not just their lipid concentrations.

Statin therapy reduces low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels and the risk of cardiovascular events, but does adding ezetimibe, a non-statin drug that reduces intestinal cholesterol absorption, further reduce the risk of cardiovascular events? The incidence is unknown. We conducted a double-blind, randomized trial of 18,144 patients who had been hospitalized for acute coronary syndrome in the past 10 days and had LDL cholesterol levels of 50 to 100 mg per deciliter (1.3 to 2.6 millimoles per liter). The combination of simvastatin (40 mg) and ezetimibe (10 mg) (simvastatin-ezetimibe) was compared with simvastatin (40 mg) and placebo (simvastatin monotherapy). The primary endpoint was a composite of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, unstable angina requiring rehospitalization, coronary revascularization (≥30 days after randomization), or nonfatal stroke. Median follow-up time was 6 years. During the study period, the median time-weighted average LDL cholesterol level was 53.7 mg per deciliter (1.4 mmol per liter) in the simvastatin-ezetimibe group and 69.5 mg per deciliter ( 1.8 mmol per liter). The Kaplan-Meier event rate for the 7-year primary endpoint was 32.7% in the simvastatin-ezetimibe group versus 34.7% in the simvastatin monotherapy group (absolute risk difference, 2.0 percentage points; hazard ratio, 0.936; 95% Confidence interval, 0.89 to 0.99; P=0.016). The incidence of prespecified muscle, gallbladder, and hepatic adverse effects, as well as cancer, was similar in both groups. When added to statin therapy, ezetimibe gradually reduces LDL cholesterol levels and improves cardiovascular outcomes. Additionally, lowering LDL cholesterol to levels below previous goals provides additional benefits. (Funded by Merck; IMPROVE-IT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00202878.).

Patients with diabetes mellitus are at increased risk for cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, although their plasma concentrations of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol are generally similar to those in the general population. Previous evidence on the effects of cholesterol lowering in people with diabetes is limited, and most people with diabetes are not currently receiving cholesterol-lowering treatment despite its increased risk. 5963 British adults (aged 40-80 years) with known diabetes and a further 14573 people with occlusive arterial disease (but no diagnosed diabetes) were randomly assigned to receive 40 mg of simvastatin daily or matching placebo agent. Prespecified analyzes within these preexisting disease subcategories and other relevant subcategories were first major coronary event (i.e., nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death) and first major vascular event (i.e., major coronary event, stroke, or revascularization ). Subsequent vascular events during scheduled treatment were also analyzed. Comparing all participants assigned simvastatin to all participants assigned placebo (i.e., treatment intent), the mean difference in LDL cholesterol over 5 years of treatment was 1.0 mmol/L (39 mg/dL). First-event rates of major coronary events, strokes, and revascularization were significantly reduced by about one-quarter in both participants with and without diabetes. For the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events in participants with diabetes, the event rate was significantly reduced by 22% (95% CI 13-30) (601 [20.2%] vs. 748 [25.1%] assigned to simvastatin) placebo allocation, p<0.0001), which was similar to other high-risk individuals studied. Among the 2912 participants with diabetes who did not have any diagnosed occlusive arterial disease at enrollment, mortality was also significantly reduced by 33% (95% CI 17-46, p=0.0003) and 27% (95% CI 13 -40, p=0.0003). The risk ratio was also reduced by about a quarter in each of the other subcategories of people with diabetes studied, including: those with different duration, type or control of diabetes; those who were over 65 at entry or had high blood pressure people; and people with total cholesterol less than 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). Additionally, among participants who experienced their first major vascular event after randomization, assignment to simvastatin reduced the incidence of subsequent events during the scheduled treatment period. This study provides direct evidence that cholesterol-lowering treatment is beneficial in patients with diabetes, even if they do not yet have overt coronary heart disease or high cholesterol concentrations. Among extensively studied patients with diabetes, 40 mg of simvastatin dispensed daily reduced the incidence of a first major vascular event by approximately one-quarter. Actual use of this statin regimen may reduce these rates by approximately one-third, after accounting for nonadherence. For example, among the type of diabetic patients studied who did not have occlusive arterial disease, 5 years of treatment was expected to prevent at least one major vascular event in about 45 per 1,000 people (and, of those 45, about 70 first occurring or subsequent event during treatment). Statin therapy should now be routinely considered in all patients with diabetes who are at sufficiently high risk for major vascular events, regardless of their initial cholesterol concentration.

In patients with pre-existing cardiovascular disease, residual cardiovascular risk remains despite achieving target low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels with statin therapy. It is unclear whether adding extended-release niacin to simvastatin to raise low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol is superior to simvastatin alone in reducing such residual risks. We randomly assigned eligible patients to receive extended-release niacin, 1500 to 2000 mg daily, or matching placebo. All patients were treated with simvastatin (40 to 80 mg daily) plus ezetimibe (10 mg daily) if needed to maintain LDL cholesterol levels of 40 to 80 mg/dL (1.03 to 2.07 mmol /Lift). The primary endpoint was the first event in the composite of death from coronary heart disease, nonfatal myocardial infarction, ischemic stroke, hospitalization for acute coronary syndrome, or symptom-driven coronary or cerebral revascularization. A total of 3414 patients were randomly assigned to receive niacin (1718) or placebo (1696). The trial was stopped after an average follow-up of 3 years due to lack of efficacy. At 2 years, niacin treatment significantly increased median HDL cholesterol levels from 35 mg per deciliter (0.91 mmol per liter) to 42 mg per deciliter (1.08 mmol per liter) and triglyceride levels from 164 mg per deciliter (1.85 mmol per liter) reduced. mg per deciliter (1.60 mmol per liter). The primary endpoint occurred in 282 patients (16.4%) in the niacin group and 274 patients (16.2%) in the placebo group (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval, 0.87 to 1.21; P=0.79, log-rank test). Adding nicotine to statin therapy during 36 months of follow-up in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and LDL cholesterol levels below 70 mg/dL (1.81 mmol/L) Acid did not increase clinical benefit, despite significant clinical benefit. (Funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute and Abbott Laboratories; AIM-HIGH ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00120289.).

Lower blood cholesterol concentrations have been consistently found to be strongly associated with a lower risk of coronary heart disease, but not with a lower risk of stroke. Despite this observation, previous randomized trials have shown that cholesterol-lowering statin therapy reduces the risk of stroke, but large-scale prospective confirmation is needed. 3280 adults with cerebrovascular disease, and an additional 17256 adults with other occlusive arterial disease or diabetes, were randomly assigned to receive 40 mg of simvastatin per day or matching placebo. Subgroup analyzes prespecified the first "major vascular event" (i.e., nonfatal myocardial infarction or death from coronary heart disease, any type of stroke, or any reconstructive surgery) in a previous disease subcategory. Secondary outcomes included any stroke and stroke subtype. Comparing all participants assigned simvastatin to all participants assigned placebo (i.e., “intention-to-treat”), the mean difference in LDL cholesterol over the 5-year treatment period was 1.0 mmol/L (39 mg/dL) . Overall, there was a significant 25% (95% CI 15-34) reduction in the incidence of first stroke events (444 [4.3%] in the simvastatin group vs. 585 [5.7%] in the placebo group; p<0.0001), reflecting There was a clear 28% (19-37) reduction in presumed ischemic stroke (p<0.0001), with no significant difference in hemorrhagic stroke (51 [0.5%] vs 53 [0.5%]; incidence rate ratio 0.95 [0.65 -1.40]; p=0.8). Additionally, simvastatin also reduced the number of people who had only a transient ischemic attack (2.0% vs 2.4%; p=0.02) or who required carotid endarterectomy or angioplasty (0.4% vs 0.8%; p=0.0003). The reduction in strokes was not significant in the first year but became significant by the end of the second year (p=0.0004). Among patients with pre-existing cerebrovascular disease, the incidence of stroke was not significantly reduced, but the incidence of any major vascular event was significantly reduced by 20% (8-29) (406 [24.7%] vs 488 [29.8%]; p =0.001). The proportion of strokes was reduced by about a quarter among every other subcategory of participants studied, including: those with coronary heart disease or diabetes; those younger than or older than 70 years old at entry; and those with varying blood pressure or Patients with low lipid levels (even if LDL cholesterol is less than 3.0 mmol/L [116 mg/dL] before treatment). Far more people suffered strokes in this study than in any previous cholesterol-lowering trial. The results showed that statin treatment rapidly reduced not only the incidence of coronary events but also the incidence of ischemic stroke, without having a significant effect on cerebral hemorrhage, even in individuals with low cholesterol concentrations. Dispensing 40 mg of simvastatin daily reduced the incidence of ischemic stroke by about a quarter, so actual use of this regimen may reduce stroke rates by about a third, after accounting for noncompliance in the trial one. The HPS also provides clear evidence that statin treatment is beneficial in people with existing cerebrovascular disease, even if they do not yet have overt coronary disease.

Previous studies have shown that experimental hypercholesterolemia induces coronary vasa vasorum (VV) neovascularization. Recent evidence suggests that HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors (statins) have beneficial effects that are independent of hypolipidemic effects. We aimed to determine the effect of simvastatin on coronary VV neovascularization without lowering cholesterol. Pigs were randomly divided into 3 groups and fed a normal (N), high cholesterol (HC) or HC+simvastatin (HC+S) diet for 12 weeks. The proximal left anterior descending artery was isolated and reconstructed with a micro-CT scan. The VV density in successive cross-sections along the vessel was then quantified. LDL cholesterol was similarly increased in HC and HC+S compared to N. Compared with N (3.1+/-0.2 vs. 1.8+/-0.1 mm(2); P<0.05). 2) ); P<0.05), despite a similar increase in vessel wall area compared with N (2.5+/-0.1 mm(2); P<0.05). Compared with N, VEGF expression of coronary tissue was increased in HC but not in HC+S. But not in HC+S. . These data are consistent with an alternative mechanism for the vascular effects of statins, independent of cholesterol lowering.

Simvastatin attenuates ischemia and reperfusion in normocholesterolemic animals by stabilizing endothelial nitric oxide synthase activity and inhibiting neutrophil-mediated injury. Since endothelial dysfunction is a deleterious effect of hypercholesterolemia, we investigated whether short-term treatment with simvastatin could inhibit leukocyte-endothelial interactions and attenuate myocardium in apoE-deficient (apoE(-/-)) mice fed high cholesterol. Ischemia-reperfusion damages diet. We studied leukocyte-endothelial interactions in apoE(-/-) mice fed a normal or high-cholesterol diet after short-term (i.e., 18 h) simvastatin treatment. We also studied the therapeutic effect of simvastatin on myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury by subjecting apoE(-/-) mice to 30 minutes of ischemia and 24 hours of reperfusion. ApoE(-/-) mice fed a high-cholesterol diet exhibited higher blood cholesterol levels that were not affected by short-term simvastatin treatment. However, simvastatin treatment significantly attenuated the increase in leukocyte rolling and adhesion (P<0.01 vs. vehicle) in cholesterol-fed apoE(-/-) mice (P<0.001 vs. control diet). Cholesterol-fed apoE(-/-) mice subjected to myocardial ischemia-reperfusion also experienced increased myocardial necrosis (P<0.01 vs. control diet), which was significantly attenuated by simvastatin (vs. vehicle). Ratio P<0.01). Simvastatin treatment also significantly increased vascular nitric oxide production in apoE(-/-) mice. Simvastatin attenuates leukocyte-endothelial cell interactions and ameliorates ischemic injury in hypercholesterolemic mice, independent of its hypolipidemic effect.

From a physiological perspective, physical activity may reduce the risk of stroke. However, epidemiological studies on physical activity and stroke risk have produced mixed results. Therefore, we sought to examine the association between exercise and stroke risk. This was a prospective cohort study of 21 823 men, followed for a mean of 11.1 years. Participants were from the Physicians' Health Study, a randomized trial of low-dose aspirin and beta-carotene. Men aged 40 to 84 years at baseline self-reported freedom from myocardial infarction, stroke, transient ischemic attack, and cancer. At baseline, they reported the frequency of exercise vigorous enough to cause sweating. The occurrence of stroke was reported by the participant and confirmed after medical record review (n=533). We used Cox proportional hazards regression to analyze the data. Relative risk of total stroke associated with vigorous exercise <1, 1, 2 to 4, and >/= 5 times per week at baseline, respectively, after adjustment for age, treatment assignment, smoking, alcohol use, history of angina, and parental history of myocardial infarction were 1.00 (reference), 0.79 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.61 to 1.03), 0.80 (95% CI, 0.65 to 0.99), and 0.79 (95% CI, 0.61 to 1.03), respectively; trend P =0.04. In subgroup analyses, the negative association with hemorrhagic stroke appeared to be stronger than with ischemic stroke. When we additionally adjusted for body mass index, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and history of diabetes, the corresponding relative risks for total stroke were 1.00 (reference), 0.81 (95% CI, 0.61 to 1.07), and 0.88 (95% CI, 0.70), respectively. 1.10) and 0.86 (95% CI, 0.65 to 1.13); P for trend=0.25. Vigorous exercise that results in sweating is linked to a lower risk of stroke in men. In the present study, the inverse association with physical activity appears to be mediated through beneficial effects on body weight, blood pressure, serum cholesterol, and glucose tolerance. In addition to its beneficial effect on these variables, physical activity had no significant residual association with stroke incidence.

The beneficial effects of statins in preventing cardiovascular events may depend, at least in part, on their anti-inflammatory effects. The purpose of the study was to evaluate the effects of simvastatin and aspirin on serum C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), and interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels in subjects with hypercholesterolemia Impact. 33 asymptomatic men with total cholesterol (TC) >6.5 mmol l(-1) and 25 men with coronary heart disease and borderline high cholesterol levels (between 5.2 and 6.5 mmol l(-1)) received long-term Serum concentrations of CRP, TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-8 were measured before and after 3 months of simvastatin treatment (20-40 mg daily) with low-dose aspirin (75 mg/d). In the former group, these inflammatory markers were also measured before and after two weeks of treatment with aspirin (300 mg/d) before and after simvastatin or in combination with simvastatin conduct. CRP and TNF-α were significantly reduced in both groups; IL-6 levels were reduced only in subjects with overt hypercholesterolemia. Aspirin has no effect on the anti-inflammatory effects of simvastatin. In men with hypercholesterolemia, simvastatin treatment reduces serum levels of CRP and proinflammatory cytokines. Low-dose aspirin does not increase the anti-inflammatory effects of simvastatin.

Previous research on diet and coronary heart disease (CHD) has focused primarily on nutrient intake rather than whole foods. Since dietary fiber, folate, and antioxidants have been found to have a possible protective effect against coronary heart disease, increased vegetable intake is recommended. However, due to the chemical and physical complexity of vegetables, the effects of individual nutrients may vary if consumed as whole foods. Furthermore, little is known about the direct relationship between vegetable intake and coronary heart disease risk. We prospectively assessed the association between vegetable intake and risk of coronary heart disease in the Physicians' Health Study, a 1982 study of 22 071 US male physicians aged 40–84 years. -Randomized trial of carotene. amount of information and provides information at the second, fourth and sixth years of follow-up. During the 12-year follow-up period, we identified 1148 cases of CHD (387 cases of myocardial infarction and 761 cases of coronary artery bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty). After adjusting for age, randomized treatment, body mass index (BMI), smoking, alcohol consumption, physical activity, history of diabetes, history of hypertension, history of high cholesterol, and use of multivitamins, men consuming at least 2.5 servings per day were associated with those in the lowest category (< 1 serving/day), the relative risk (RR) of CHD for vegetable consumption was 0.77 (95% CI: 0.60-0.98). Adjusting for the same covariates in an overall trend analysis treating vegetable intake as a continuous variable, we found that the risk of coronary heart disease was associated with an RR of 0.83 (95% CI: 0.71-0.98) for each additional serving of vegetables per day. The inverse association between vegetable intake and CHD risk was stronger among men with a BMI > or = 25 (RR = 0.71, 95% CI: 0.51-0.99) or current smokers (RR = 0.40, 95% CI: 0.18-0.86 ) is more obvious. Our results showed an inverse association between vegetable intake and coronary heart disease risk. These prospective data support current dietary guidelines for increased vegetable intake to prevent coronary heart disease.

Homeless people are an extremely vulnerable population in North America. Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death among older homeless men. The purpose of this study was to examine cardiovascular risk factors in a representative sample of homeless adults and identify opportunities for improved risk factor modification. Homeless individuals were randomly selected from Toronto single adult shelters. The response rate was 79%. Participants (n=202) were interviewed, body measured, and blood sampled. The average age of participants was 42 years, and 89% were male. Smoking prevalence among the homeless (78%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 72% to 84%) was significantly higher than that in the general population (standardized incidence ratio [SMR], 254; 95% CI, 216 to 297) . High blood pressure, high cholesterol and diabetes are no more common than in the general population but are often poorly controlled. Homeless men were significantly less likely to be overweight or obese than men in the general population (SMR, 79; 95% CI, 63 to 98). Twenty-nine percent of subjects reported past year cocaine use (95% CI, 23% to 36%). Fifteen percent of subjects reported CVD, with less than one-third reporting taking aspirin or cholesterol-lowering medications. According to the multiple risk factor equation, the median estimated 10-year absolute risk of myocardial infarction or death from coronary heart disease among homeless men aged 30 to 74 years was 5% (interquartile range, 3% to 9%) . Cardiovascular risk factor modification among homeless adults in Toronto despite universal health coverage. Multiple risk factor equations may underestimate the true risk for this population by not adequately accounting for factors such as cocaine use and heavy smoking.

Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor that offers a simple fixed-dose regimen for the treatment of acute deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and ongoing therapy without the need for laboratory monitoring. We conducted an open-label, randomized, event-driven, noninferiority study comparing oral rivaroxaban alone (15 mg twice daily for 3 weeks, then 20 mg once daily) with Comparison of subcutaneous enoxaparin followed by a vitamin K antagonist (warfarin or acenocoumarol) for 3, 6, or 12 months in patients with acute, symptomatic DVT. In parallel, we conducted a double-blind, randomized, event-driven superiority study comparing rivaroxaban (20 mg once daily) alone to rivaroxaban (20 mg once daily) in patients who had completed 6 to 12 months of intravenous therapy. Comparisons with placebo were conducted for an additional 6 or 12 months. The primary efficacy outcome in both studies was recurrent venous thromboembolism. The primary safety outcomes were major bleeding or clinically relevant non-major bleeding in the initial treatment study and major bleeding in the ongoing treatment study. The study of rivaroxaban in acute DVT included 3449 patients: 1731 patients were treated with rivaroxaban and 1718 patients were treated with enoxaparin plus a vitamin K antagonist. For the primary outcome, rivaroxaban was not inferior (36 events [2.1%] compared with 51 events [3.0%] for the enoxaparin vitamin K antagonist; hazard ratio, 0.68; 95% Confidence interval [CI], 0.44 to 1.04; P<0.001). The primary safety outcome occurred in 8.1% of patients in each group. In the ongoing treatment study, which included 602 patients in the rivaroxaban group and 594 patients in the placebo group, rivaroxaban had superior efficacy (8 events [1.3%] versus 42 events [7.1%] in the placebo group). ]; hazard ratio, 0.18; 95% CI, 0.09 to 0.39; P<0.001). Four patients in the rivaroxaban group experienced nonfatal major bleeding (0.7%) compared with none in the placebo group (P=0.11). Rivaroxaban offers a simple single-agent approach for short-term and ongoing treatment of venous thrombosis that may improve the benefit-risk ratio of anticoagulant therapy. (Funded by Bayer Schering Pharma and Ortho-McNeil; ClinicalTrials.gov numbers: NCT00440193 and NCT00439725.).

It is unknown whether the oral factor Xa inhibitor edoxaban can replace warfarin in patients with VTE. In a randomized, double-blind, noninferiority study, we randomly assigned patients with acute VTE who were initially treated with heparin to receive edoxaban at a dose of 60 mg once daily or 30 mg once daily (eg, , in patients with) a creatinine clearance of 30 to 50 ml per minute or a body weight less than 60 kg), or in patients receiving warfarin. Patients received study drug for 3 to 12 months. The primary efficacy outcome was recurrent VTE symptoms. The primary safety outcome was major bleeding or clinically relevant nonmajor bleeding. A total of 4921 patients developed deep vein thrombosis and 3319 patients developed pulmonary embolism. Among patients receiving warfarin, they were in the therapeutic range 63.5% of the time. For the primary efficacy outcome, edoxaban was noninferior to warfarin, which occurred in 130 patients (3.2%) in the edoxaban group and 146 patients (3.5%) in the warfarin group. This was the case (hazard ratio, 0.89; 95% confidence interval [CI]), 0.70 to 1.13; P<0.001 for noninferiority). Safety outcomes occurred in 349 patients (8.5%) in the edoxaban group and in 423 patients (10.3%) in the warfarin group (hazard ratio, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.71 to 0.94; P for superiority =0.004). The incidence of other adverse events was similar in both groups. A total of 938 patients with pulmonary embolism had right ventricular dysfunction as assessed by measuring N-terminal brain natriuretic peptide precursor levels; the recurrence rate of venous thromboembolism in this subgroup was 3.3% in the edoxaban group and 6.2% in the warfarin group ( hazard ratio, 0.52; 95% CI, 0.28 to 0.98). Once-daily administration of edoxaban after initial treatment with heparin was noninferior to high-quality standard care and significantly reduced bleeding in a broad range of patients with VTE, including those with severe pulmonary embolism. (Funded by Daiichi-Sankyo; Hokusai-VTE ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00986154.)

Patients with acute proximal deep vein thrombosis are usually first treated in the hospital with intravenous standard (unfractionated) heparin. However, low molecular weight heparin's longer plasma half-life, better bioavailability after subcutaneous injection, and more predictable anticoagulant response make it attractive for home use. We compared these two methods. Patients with acute proximal deep vein thrombosis were randomly assigned to receive hospital-based intravenous standard heparin (253 patients) or primarily low-molecular-weight heparin (1 mg enoxaparin per kilogram of body weight subcutaneously twice daily) at home. patient). The study design allowed patients taking LMWH as an outpatient to go home immediately and patients taking LMWH as an inpatient to be discharged early. All patients received warfarin starting the next day. Thirteen of 247 patients (5.3%) who received low-molecular-weight heparin had recurrent thromboembolism compared with 17 of 253 patients (6.7%) who received standard heparin; P = 0.57; absolute difference, 1.4 percentage points; 95% confidence interval), -3.0 to 5.7). Five patients receiving low-molecular-weight heparin experienced major bleeding, compared with three patients receiving standard heparin. After randomization, the average length of stay in the hospital for patients who received low-molecular-weight heparin was 1.1 days compared with 6.5 days for those who received standard heparin. 120 patients in the low-molecular-weight heparin group did not need to be hospitalized at all. Low molecular weight heparin can safely and effectively treat patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis at home.

Prevention of deep vein thrombosis in hospitalized patients remains underutilized. We hypothesized that the use of computerized alert programs to encourage prevention may reduce the frequency of deep venous thrombosis in high-risk hospitalized patients. We developed a computer program linked to a patient database to identify consecutive hospitalized patients at risk for deep venous thrombosis without prophylaxis. The program used medical record numbers to randomly assign 1255 eligible patients to an intervention group, in which the responsible physician was alerted to the patient's risk for deep vein thrombosis, and 1251 patients to a control group, in which no alert was issued. Physicians need to confirm the alarm and can then withhold or order prophylaxis, including graded compression stockings, pneumatic pressure boots, unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparin, or warfarin. The primary endpoint was clinically diagnosed, objectively confirmed deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days. A higher number of patients received mechanical prophylaxis (10.0% vs. 1.5%, P<0.001) or drug prophylaxis (23.6% vs. 13.0%, P<0.001) in the intervention group. The primary endpoint occurred in 61 patients (4.9%) in the interventional group compared with 103 patients (8.2%) in the control group; Kaplan-Meier estimated that the likelihood of freedom from deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days was 94.1%, respectively ( 95 % confidence interval, 92.5% to 95.4%) and 90.6% (95% confidence interval, 88.7% to 92.2%), respectively ( P < 0.001). Computerized alerts reduced the risk of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism at 90 days by 41% (hazard ratio, 0.59; 95% confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.81; P=0.001). The establishment of a computerized alert program increased physician use of preventive measures and significantly reduced the incidence of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism in high-risk hospitalized patients.

In patients with cryptogenic ischemic stroke, it is unknown whether non-closure of the foramen ovale reduces the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke. In a multicenter, randomized, open-label trial with blinded endpoint events, we randomized patients aged 18 to 60 years with patent foramen ovale (PFO) and cryptogenic ischemic stroke. Assigned to receive occlusion. The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of recurrent nonfatal ischemic stroke, fatal ischemic stroke, or early death after randomization. Results of the analysis of the primary outcome from the original trial period were previously reported; the current analysis of data from the extended follow-up period is considered exploratory. We enrolled 980 patients (mean age 45.9 years) at 69 sites. Patients were followed for a median of 5.9 years. Treatment exposure was unequal between the two groups (3141 patient-years in the PFO closure group versus 2669 patient-years in the medical therapy group) due to a higher dropout rate in the medical therapy group. In the intention-to-treat population, 18 patients in the PFO closure group and 28 patients in the medical therapy group experienced recurrent ischemic stroke, resulting in 0.58 events per 100 patient-years and 0.58 events per 100 patient-years. There were 1.07 events per patient. Unexplained recurrent ischemic stroke occurred in 10 patients in the PFO closure group and in 23 patients in the medical therapy group (hazard ratio, 0.38; 95% CI, 0.18 ~0.79; P=0.007). Venous thromboembolism (including pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis) was more common in the PFO closure group than in the medical therapy group. In adults with cryptogenic ischemic stroke, PFO closure was associated with a lower incidence of recurrent ischemic stroke compared with medical treatment alone during long-term follow-up. (Funded by St. Jude Medical; RESPECT ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00465270.).

Individuals with transient ischemic attacks and ischemic strokes are at high risk for recurrent stroke and death. Although acetylsalicylic acid (ASA, aspirin) has been proven and accepted as standard therapy for these patients, recent trials suggest that the combination of ASA with dipyridamole (DP) or clopidogrel may be superior to ASA. Blocking the renin-angiotensin system with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers may also reduce stroke recurrence. The ongoing PRoFESS (Prevention Scheme to Effectively Avoid a Second Stroke) trial is designed to evaluate whether ASA + extended-release DP compared with clopidogrel and telmisartan in addition to usual care in post-stroke patients will reduce the risk of second stroke. Risk of stroke. PRoFESS was a multicenter, randomized, double-blind trial involving 695 centers from 35 countries. Patients ≥50 years of age, stable, and <120 days old from ischemic stroke were randomized. The primary outcome of the trial was the identification of recurrent stroke using time-to-event analysis. The most important secondary outcome was the composite of stroke, myocardial infarction, or vascular death. Other secondary outcomes included this composite endpoint + congestive heart failure, new-onset diabetes mellitus, other specified occlusive vascular events (pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, peripheral arterial occlusion, transient ischemic attack, cerebral venous thrombosis, or no Retinal vascular accident classified as stroke), any death, stroke subtype (according to TOAST criteria and Mini-Mental State Examination score). Safety was assessed by assessing the risk of major bleeding events. Comparisons between ASA + DP and clopidogrel are based on an initial assessment of non-inferiority followed by assessment of superiority, whereas for telmisartan we will assess superiority relative to placebo. Using a 2 x 2 factorial design with more than 20,000 patients randomized, PRoFESS is the largest stroke trial investigating the prevention of recurrent stroke. The mean age was 66.1 +/- 8.6 years, and 36.0% of patients were female. The median time from qualifying event to randomization was 15 days, with 39.9% of patients randomized within 10 days. According to TOAST criteria, 28.5% of strokes are caused by large vessel disease, 52.1% by small vessel disease, 1.8% by cardioembolism, 2.0% by other established causes, and 15.5% is caused by an undetermined cause. PRoFESS is the largest secondary stroke prevention trial to date and will directly compare the benefits of two antiplatelet regimens and telmisartan versus placebo.

The risk of bleeding complications during and after early hip fracture surgery in patients taking clopidogrel and other anticoagulants has not been established. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the risk of perioperative bleeding and clinical outcomes after early hip fracture surgery in patients taking clopidogrel (Plavix) and other oral anticoagulants. The study design was a retrospective cohort analysis using data extracted from hospital records and state death records. Regional Medical Center (Level 2 Trauma). Data from 1118 patients over 60 years of age who underwent surgical treatment for hip fractures between 2004 and 2008 were reviewed. Eighty-two patients who underwent late surgery (more than 3 days after admission) were excluded. Patients taking clopidogrel were compared with those not taking clopidogrel. Additionally, patients taking clopidogrel alone were compared with those taking both clopidogrel and aspirin, aspirin only, warfarin only, or no anticoagulant. 74 of 1036 patients (7%) were taking clopidogrel, while the control group included 253 patients taking aspirin only, 90 patients taking warfarin, and 619 patients taking no anticoagulants . There were no significant differences in estimated blood loss, transfusion requirements, final blood count, hematoma evacuation, length of stay (LOS), or in-hospital or 1-year mortality between patients taking clopidogrel and those not taking clopidogrel. The American Society of Anesthesiologists score was higher in the clopidogrel group and the warfarin group (P = 0.05), the LOS was increased in the clopidogrel group (P = 0.05), and the deep vein thrombosis rate was higher in patients taking warfarin (P = 0.05). Clopidogrel alone compared with aspirin, aspirin and clopidogrel, and no anticoagulant compared with warfarin in terms of estimated blood loss, transfusion requirements, final blood counts, bleeding, or perioperative There were no significant differences in early-stage complications or mortality. Taking clopidogrel, aspirin, or warfarin (at prescribed international normalized ratios) in patients undergoing early hip fracture surgery does not significantly increase the risk of bleeding, bleeding complications, or death. Comorbidities and American Society of Anesthesiologists scores were significantly higher in the clopidogrel group, which may have contributed to increased postoperative LOS in this group.

Several novel anticoagulants are in clinical development. There are two drugs recently, dabigatran etexilate/Pradaxa. Rivaroxaban/rivaroxaban has marketing authorization in Europe and Canada for the prevention of thromboembolic events after major orthopedic surgeries such as total hip and knee replacements. Results from a phase III clinical study of thromboprophylaxis in major orthopedic surgery are highlighted and discussed in detail. Ongoing Phase II and III clinical trials are evaluating its use in the secondary prevention and treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, mid- and long-term prevention of stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation, and in combination with aspirin and clopidogrel. Efficacy in patients suffering from acute coronary syndrome. Many other antithrombotic small molecules, including new generation low molecular weight heparins, are currently in various stages of clinical development. In addition to oral administration, newer anticoagulants have a more balanced benefit/risk ratio and a wider therapeutic window. They act rapidly, have predictable anticoagulant effects, and do not require routine laboratory monitoring. They have minor interactions with food and drugs, including with cytochrome P450 and P.gp. They are highly specific, target a single clotting factor and may carry similar or less bleeding risks than older anticoagulants. Finally, they can be used in a wider range of patients, especially in patients with advanced cancer and the elderly, without any dose adjustment, regardless of patient age, gender, weight, or in patients with mild renal insufficiency. Their use around the world is expected to confirm the promising results of clinical trials.

Allopurinol is a commonly used drug to treat gout and hyperuricemia and is a common cause of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs), including drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis. Adverse events are unpredictable and have significant morbidity and mortality. To identify genetic markers for allopurinol-SCAR, we performed a case-control association study. We recruited 51 allopurinol-SCAR patients and 228 control individuals (135 allopurinol-tolerant subjects and 93 healthy subjects from the general population) and examined 823 SNPs in the gene were genotyped. Preliminary screening revealed a strong association between allopurinol-SCAR and SNPs in the MHC region, including BAT3 (encoding HLA-B-related transcript 3), MSH5 (mutS homolog 5), and MICB (MHC class I Polypeptide related sequence B) (P < 10(-7)). We then determined the alleles of HLA loci A, B, C, and DRB1. The HLA-B*5801 allele was present in all (100%) of the 51 allopurinol-SCAR patients but only in 20 (15%) of the 135 tolerant patients [odds ratio 580.3 (95% confidence range, 34.4-9780.9); adjusted P value = 4.7 10(-18)]. HLA alleles A*3303, Cw*0302 and DRB1*0301 are in linkage disequilibrium and form an extended haplotype with HLA-B*5801. Our results show that allopurinol-SCAR is closely associated with genetic susceptibility in Han Chinese. In particular, the HLA-B*5801 allele is an important genetic risk factor for this life-threatening disease.

Develop evidence-based recommendations for gout treatment. The multidisciplinary guideline development group consisted of 19 rheumatologists and one evidence-based medicine expert representing 13 European countries. Key claims for management were generated using the Delphi consensus method. Research evidence was systematically searched for each proposition. Where possible, effect sizes (ES), number needed to treat, relative risks, odds ratios, and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios were calculated. The quality of evidence is classified according to the level of evidence. Strength of recommendations (SOR) was assessed using EULAR visual analogue and ordinal scales. After three Delphi rounds, 12 key propositions were generated. Proposals include non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments and address symptom control of acute gout, urate-lowering therapy (ULT) and prevention of acute gout. The importance of patient education, changing unhealthy lifestyles (weight loss in obese patients, reducing alcohol consumption, low animal purine diet) and treating related comorbidities and risk factors are emphasized. Recommended medications for acute exacerbations are oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), oral colchicine (ES = 0.87 (95% confidence interval, 0.25 to 1.50)), or joint aspiration and injection of corticosteroids. ULT is suitable for patients with recurrent acute attacks, joint disease, tophi, or gout imaging changes. Allopurinol was shown to be an effective long-term ULT (ES = 1.39 (0.78 to 2.01)). If allopurinol toxicity occurs, options include other xanthine oxidase inhibitors, allopurinol desensitization, or uricosuric agents. The uricosuric benzbromarone is more potent than allopurinol (ES = 1.50 (0.76 to 2.24)) and can be used in patients with mild to moderate renal impairment but may be hepatotoxic. When gout is associated with diuretic use, diuretics should be discontinued if possible. To prevent acute attacks, it is recommended to take colchicine 0.5-1 mg daily or a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (gastric protection if necessary). Combining research evidence and expert consensus, 12 key recommendations for gout management were developed. The evidence was evaluated and an SOR provided for each proposal.

Febuxostat is a novel non-purine-selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is a potential alternative to allopurinol in patients with hyperuricemia and gout. We randomly assigned 762 gout patients with serum uric acid concentrations of at least 8.0 mg/dL (480 μmol/L) to receive either febuxostat (80 mg or 120 mg) or allopurinol (300 mg) once daily. Lasted 52 weeks; 760 people received study drug. Between weeks 1 and 8, use naproxen or colchicine to prevent gout attacks. Secondary endpoints included gout attack rate and reduction in tophi area. The primary endpoint was met in 53% of patients treated with 80 mg of febuxostat, 62% of patients treated with 120 mg of febuxostat, and 21% of patients treated with allopurinol. The primary endpoint was determined (P<0.001 for each febuxostat group versus allopurinol group). Although the incidence of gout attacks decreased with continued treatment, the overall incidence was similar in all groups from weeks 9 to 52: 64% of patients who received 80 mg of febuxostat and 120 mg of febuxostat. Gout attacks occurred in 70% of patients on buxostat and 64% of patients on febuxostat 120 mg. =0.99; 120 mg febuxostat vs allopurinol, P=0.23). The median reduction in tophi area was 83% in patients who received 80 mg of febuxostat and 66% in those who received 120 mg of febuxostat and 66% in those who received allopurinol. Tophi area decreased by 50% in treated patients (P=0.08 for 80 mg febuxostat vs. allopurinol; P=0.16 for 120 mg febuxostat vs. allopurinol). More patients in the high-dose febuxostat group discontinued the study than in the allopurinol group (P=0.003) or the low-dose febuxostat group. Four of 507 patients (0.8%) died in the two febuxostat groups and none of the 253 patients in the allopurinol group; all deaths were judged by the investigators (who remained blinded to the treatment) to be This was due to causes unrelated to the study drug (comparison of febuxostat combination group and allopurinol group, P = 0.31). Febuxostat daily doses of 80 mg or 120 mg are more effective in lowering serum uric acid than the commonly used fixed daily dose of allopurinol of 300 mg. Similar reductions in gout attacks and tophi area were seen in all treatment groups.

The classic xanthine oxidase (XO) inhibitor allopurinol has been the cornerstone of clinical treatment of gout and hyperuricemia-related diseases for decades. Recent data suggest that XO also plays an important role in various forms of ischemic and other types of tissue and vascular injury, inflammatory diseases, and chronic heart failure. Allopurinol and its active metabolite opurinol have shown great promise in treating these diseases in experimental animals and small-scale human clinical trials. Although some of the beneficial effects of these compounds may not be related to the inhibition of XOs, the encouraging findings have sparked renewed interest in the development of other novel families of XO inhibitors for various therapeutic indications. Here, we provide an important overview of the role of XO inhibitors in various pathophysiological conditions and review the various emerging therapeutic strategies offered by this approach.

To evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in subjects with primary fibromyalgia, with or without major depressive disorder. This study was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted at 18 outpatient research sites in the United States. A total of 207 subjects meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for primary fibromyalgia were enrolled (89% female, 87% white, mean age 49 years, 38% with current major depressive disorder). After 1 week of single-blind placebo treatment, subjects were randomly assigned to receive duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (n = 104) or placebo (n = 103) for 12 weeks. Co-primary outcome measures were Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) total score (score range 0-80, with 0 indicating no impact) and FIQ pain score (score range 0-10). Secondary outcome measures included mean tender point pain threshold, number of tender points, FIQ fatigue, waking fatigue and stiffness scores, Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI-Severity) scale, Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-Improvement) scale , Brief Pain Inventory (Short Form), Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36, Depression Quality of Life Scale, and Sheehan Disability Scale. Duloxetine-treated subjects improved significantly more on the FIQ total score than placebo-treated subjects (P = 0.027), with a treatment difference of -5.53 (95% confidence interval -10.43, - 0.63), but not in FIQ pain score (P = 0.130). Compared with placebo-treated subjects, duloxetine-treated subjects had lower mean pain severity scores on the Brief Pain Scale (P = 0.008), mean interference scores on the Brief Pain Scale (P = 0.004), There was a significantly greater reduction in tender point number (P = 0.004). , PGI improvement (P = 0.033) and significantly greater improvements in some indicators. Treatment with duloxetine improved fibromyalgia symptoms and pain severity regardless of baseline status of major depression. Duloxetine-treated female subjects (n = 92) demonstrated significantly greater improvements on most efficacy measures compared with placebo-treated female subjects (n = 92), while duloxetine-treated female subjects (n = 92) There were no significant improvements in any efficacy measures among statin-treated male subjects (n = 12). The treatment effect, which significantly reduced pain in female subjects, was independent of effects on mood or anxiety. Duloxetine is safe to administer and well tolerated. In this 12-week randomized controlled trial, which included a 1-week placebo run-in period, duloxetine was effective in many of the symptoms associated with fibromyalgia in subjects (particularly women) with and without major depression. Symptoms of Relevance is an effective and safe treatment with significant improvements in most outcome measures.

This was a 12-week randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial to evaluate duloxetine, a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in 354 patients with primary Efficacy and safety in women with fibromyalgia, with and without current major depression. Patients (90% white; mean age 49.6 years; 26% with major depressive disorder) received duloxetine 60 mg once daily (QD) (N=118), duloxetine 60 mg twice daily ( BID) (N=116), or placebo (N=120). The primary outcome was the Brief Pain Scale mean pain severity score. Response to treatment was defined as a score reduction > or = 30%. Mean pain severity scores on the Brief Pain Scale were significantly improved in the duloxetine treatment group compared with placebo (P<0.001). A significantly higher proportion of patients receiving duloxetine had a ≥30% decrease in this score (duloxetine 60 mg QD (55%; P < 0.001); duloxetine 60 mg BID (54%; P = 0.002); placebo (33%)). The therapeutic effect of duloxetine on reducing pain was independent of its effects on mood and the presence of major depression. Compared with patients who received placebo, patients who received duloxetine 60 mg QD or duloxetine 60 mg BID had lower scores on the remaining Brief Pain Inventory pain severity and interference scores, the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire, and severity scores. Clinical global impression, patient global impression of improvement, and multiple quality of life measures. Both doses of duloxetine were administered safely and were well tolerated. In conclusion, duloxetine 60 mg QD and duloxetine 60 mg BID are both effective and safe in the treatment of fibromyalgia in female patients with and without major depression.

The primary objective of this study was to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine for reducing pain severity in fibromyalgia patients with and without major depression. This was a 6-month multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. A total of 520 patients meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for fibromyalgia were randomly assigned to duloxetine (20 mg/day, 60 mg/day, or 120 mg/day) or placebo once daily for 6 month (after 3 months, the duloxetine 20 mg/day group was titrated to 60 mg/day). Co-primary outcome measures were Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) mean pain severity score and Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) score. Safety was assessed by treatment-emergent adverse events and changes in vital signs, laboratory and electrocardiographic measurements. Patients who received duloxetine 120 mg/day had a significant improvement on the co-primary outcome measure at 3 months (change in BPI score [-2.31 vs -1.39, P < 0.001] and PGI-I [2.89 vs 3.39, P=0.004]) and at 6 months (BPI change [-2.26 vs -1.43, P=0.003] and PGI-I [2.93 vs 3.37, P=0.012]). Treatment with duloxetine 60 mg/day also significantly improved the secondary primary endpoint at 3 months and BPI at 6 months compared with placebo. Duloxetine is effective in patients with and without major depression. There were no clinically significant differences in changes in vital signs, laboratory measurements, or electrocardiographic measurements between treatment groups. Study results indicate that duloxetine at doses of 60 mg/day and 120 mg/day appears to be safe and effective in patients with fibromyalgia.

Duloxetine is a balanced serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor licensed for the treatment of major depression, stress urinary incontinence, and the treatment of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A number of trials have been conducted to study the use of duloxetine in neuropathic and nociceptive pain conditions. This is the first update of a review first published in 2010. On November 19, 2013, we searched the Cochrane Neuromuscular Group Professional Register, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHSEED, MEDLINE and EMBASE. We searched ClinicalTrials.gov for ongoing trials in April 2013. We selected all randomized or quasi-randomized trials of any formulation of duloxetine for the treatment of painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain in adults. We used standard methodological procedures expected from the Cochrane Collaboration. We identified 18 trials including 6407 participants. We identified 12 of these studies in the literature search for this update. Eight studies involved a total of 2728 participants with painful diabetic neuropathy, and six studies involved 2249 participants with fibromyalgia. Three studies included participants with depression and painful physical symptoms, and one study included participants with central neuropathic pain. Most studies had a low risk of bias, although significant dropout rates, imputation methods, and the fact that nearly every study conducted or sponsored by a drug manufacturer increased the risk of bias in some areas. Duloxetine 60 mg daily was effective in the short-term treatment of painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy, with a risk ratio (RR) of 1.73 (95% CI 1.44 to 2.08) for ≥50% pain relief at 12 weeks. The associated NNTB was 5 (95% CI 4 to 7). Duloxetine 60 mg daily after 12 weeks (RR 1.57, 95% CI 1.20 to 2.06 for ≥50% pain relief; NNTB 8, 95% CI 4 to 21) and above 28 weeks (RR 1.58, 95) Also effective in fibromyalgia. In one small, high-quality trial, there was no effect on central neuropathic pain. In all cases, adverse events were common in both the treatment and placebo groups, but were more common in the treatment group with a dose-dependent effect. Most adverse effects were mild, but 16% of participants discontinued medication due to adverse effects. Serious adverse events are rare. Eight studies conducted by the manufacturer of duloxetine provided a sufficient amount of moderate-quality evidence to show that daily doses of 60 mg and 120 mg were effective in treating the pain of diabetic peripheral neuropathy, but not lower daily doses. No further testing is required. For fibromyalgia, there is lower-quality evidence that duloxetine is effective at similar doses and has similar effects to those used to treat diabetic peripheral neuropathy. The benefits of treating fibromyalgia may be through greater improvements in psychiatric symptoms compared with physical pain. There was low-to-moderate quality evidence that pain associated with depressive symptoms may also be relieved, but an NNTB of 8 for fibromyalgia and depression does not indicate substantial benefit. More trials (ideally independent investigator-led studies) are needed in these indications to achieve the optimal amount of information to make convincing efficacy determinations. doses (especially the 120 mg daily dose) are more common than the 20 mg daily dose. A direct comparison of effective pregabalin) is appropriate. Unbiased economic comparisons would further aid decision-making, but no high-quality studies contain economic data.

Peripheral arterial disease is considered a manifestation of systemic atherosclerosis with associated adverse cardiovascular and limb events. Data from previous trials suggest that patients receiving clopidogrel monotherapy have a lower risk of cardiovascular events than patients receiving aspirin. We wanted to compare the effects of clopidogrel and ticagrelor, a potent antiplatelet drug, in patients with peripheral arterial disease. In this double-blind, event-driven trial, we randomly assigned 13,885 patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease to receive either ticagrelor (90 mg twice daily) or clopidogrel (75 mg once daily) alone treat. Patients were eligible if they had an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.80 or less or had previously undergone lower extremity revascularization. The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of adjudicated cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, or ischemic stroke. The primary safety endpoint was major bleeding. Median follow-up time was 30 months. The median patient age was 66 years, and 72% were male; 43% of patients were enrolled based on ABI and 57% based on prior revascularization. The mean baseline ABI across all patients was 0.71, with 76.6% of patients experiencing claudication and 4.6% experiencing critical limb ischemia. The primary efficacy endpoint occurred in 751 of 6930 patients (10.8%) who received ticagrelor and in 740 of 6955 patients (10.6%) who received clopidogrel (hazard ratio, 1.02; 95% confidence interval [ CI], 0.92 to 1.13; P=0.65). In each group, acute limb ischemia occurred in 1.7% of patients (hazard ratio, 1.03; 95% CI, 0.79 to 1.33; P=0.85) and major bleeding occurred in 1.6% of patients (hazard ratio, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.84 to 0.85). 1.33). In patients with symptomatic peripheral arterial disease, ticagrelor was not superior to clopidogrel in reducing cardiovascular events. The incidence of major bleeding was similar in both trial groups. (Funded by AstraZeneca; EUCLID ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT01732822.).

Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) affects approximately 20% of adults over the age of 55 and is a strong predictor of myocardial infarction, stroke, and death from vascular causes. The goals of treatment are to prevent future major coronary and cerebrovascular events and to improve leg symptoms. Review of the best evidence for pharmacological treatment of PAD. MEDLINE and the Cochrane database were searched from 1990 to November 2005 for randomized trials and meta-analyses of pharmacological treatments for PAD. The references of these articles were also searched. Search terms included, individually and in combination: peripheral arterial disease, peripheral arterial disease, PAD, randomized controlled trial, controlled trial, randomized and meta-analysis. Special focus is given to randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses of clinically relevant pharmacological treatments for PAD. Outcome measures included leg symptoms (intermittent claudication and walking distance), death, and major coronary and cerebrovascular events. Leg claudication symptoms, walking distance, and quality of life can be improved by smoking cessation (physician advice, nicotine replacement therapy, and bupropion), structured exercise programs, statins, cilostazol, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors to improve. Major coronary and cerebrovascular events can be reduced by lowering blood pressure with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs, antiplatelet therapy with statins, aspirin, or clopidogrel, and possibly by smoking cessation risks of. The large and growing burden of PAD and its local and Systemic complications.

Incomplete inhibition of platelet thromboxane production, as measured by elevated urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events. We aimed to determine the external validity of this association in aspirin-treated patients participating in the Clopidogrel at High Atherothrombotic Risk and Ischemia Stabilization, Management, and Avoidance (CHARISMA) trial and to determine whether Any modifiable factors or interventions that reduce urinary 11-dehydrothromoxane B(2) concentrations may reduce cardiovascular risk. Urinary 11-dehydrothromoxane B(2) concentrations were measured in 3261 aspirin-treated patients who were randomly assigned to placebo or clopidogrel for at least 1 month. Baseline urinary 11-dehydrothromoxane B(2) concentrations in the highest quartile were associated with an increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death compared with the lowest quartile (adjusted hazard ratio 1.66, 95 % CI 1.06 to 2.61, P = 0.03). Increasing age, female gender, history of peripheral arterial disease, current smoking, and treatment with oral hypoglycemic agents or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors were independently associated with increased urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations, whereas aspirin Doses > or = 150 mg/d, history of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug therapy, history of hypercholesterolemia, and statin therapy were associated with lower concentrations. Randomization of clopidogrel (compared with placebo) did not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients in the highest quartile of urinary 11-dehydrothromoxane B(2). In patients receiving aspirin, urinary concentrations of 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) are an externally valid and potentially preventable risk factor for stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death in patients at risk for atherothrombotic events. Determinants of change.

This guideline focuses on antithrombotic pharmacotherapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease and relief of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The approach to this guideline follows that described in Methods for the Development of Guidelines for Antithrombotic Treatment and Thrombosis Prevention: Antithrombotic Treatment and Thrombosis Prevention, 9th Edition: American College of Chest Physicians Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines. The most important of our 20 tips is as follows. In patients ≥50 years of age with asymptomatic PAD or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we recommend aspirin (75–100 mg/d) rather than no treatment (Grade 2B) for primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic PAD, including those before and after peripheral arterial bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty, we recommend long-term aspirin (75-100 mg/d) or Clopidogrel (75 mg/d) (Grade 1A). We recommend against the use of warfarin plus aspirin in patients with symptomatic PAD (Grade 1B). We recommend single antiplatelet therapy rather than dual antiplatelet therapy in patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal stenting of peripheral arteries (Grade 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we recommend adding cilostazol to aspirin (75-100 mg/d) or clopidogrel (75 mg/d) (100 mg bid) (Grade 2C). We recommend the use of prostaglandins (Grade 2C) in patients with severe limb ischemia and rest pain that precludes revascularization. For patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgery rather than peripheral arterial thrombolysis (Grade 1B). For most patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis, the recommendation continues to favor monoantiplatelet therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events. Other treatments to relieve extremity symptoms should be considered only after evaluation with exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and peripheral arterial revascularization.

The approach to this guideline follows that described in Methods for the Development of Guidelines for Antithrombotic Treatment and Thrombosis Prevention: Antithrombotic Treatment and Thrombosis Prevention, 9th Edition: American College of Chest Physicians Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guidelines.
