Bleeding is a common complication of acute myocardial infarction (AMI) treatment and is associated with poor prognosis. Contemporary models of major bleeding associated with AMI treatment can stratify patients at higher risk for bleeding and require risk adjustment for AMI practices and outcomes. In-hospital major bleeding risk models were developed for patient populations with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and non-ST-segment myocardial infarction using the Acute Coronary Treatment and Intervention Outcomes Network Registry-Getting Guidelines (ACTION Registry-GWTG) database. infarction. The model used only baseline variables and was developed (n = 72,313) and validated (n = 17,960) in patients with AMI (251 centers in the United States from January 2007 to December 2008). The 12 most statistically and clinically significant variables were included in the final regression model. Calibration plots are shown, and model discrimination is demonstrated in derivation and validation cohorts and key subgroups. The incidence of major bleeding in the general population is 10.8%. The 12 factors associated with major bleeding in the model were heart rate, baseline hemoglobin, female sex, baseline serum creatinine, age, electrocardiogram changes, heart failure or shock, diabetes, peripheral arterial disease, weight, systolic blood pressure, and home warfarin use. The risk model had good discrimination in the derivation (C statistic = 0.73) and validation (C statistic = 0.71) cohorts. Risk scores for major bleeding corresponded well to observed bleeding: very low risk (3.9%), low risk (7.3%), moderate risk (16.1%), high risk (29.0%), and very high risk (39.8%). In conclusion, the ACTIONRegistry-GWTG in-hospital major bleeding model uses variables at presentation to stratify major bleeding risk and provide risk-adjusted bleeding outcomes for quality improvement programs and clinical decision-making.

For initial and long-term treatment of acute coronary syndrome, combined anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy is more effective than antiplatelet therapy alone but is associated with an increased risk of bleeding. Antiplatelet therapy is often combined with oral anticoagulants in patients with indications for warfarin therapy (e.g., atrial fibrillation) who also have indications for antiplatelet therapy (e.g., coronary artery disease), but the appropriateness of this approach has not been determined Sure. For the long-term treatment of acute coronary syndrome and stroke and possibly peripheral arterial disease, anticoagulation appears to be as effective as antiplatelet therapy but can lead to more bleeding. Therefore, patients who develop atrial fibrillation may simply need to switch from antiplatelet therapy to anticoagulant therapy. For patients with prosthetic heart valves, the combination of anticoagulants and antiplatelet therapy has only been shown to provide additional benefit over anticoagulants alone. The combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is less effective than oral anticoagulants in patients with atrial fibrillation, while the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is more effective than oral anticoagulants in patients with coronary stents. Whether the benefits of triple therapy outweigh the risks in patients with atrial fibrillation and coronary stents requires randomized trials to evaluate.

Vascular disease is incorporated into risk scoring systems to predict stroke in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF). This ROCKET AF post hoc analysis was designed to determine the absolute incidence of stroke and bleeding and the relative effectiveness and safety of rivaroxaban versus warfarin in patients with and without peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Peripheral arterial disease was defined on the case report form as the presence of intermittent claudication, arterial insufficiency amputation, revascularization, bypass surgery, or percutaneous intervention of an extremity, or previously documented abdominal aortic aneurysm. ROCKET AF was a double-blind, double-dummy, randomized controlled trial comparing rivaroxaban and warfarin in the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism. A total of 839 (5.9%) patients in ROCKET AF had PAD. Patients with and without PAD had similar rates of stroke or systemic embolism [HR: 1.04, 95% CI (0.72, 1.50), P = 0.84] and major or non-major clinically relevant (NMCR) bleeding [HR: 1.11, 95% CI (0.96, 1.28), P = 0.17], respectively. Compared with warfarin, rivaroxaban was effective in preventing stroke or systemic disease in patients with PAD (HR: 1.19, 95% CI: 0.63-2.22) and in patients without PAD (HR: 0.86, 95% CI: 0.73-1.02). The efficacy of embolization is similar. There was a significant interaction between major bleeding or NMCR bleeding in PAD patients treated with rivaroxaban and warfarin (HR: 1.40, 95 % CI: 1.06-1.86); interaction P = 0.037). Patients with PAD in ROCKET AF did not have a statistically significantly increased risk of stroke or systemic embolism compared with patients without PAD, and patients treated with rivaroxaban and warfarin had similar efficacy outcomes. . Among patients with PAD, rivaroxaban was associated with a higher risk of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding compared with warfarin (P for interaction = 0.037). Further studies are needed to validate this subgroup analysis and determine optimal treatment for this high-risk AF patient population with PAD.

Management of warfarin therapy is complicated by the wide variation in drug response between patients. Variations in the gene encoding vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1) may influence response to warfarin. We conducted a retrospective study of European and American patients receiving long-term warfarin maintenance therapy. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to determine the effect of VKORC1 haplotypes on warfarin dose. We determined VKORC1 haplotype frequencies in African American, European American, and Asian American populations and VKORC1 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression in human liver samples. We identified 10 common noncoding VKORC1 SNPs and inferred 5 major haplotypes. We identified low-dose haplotype groups (A) and high-dose haplotype groups (B). The mean (+/-SE) maintenance dose of warfarin differed significantly among the three haplotype group combinations, with A/A being 2.7+/-0.2 mg daily and A/B being 4.9+/-0.2 mg daily. A/B is 6.2 mg per day. VKORC1 haplotype groups A and B explained approximately 25% of the dose variation. Asian Americans have a higher proportion of group A haplotypes, and African Americans have a higher proportion of group B haplotypes. VKORC1 mRNA levels vary according to haplotype combinations. VKORC1 haplotypes can be used to stratify patients into low-, medium-, and high-dose warfarin groups and may explain differences in dosage requirements between patients of different ancestry. The molecular mechanisms of this warfarin dose response appear to be regulated at the transcriptional level.

Coumarin derivatives, such as warfarin, are the therapies of choice for long-term treatment and prevention of thromboembolic events. Coumarin achieves coagulation by inhibiting the vitamin K epoxide reductase multiprotein complex (VKOR). This complex recycles vitamin K 2,3-epoxide into vitamin K hydroquinone, a cofactor critical for post-translational γ-carboxylation of multiple coagulation factors. Despite extensive efforts, the components of the VKOR complex have yet to be identified. This complex is thought to be involved in two human genetic disorders: vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor type 2 combined deficiency (VKCFD2; Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) 607473), and resistance to the coumarin anticoagulant drug (warfarin). Lin) resistance resistance, WR; OMIM 122700). Here, by using linked messages from three species, we identify the vitamin K epoxide reductase complex subunit 1 (VKORC1) gene, which encodes a small transmembrane protein of the endoplasmic reticulum. VKORC1 contains missense mutations in both human disease and warfarin-resistant rat strains. Overexpression of wild-type VKORC1, but not VKORC1 harboring the VKCFD2 mutation, results in a significant increase in VKOR activity that is sensitive to warfarin inhibition.

Current dosing algorithms do not take into account genetic and environmental factors in warfarin dosing determination. This study investigated the effects of age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and body size on warfarin dose requirements. The study population was 297 patients on stable anticoagulant therapy with a target international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0 to 3.0. Genetic analysis of CYP2C9 (*2 and *3 alleles) and VKORC1 (-1639 polymorphism) was performed, and venous INR and plasma R- and S-warfarin concentrations were determined. Patients with CYP2C9 homozygous wild-type had the highest mean daily warfarin dose requirements compared with patients with variant *2 and *3 alleles (P < .001) and were significantly more likely to have the VKORC1 (position -1639) GG genotype Compared with patients, warfarin has the highest daily dose requirements. Between ages 20 and 90 years, the average daily dose requirement for warfarin decreases by 0.5 to 0.7 mg per decade. Age, height, and CYP2C9 genotype had a significant effect on S-warfarin and total warfarin clearance, whereas only age and body size had a significant effect on R-warfarin clearance. Multivariable regression models including age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotypes, and height variables produced the best model for estimating warfarin dose (R2 = 55%). Based on these data, a new warfarin dosing regimen was developed. The effectiveness of the dosing regimen was confirmed in a second group of patients treated with warfarin.

The use of trial and error doses to initiate warfarin therapy is problematic. Our goal is to develop and validate pharmacogenetic algorithms. In a derivation cohort of 1,015 participants, independent predictors of treatment dose were: VKORC1 polymorphism -1639/3673 G>A (-28% for each allele), body surface area (BSA) (per 0.25 m (2) +11%), CYP2C9(*)3 (-33% per allele), CYP2C9(*)2 (-19% per allele), age (-7% per decade), target international normalized ratio (INR) (+11% per 0.5 unit increase), amiodarone use (-22%), smoking status (+10%), race (-9%), and current thrombosis (+7% ). This pharmacogenetic equation explained 53-54% of the variation in warfarin dose in the derivation and validation (N= 292) cohorts. For comparison, clinical equations explained only 17-22% of dose variability (P < 0.001). In the validation cohort, we prospectively used a pharmacogenetic dosing algorithm in patients initiating warfarin therapy, two of whom developed major bleeding. To promote the use of these pharmacogenetic and clinical algorithms, we have developed a non-profit website: http://www.WarfarinDosing.org.

Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying those individuals who are more vulnerable to harm from certain drugs. Routine adoption of pharmacogenetic testing requires demonstration of its cost-effectiveness. The purpose of this review is to systematically review published economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests designed to prevent or reduce the incidence of adverse effects. We conducted a systematic literature review on economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic trials aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms including pharmacogenetic testing, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluation and pharmaceuticals. Titles were independently screened by two reviewers. Articles deemed to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened by abstract, and the full text was reviewed. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met inclusion criteria. There is evidence to support the cost of HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58 testing Benefits: 01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19 (before clopidogrel treatment). Regarding TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptopristin, azathioprine and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (informing genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate) and factor V Leiden test (in oral contraceptives). It is not cost-effective to test A1555G before prescribing an aminoglycoside. Our systematic review found strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of genotyping prior to treatment with a number of common medications. However, further analysis and/or reliable clinical evidence is required before recommendations can be made for others.

This article summarizes discussions at the 3rd European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Biomedical Conference on Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, held in Spain in June 2010. Its focus is on practical applications in routine medical practice. We provide practical advice for ten different clinical situations that either have or have not been approved by regulatory agencies. We present some comments that may accompany the results of these tests, indicating optimal medications and dosages to prescribe. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, HLA-B*5701-flucloxacillin, SLCO1B1-statins, and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. We hope these practical recommendations will assist physicians, biologists, scientists, and other health care professionals in developing, performing, and interpreting these genetic tests.

Serious adverse drug reactions are the sixth leading cause of death in the United States and the leading cause of postmarketing drug withdrawals, costing billions of dollars annually in all developed countries. Some of these serious adverse drug reactions can be avoided through systematic screening of pharmacogenomic risk factors. Over the past few years, regulatory agencies have introduced pharmacogenomic labels for several drugs, but although a priori genetic testing is still recommended or recommended, it is rarely mandated due to a lack of evidence-based medicine knowledge. Recently published pharmacogenomic randomized, controlled and ongoing trials will progressively mandate genotyping testing for, for example, HLA-B*5701 (abacavir), TPMT (6-mercaptopurine), CYP2C9 plus VKORC1 (warfarin ) and CYP3A5 (tacrolimus) genotyping testing. Parallel developments in pharmacogenomic bed testing will certainly establish gene-based prescribing in routine medical practice.

Pharmacogenomics seeks to explain inter-individual variability in response to drugs due to genetic variation. Although technological advances have provided us with relatively simple and inexpensive genotyping methods, the promise of personalized medicine has not yet met our high expectations. Successes in pharmacogenomics to date include HLA-B*5701 screening to avoid allergy to the antiretroviral abacavir, thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) genotyping to avoid thiopurine toxicity, and CYP2C9 and CYP2C9 screening. However, there are few examples of pharmacogenetics that have been applied in clinical practice to treat complex diseases. Unfortunately, lack of reproducibility of findings from observational studies involving many genes and diseases appears to be a common pattern in pharmacogenomics research. In this article, we discuss some methodological and statistical issues in study design, gene and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) selection, and data analysis that should be considered in future pharmacogenomic studies. First, we discuss some issues related to the design of epidemiological studies, particularly pharmacogenomic studies. Second, we describe some of the advantages and disadvantages of candidate gene approaches (including gene and SNP selection) and genome-wide scanning approaches. Finally, traditional methods and several innovative methods for analyzing large pharmacogenomic datasets are presented, dealing with issues of multiplexing and systems biology in different ways.

Cytochrome P450 2C19 (CYP2C19) is a major (or partial) reason for the large variability in the pharmacokinetics of many clinically important drugs. Based on the ability to metabolize (S)-mephenytoin or other CYP2C19 substrates, individuals are classified as extensive metabolizers (EM) or poor metabolizers (PM). Eight variant alleles (CYP2C19*2 to CYP2C19*8) that predict PM have been identified. The distribution of EM and PM genotypes and phenotypes showed extensive interethnic differences. Non-genetic factors such as enzyme inhibition and induction, aging, and cirrhosis can also modulate CYP2C19 activity. In EM, approximately 80% of doses of the proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) omeprazole, lansoprazole, and pantoprazole appear to be cleared by CYP2C19, whereas CYP3A is more important in PM. Five-fold higher exposure to these drugs was observed in PM for CYP2C19 than in EM, and a further increase occurred during inhibition of alternative metabolic pathways catalyzed by CYP3A in PM. Thus, PMs of CYP2C19 experienced more effective acid suppression and better duodenal and gastric ulcer healing during omeprazole and lansoprazole treatment compared with EMs. The pharmacoeconomic value of CYP2C19 genotyping remains unclear. Our calculations suggest that CYP2C19 genotyping would save approximately $5000 per 100 Asians tested but not for white patients. However, genotyping common alleles of CYP2C19 before initiating PPI therapy for reflux and H. pylori infection is a cost-effective tool to determine appropriate treatment duration and dosing regimen. Alterations in CYP2C19 activity do not appear to increase the risk of adverse drug reactions/proton pump inhibitor interactions. Phenytoin plasma concentrations and toxicity have been shown to be increased in patients taking CYP2C19 inhibitors or with variant alleles, and due to its narrow therapeutic range, genotyping for CYP2C19 in addition to CYP2C9 may be required to optimize phenytoin dosage . The risk of toxicity from tricyclic antidepressants may be increased in patients with reduced CYP2C19 and/or CYP2D6 activity. CYP2C19 is the primary enzyme responsible for the activation of proguanil to cycloguanil, but there are no clinical data to suggest that PM of CYP2C19 poses a greater risk of malaria prophylaxis or treatment failure. Diazepam clearance is significantly reduced in PM or when CYP2C19 inhibitors are used concomitantly, but the clinical consequences are usually minimal. Finally, many studies have attempted to determine the relationship between CYP2C19 genotype and phenotype and susceptibility to xenobiotic-induced disease, but these have been unconvincing.

Voriconazole is the treatment of choice for zoomycosis and a new treatment option for candidiasis. Hepatic disease, age, genetic polymorphisms in cytochrome CYP2C19, and drugs can affect the metabolism of voriconazole. Large changes in voriconazole pharmacokinetics may be associated with reduced efficacy or toxicity. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the utility of measuring voriconazole blood concentrations with personalized dose adjustment. A total of 181 high-pressure liquid chromatography measurements were performed on 52 patients over 2388 treatment days. Wide variation in voriconazole plasma trough concentrations was observed, ranging from < or = 1 mg/L in 25% of cases (the lowest inhibitory concentration to which 90% of isolates are susceptible for most fungal pathogens) to > 5.5 mg/L. L (a level potentially associated with toxicity) was present in 31% of cases. Lack of response to treatment was more common in patients with voriconazole concentrations < or = 1 mg/L (6 of 13 patients [46%], 5 of whom had aspergillosis, 4 of whom received a median dose Oral therapy was 6 mg/L. After increasing the voriconazole dose, blood concentrations reached >1 mg/L, and the infection resolved completely in 5 of 16 patients with voriconazole trough blood concentrations >5.5 mg/L. (31%) developed encephalopathy in 4 patients receiving intravenous voriconazole at a median dose of 8 mg/kg per day, whereas no patients developed encephalopathy at doses < or = 5.5 mg/L (P=.002). Concomitant use of meprazole may have resulted in the accumulation of voriconazole in 4 patients. In all cases, discontinuation of treatment resulted in rapid and complete neurologic recovery. Voriconazole therapeutic drug monitoring improves the efficacy and safety of severely ill patients with invasive fungal diseases. .

Many drugs, including proton pump inhibitors and certain antidepressants, are metabolized by the polymorphic cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2C19 enzyme. There is a large proportion of extensive metabolizers that do not reach appropriate drug levels and we aimed to investigate any genetic background. The 5' flanking region of the CYP2C19 gene was sequenced in subjects who were rapid metabolizers of omeprazole, and CYP2C19 phenotype-genotype associations were analyzed in Swedish (n = 107) and Ethiopian (n = 126) crude metabolizers. The relationship between the metabolic ratio of omeprazole (omeprazole/5-hydroxyomeprazole in plasma 3 hours after dosing) and the area under the blood concentration-time curve was used for prediction studies. Electrophoretic mobility shift assay using human nuclear protein extracts. Liver reporter vector transfection in CD1 mice. We found a novel allele (CYP2C19*17) carrying -806C>T and -3402C>T, with a frequency of 18% in Swedes and Ethiopians and 18% in Chinese subjects. The frequency is 4%. In Sweden, the rate of omeprazole metabolism in subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.50 [interquartile range, 0.37-0.73]) was higher than that of subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median , 0.25 [interquartile range, 0.15-0.33]). In Ethiopians, there was a significant difference in CYP2C19*1 homozygous individuals (median, 0.20 [interquartile range, 0.12-0.37]) and CYP2C19*17 homozygous individuals (median, 0.05 [interquartile range, 0.12-0.37]). Similar differences in the S/R-mephenytoin ratio were observed between 0.12 and 0.37]. Electrophoretic mobility shift analysis showed that human liver nuclear protein specifically binds to elements carrying -806T but not -806C. Reporter vector experiments show increased transcriptional activity of the CYP2C19*17 allele in mice. Predictions indicate that CYP2C19*17 homozygotes will have a 35% to 40% decrease in the omeprazole area under the plasma concentration-time curve value compared to CYP2C19*1 homozygotes taking standard doses of omeprazole. CYP2C19*17 may cause failure of medical treatments such as proton pump inhibitors and antidepressants.

Human CYP2C is an important subfamily of P450 enzymes that metabolize approximately 20% of clinically used drugs. There are four members of this subfamily: CYP2C8, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, and CYP2C18. Among them, CYP2C8, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19 are of clinical importance. CYP2C also metabolizes some endogenous compounds such as arachidonic acid. Each member of this subfamily has been found to be genetically polymorphic. The best known of these polymorphisms is CYP2C19. CYP2C19 poor metabolizers (PMs) occur in approximately 3-5% of Caucasians, similar proportions in African Americans, and 12-100% in Asians. This polymorphism affects the metabolism of the anticonvulsant mephenytoin, proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole, the anti-anxiety drug diazepam, certain antidepressants, and the antimalarial drug proguanil. PM exposure to diazepam may produce toxic effects, and some proton pump inhibitors may be more effective against PM than EM when these drugs are used at low doses. There are many mutant alleles that can be detected through genetic testing. CYP2C9 metabolizes a variety of drugs, including the anticoagulant warfarin, antidiabetic drugs such as tolbutamide, anticonvulsants such as phenytoin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The incidence of functional polymorphisms is much lower, estimated at 1/250 in Caucasians and lower in Asians. However, the clinical consequences of these rare polymorphisms can be severe. Serious and life-threatening bleeding events have been reported with CYP2C9 PM exposed to warfarin. Phenytoin has been reported to cause severe toxicity in PM. Novel polymorphisms discovered in CYP2C8, which metabolizes paclitaxel (paclitaxel). Genetic testing is available for all known CYP2C variant alleles.

Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying those individuals who are more vulnerable to harm from certain drugs. Routine adoption of pharmacogenetic testing requires demonstration of its cost-effectiveness. The purpose of this review is to systematically review published economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests designed to prevent or reduce the incidence of adverse effects. We conducted a systematic literature review on economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic trials aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. The literature was searched using Embase, MEDLINE and the NHS Economic Evaluation Database with search terms including pharmacogenetic testing, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluation and pharmaceuticals. Titles were independently screened by two reviewers. Articles deemed to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened by abstract, and the full text was reviewed. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met inclusion criteria. There is evidence to support the cost of HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58 testing Benefits: 01 (before allopurinol) and CYP2C19 (before clopidogrel treatment). Regarding TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptopristin, azathioprine and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (informing genotype-guided dosing of coumarin derivatives), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate) and factor V Leiden test (in oral contraceptives). It is not cost-effective to test A1555G before prescribing an aminoglycoside. Our systematic review found strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of genotyping prior to treatment with a number of common medications. However, further analysis and/or reliable clinical evidence is required before recommendations can be made for others.

This article summarizes discussions at the 3rd European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Biomedical Conference on Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, held in Spain in June 2010. Its focus is on practical applications in routine medical practice. We provide practical advice for ten different clinical situations that either have or have not been approved by regulatory agencies. We present some comments that may accompany the results of these tests, indicating optimal medications and dosages to prescribe. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, HLA-B*5701-flucloxacillin, SLCO1B1-statins, and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. During HIV infection and/or antiviral treatment (ART), monocytes and macrophages exhibit multiple dysfunctions that have significant implications for HIV pathogenesis and treatment-related complications. However, the molecular components responsible for these dysfunctions remain elusive. Therefore, we applied a parallel approach of whole-genome microarray analysis and focused gene expression profiling on monocytes from patients at different stages of HIV infection and/or ART to further characterize these dysfunctions. Processes involving apoptosis, cell cycle, lipid metabolism, proteasome function, protein trafficking, and transcriptional regulation have been identified as areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection. The individual genes that may contribute to these monocyte dysfunctions include several novel factors. One of these is the adipocytokine NAMPT/visfatin, which we show is capable of suppressing HIV during early stages of the HIV life cycle. Under ART, approximately half of the identified genes returned to control levels, whereas other genes showed persistent dysregulation. In addition, several candidate biomarkers for the development of abacavir hypersensitivity reactions have been proposed (particularly CCL1 and CYP2C19). Previously described areas of monocyte dysfunction during HIV infection were confirmed and novel themes identified. Additionally, individual genes associated with these dysfunctions and ART-related diseases were identified. These genes provide a useful basis for further functional studies on the contribution of monocytes/macrophages to HIV pathogenesis. One of the genes, NAMPT/visfatin, represents a possible novel HIV restriction factor.

Pharmacogenomic studies help us understand individual differences in response to antiretroviral drugs. Genetic polymorphisms in the major histocompatibility complex gene predict the likelihood of allergic reactions in patients taking abacavir or nevirapine. Recent studies have shown that polymorphisms in the CYP2B6 gene are associated with higher efavirenz plasma concentrations and increased efavirenz CNS side effects. Polymorphisms in the MDR1 gene encoding the drug pump P-glycoprotein predict nevirapine-related hepatotoxicity and long-term virological response to efavirenz. CYP2C19 polymorphisms predict nelfinavir plasma levels and may predict the risk of virological failure of this drug. European mitochondrial haplogroups may predict increased risk of peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors. Expanded and refined knowledge about the association between human genetics and antiretroviral drug response may ultimately allow for personalized treatment based on genotyping. This article summarizes a presentation on HIV treatment and pharmacogenomics given by David W. Haas, MD, at the International AIDS Society U.S. course held in Atlanta in March 2005.

Several long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) are natural ligands of nonruminant peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ (PPARG), which is upregulated in lactating bovine mammary tissue along with its lipogenic target genes. Therefore, PPARG may represent an important control point for milk fat synthesis. We tested the adipogenesis of 19 genes in bovine mammary epithelial cells cultured with 16:0, 18:0, cis-9 18:1, trans-10 18:1, trans-10, cis-12 18 by quantitative PCR. Gene network expression: 2 [t10c12 conjugated linolenic acid (CLA)], 20:5, ethanol (control), and PPARG agonist rosiglitazone (ROSI). Triplicate cultures were maintained with 50 muM ROSI or 100 muM LCFA for 12 h. Relative to control, common responses for 16:0 and 18:0 included significant expression of INSIG1 (+298%, +92%), AGPAT6 (+137%, +169%), FABP3 (+755%, +338%) increased) and FABP4 (+171%, 157%). These were combined with greater intracellular lipid droplet formation and mRNA for ACSS2, LPIN1, SCD, and SREBF2 in response to 16:0 and greater DGAT1 and THRSP in response to 18:0. Trans-10 18:1 and t10c12 CLA reduced the expression of FASN (-60%, -31%), SCD (-100%, -357%), and SREBF1 (-49%, -189%). Furthermore, t10c12 CLA downregulates ACSS2, FABP3, INSIG1, SREBF2, and THRSP expression. SREBF1 expression was lower in cis-9 18:1 (-140%) and 20:5 (-125%) compared to controls. The latter LCFA also reduced SCD, SREBF2, and LPL expression. No effects of LCFA or ROSI on PPARG were observed, but ROSI upregulated the expression of ACACA, FASN, LPIN1, AGPAT6, DGAT1, SREBF1, SREBF2, and INSIG1 (+39% to +269%). Therefore, these genes are putative PPARG target genes in bovine mammary cells. This is the first report showing a direct effect of trans-10 18:1 on lipogenic gene expression in bovine mammary cells. Coordinated upregulation of the adipogenic gene network in response to ROSI and saturated LCFA provides support for PPARG activation regulating bovine milk fat synthesis.

Signaling by the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ (PPAR-γ) is a determinant of insulin sensitivity in adipose tissue, muscle, liver, and macrophages, and this receptor mediates Insulin-sensitizing effects of thiazolidinediones (TZDs). Because PPAR-γ is also expressed in neurons, we generated neuron-specific Pparg knockout (Pparg brain knockout (BKO)) mice to determine whether neuronal PPAR-γ signaling contributes to weight gain or Insulin sensitivity. During high-fat diet (HFD) feeding, Pparg-BKO mice had reduced food intake and increased energy expenditure compared with Pparg(f/f) mice, resulting in reduced weight gain. Pparg-BKO mice also responded better to leptin administration than Pparg(f/f) mice. When treated with the TZD rosiglitazone, Pparg-BKO mice were resistant to rosiglitazone-induced hyperphagia and weight gain and were significantly more resistant to rosiglitazone-treated Pparg(f/f) mice relative to rosiglitazone-treated Pparg(f/f) mice. Glucose metabolism improved only slightly. Hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp studies demonstrated that the increase in hepatic insulin sensitivity induced by rosiglitazone treatment during HFD feeding was completely abolished in Pparg-BKO mice, an effect consistent with the failure of rosiglitazone to improve hepatic insulin sensitivity. Related to body signal transduction. We conclude that excessive weight gain induced by HFD feeding depends in part on neuronal PPAR-γ signaling that limits thermogenesis and increases food intake. The hepatic insulin-sensitizing effects of TZDs also require neuronal PPAR-γ signaling.

The nuclear hormone receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARγ) is an important regulator of lipid and glucose homeostasis as well as cell differentiation. In vitro and in vivo studies in many cell types have shown that activation of PPARγ reduces cell proliferation. We show here that activation of PPARγ is sufficient to reduce proliferation of cultured insulinoma cell lines. We created a mouse model in which expression of the PPARG gene in β cells was eliminated (βγ KO mice) and found that these mice had significant islet hyperplasia after eating food. Interestingly, the normal expansion of beta cell mass that occurs in control mice with high-fat feeding was significantly attenuated in these animals. Despite this change in β-cell mass, no effect on glucose homeostasis was found in βγ KO mice. Furthermore, although thiazolidinediones enhanced insulin secretion from cultured wild-type islets, administration of rosiglitazone to insulin-resistant control mice and βγ KO mice showed that PPARγ in β cells is not resistant to these compounds. Necessary for the action of diabetes. These data demonstrate a critical physiological role for PPARγ function in β-cell proliferation and also show that the mechanisms controlling β-cell proliferation in obesity are distinct from those regulating baseline cell mass in islets.

Nocturnin (NOC) is a circadian regulatory protein related to a family of yeast transcription factors involved in cellular responses to nutritional status. In mammals, NOC acts as a deadenylase but lacks a transcriptional activation domain. It is highly expressed in bone marrow stromal cells (BMSC), hepatocytes, and adipocytes. Noc expression was enhanced 30-fold in BMSCs exposed to the PPAR-γ (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ) agonist rosiglitazone. Previously, we reported that Noc(-/-) mice are hypothermic, are not affected by diet-induced obesity, and, most importantly, exhibit a loss of Pparg circadian rhythms on a high-fat diet. Consistent with its effect on BMSC allocation, Noc(-/-) mice had reduced bone marrow fat and increased bone mass. Likewise, NOC overexpression enhanced adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 cells but negatively regulated osteogenesis in MC3T3-E1 cells. NOC and its mutant forms lacking deadenylase activity bind to PPAR-gamma and significantly enhance PPAR-gamma transcriptional activity. Both WT and mutant NOC promote nuclear translocation of PPAR-γ. Importantly, NOC-mediated nuclear translocation of PPAR-γ is blocked by short peptide fragments of NOC, thereby inhibiting its physical interaction with PPAR-γ. This inhibitory effect of NOC peptides was partially reversed by rosiglitazone, suggesting that the effect of NOC on PPAR-γ nuclear translocation may be independent of ligand-mediated PPAR-γ activation. In summary, Noc regulates PPAR-gamma activity through nuclear translocation and plays a unique role in the regulation of mesenchymal stem cell lineage allocation. These data illustrate the unique mechanisms by which nutrient-responsive genes influence bone marrow mesenchymal stem cell differentiation, adipogenesis, and ultimately body composition.

In this study, we sought to test the hypothesis that genetic factors may influence the antidepressant response to fluoxetine. The study focused on seven candidate genes in the serotonin pathway involved in serotonin synthesis, transport, recognition, and degradation. Our clinical sample consisted of 96 subjects with unipolar major depression treated with fluoxetine, and response variables were assessed after a 12-week trial. Patient data are also collected to study drug response patterns. Using a high-throughput single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping platform and capillary electrophoresis, we characterized 110 SNPs located in 7 candidate genes (HTR1A, HTR2A, HTR2C, MAOA, SLC6A4, TPH1, and TPH2) and Four patients with repeat polymorphisms were genotyped. Statistical tests performed included single-locus and haplotype association tests and linkage disequilibrium (LD) estimates. Using a genomic control procedure, little evidence of population stratification was observed in samples with 20 random SNPs. Our most interesting results involve 3 SNPs in the TPH1 gene and 1 SNP in the SLC6A4 gene, which showed significant single-site associations when response to fluoxetine was compared with no response (P=0.02-0.04) . All odds ratios showed an increased risk of nonresponse to fluoxetine. In the comparison of specific response with non-specific and no response, 3 SNPs in the TPH2 gene (P=0.02-0.04) were positively correlated, and 1 SNP in the HTR2A gene (P=0.02) was negatively correlated. When comparing specific and nonspecific responses, we found significant negative correlations for three SNPs in the HTR2A gene (P=0.001-0.03) and two SNPs in the MAOA gene (P=0.03-0.05). We observed variability within each gene, although LD was strong and the estimated number of haplotypes formed by the tagged SNPs was unexpectedly low. Significant haplotype associations were found for all genes except HTR1A and HTR2C genes. Although these data should be interpreted with caution due to the small sample size, these results suggest that TPH1 and SLC6A4 are involved in the general response, whereas HTR2A, TPH2, and MAOA are involved in the specific response to fluoxetine. Interestingly, we observed that some of the less common alleles of many SNP markers were associated with unresponsive and nonspecific phenotypes.

The serotonin transporter is a molecular target of many antidepressant drugs, and the gene encoding this protein (SLC6A4) has been implicated in response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). We sought to further test the hypothesis that SLC6A4 is involved in SSRI response by resequencing the SLC6A4 gene in subjects with major depression. The sequences of all exons, parts of all introns, and the promoter region containing a polymorphic repeat polymorphism previously associated with SSRI response (HTTLPR) were determined in 96 subjects, and the variants were tested with Correlates of response to treatment with fluoxetine. We screened a total of 712 KB of sequence and identified 27 SLC6A4 variants, 21 of which have not been previously described. There are 17 on each chromosome, including three of the five exonic variants. A polymorphism (rs25531) upstream of HTTLPR showed evidence of an association with treatment response, and biochemical experiments showed that this polymorphism altered the binding of nuclear extracts to a consensus sequence of the activin 2 transcription factor, which is thought to regulate Key factors in mammalian neural gene expression. These results support an association between SSRI response and DNA variation in the serotonin transporter locus. We also identified a potentially important functional variant that contributes to this association, as well as a biological mechanism that may mediate its effect.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by recurring distressing intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors or mental activities that one feels compelled to perform (compulsions). Obsessive-compulsive disorder has a partial genetic basis. For the treatment of obsessive-compulsive disorder, effective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) drugs (clomipramine (Anafranil), fluvoxamine (Luvox), fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft), and Roxetine (Paxil)) acts on the serotonin transporter, including uniquely effective. Polymorphisms in the promoter region of the gene encoding this protein (SLC6A4) were recently reported to affect protein expression and to be associated with measures of anxiety, depression, and autism (designed using a family-controlled Transmission Disequilibrium Test (TDT)). Thus, SLC6A4 has strong a priori support for potentially influencing OCD risk: the protein it encodes is a drug target; genetic polymorphisms influence function; and polymorphisms have been shown to correlate with behavioral phenotypes. We used TDT with a set of 34 European-American family trios (30 unrelated and 4 from extended pedigrees) to test for linkage disequilibrium between alleles at the OCD and SLC6A4 promoter polymorphic sites. Of the 35 heterozygous parents, 24 inherited the “l” SLC6A4 allele and 11 inherited the “s” allele (chi 2 TDT = 4.83; P < 0.03). Considering only the 13 SRI drug nonresponders, there were 13 heterozygous parents, 10 of whom inherited the “l” allele and 3 who inherited the “s” allele (chi 2 TDT = 3.77; P < 0.052). These data provide preliminary support for an association and linkage disequilibrium between the SLC6A4 'l' allele and OCD.

Key findings from recent studies of SLC6A4 and its corresponding protein, serotonin (5-HT) transporter (SERT), in humans, rodents, and nonhuman primates indicate that SLC6A4 noncoding 5', 3' UTRs and Combinations of intronic regions plus coding variants act together to alter 5HT transport up to 40-fold in vitro. In vivo, SLC6A4 variants in humans and other species cause significant physiological changes, albeit attenuated neurodevelopmental adaptations of 5-HT receptors and compensatory alterations in 5-HT synthesis and metabolism. Polymorphisms in SLC6A4 are associated with differences in mood, endocrine and personality traits, as well as many diseases. However, the combination of this gene with gene × gene (G × G) and gene × environment (G × E) interactions is still not fully understood, and some association findings remain controversial. Given its primary importance in the regulation and function of the entire serotonergic system, as demonstrated by the consequences of reuptake inhibition mediated by SRIs such as fluoxetine in humans and by genetically engineered alterations in mice and rats ), SLC6A4 and SERT seem likely to be important in our field's attempts to better understand and treat 5-HT-related diseases, which remains an area of ​​great interest.

Hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir are strongly associated with the presence of the HLA-B*5701 allele. This study aimed to determine the effectiveness of prospective HLA-B*5701 screening in preventing allergic reactions to abacavir. The double-blind, prospective, randomized study involved 1956 patients from 19 countries who were infected with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 and had not previously received abacavir. We randomly assigned patients to undergo prospective HLA-B*5701 screening, excluding HLA-B*5701-positive patients who received abacavir (prospective screening group), or to receive abacavir with standard care but No prospective screening is performed. All patients starting abacavir were observed for 6 weeks. To immunologically confirm and enhance the specificity of clinical diagnosis of allergic reactions to abacavir, we performed epidermal patch testing with abacavir. The prevalence of HLA-B*5701 was 5.6% (109 of 1956 patients). Among patients treated with abacavir, 72% were male, 84% were white, and 18% had not received prior antiviral therapy. Screening eliminated immunologically confirmed hypersensitivity reactions (0% in the prospective screening group and 2.7% in the control group, P < 0.001), with a negative predictive value of 100% and a positive predictive value of 47.9%. Hypersensitivity reactions were clinically diagnosed in 93 patients, and the incidence rate in the prospective screening group (3.4%) was significantly lower than that in the control group (7.8%) (P<0.001). HLA-B*5701 screening reduces the risk of allergic reactions to abacavir. In a predominantly white population, similar to the present study, 94% of patients who did not carry the HLA-B*5701 allele were at low risk for allergic reactions to abacavir. Our results suggest that pharmacogenetic testing can be used to prevent specific toxic effects of drugs. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00340080.)

The use of abacavir, a potent HIV-1 nucleoside analog reverse transcriptase inhibitor, is complicated by the development of a potentially life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome in approximately 5% of cases. Genetic factors that influence the immune response to abacavir may contribute to susceptibility. We aimed to search for associations between MHC alleles and abacavir hypersensitivity in HIV-1-positive individuals receiving abacavir. MHC region typing was performed on the first 200 Western Australian HIV cohort study participants exposed to abacavir. Abacavir allergy was confirmed in 18 patients, and 167 patients with exposure to the drug for more than 6 weeks (abacavir tolerance) were excluded. Fifteen people experienced some symptoms but did not meet abacavir allergy criteria. The p-value is corrected for comparisons of multiple HLA alleles (p(c)) by multiplying the original p-value by the estimated number of HLA alleles present within the locus examined. HLA-B*5701 was present in 14 of 18 (78%) abacavir-allergic patients and in 4 (2%) of 167 abacavir-resistant patients (odds ratio 117 [95% CI 29-481], p(c )<0.0001), and the HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 combination was found in 13 (72%) allergic patients and 5 (3%) tolerant patients (73 [ 20-268], p(c)<0.0001). HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 were combined in 13 (72%) allergic patients but not in any tolerant patients (822 [43-15 675], p(c)<0.0001). Other MHC markers are also present on the 57.1 ancestral haplotype to which the above three markers belong, confirming the existence of haplotype-specific linkage disequilibrium and locating potential susceptibility loci bounded by C4A6 and HLA-C Area. In the entire abacavir-exposed cohort (n=200), the presence of HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 had a positive predictive value of 100% and a negative predictive value of 97% for hypersensitivity reactions. Genetic susceptibility to abacavir hypersensitivity is carried by the 57.1 ancestral haplotype. In our population, discontinuation of abacavir in patients with HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 should reduce the prevalence of hypersensitivity reactions from 9% to 2.5% without inappropriate rejection Use abacavir in any patient.

Approximately 4% of patients receiving abacavir to treat HIV-1 infection are allergic to abacavir. We performed a retrospective case-control study to identify multiple markers near HLA-B that are associated with hypersensitivity reactions. HLA-B57 was present in 39 of 84 patients (46%) compared with 4 of 113 controls (4%) (p<0 small midpoint 0001). However, these findings relate primarily to white men due to lower enrollment of women and other ethnic groups. The sensitivity of HLA-B57 found in this study to predict abacavir hypersensitivity was lower compared with previous reports, highlighting that the predictive value of the marker varies among populations. Clinical monitoring and management of hypersensitivity reactions in patients receiving abacavir must remain unchanged.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLAs) are highly polymorphic proteins that initiate immunity by presenting pathogen-derived peptides to T cells. HLA polymorphisms map primarily to the antigen-binding cleft, diversifying the autologous and pathogen-derived peptide antigen repertoire selected by different HLA allotypes. An increasing number of immunologically based drug reactions, including abacavir hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS) and carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), are associated with specific HLA alleles . However, little is known about the underlying mechanisms of these associations, including the relative risk of AHS, a classic HLA-related drug reaction that occurs only in individuals with a common histocompatibility allele HLA-B*57:01 More than 1,000 (Refs 6, 7). We show that unmodified abacavir binds non-covalently to HLA-B*57:01, located at the base of the antigen-binding cleft and into the F pocket, where the carboxyl-terminal tryptophan normally anchors peptides bound to HLA-B *57:01. Abacavir binds to HLA-B*57:01 with precise specificity, changing the shape and chemistry of the antigen-binding cleft, thereby altering the repertoire of endogenous peptides that bind HLA-B*57:01. In this way, abacavir guides the selection of new endogenous peptides, inducing significant changes in the "immunology itself." The resulting peptide-centered "altered self" activates abacavir-specific T cells, thereby driving polyclonal CD8 T cell activation and systemic responses manifesting as AHS. We also found that carbamazepine, a widely used antiepileptic drug associated with hypersensitivity reactions in HLA-B*15:02 individuals, binds to this allotype, resulting in changes in the self-peptide repertoire presented. Our results simultaneously highlight the importance of HLA polymorphisms in the evolution of pharmacogenomics and provide a general mechanism for the growing number of HLA-related hypersensitivity reactions involving small molecule drugs.

Advances in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia, particularly with tyrosine kinase inhibitors, require periodic updates in concepts and management. The European LeukemiaNet expert group reviewed previous and new research to update recommendations made in 2009. Efficacy was assessed at 3, 6, and 12 months by standardized true quantitative polymerase chain reaction and/or cytogenetics. BCR-ABL1 transcript levels ≤10% at 3 months, <1% at 6 months, and ≤0.1% after 12 months were defined as best response, whereas >10% at 6 months and >1% after 12 months Defined as failure, mandatory treatment change. Likewise, partial cytogenetic response (PCyR) at 3 months and complete cytogenetic response (CCyR) at 6 months defined optimal response, whereas no CyR at 3 months (Philadelphia chromosome positive [Ph+]> 95%), less than the PCyR at 6 months, and less than the CCyR from 12 months onwards was defined as failure. Between optimal and failure, there is an intermediate warning zone that requires more frequent monitoring. Similar definitions are provided for response to second-line therapy. Specific recommendations are made for patients in accelerated phase and blast phase and for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Best responders should continue treatment indefinitely with careful monitoring, or they could participate in controlled studies with discontinuation of treatment once a deeper molecular response is achieved.

Although the role of hedgehog (Hh) signaling in embryonic patterning is well established, its functions in adult tissue renewal and maintenance remain unclear, and the relationship of these functions to cancer development has not been established. Here, we show that loss of Smoothened (Smo), an important component of the Hh pathway, impairs hematopoietic stem cell turnover and reduces induction of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) by the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein. Loss of Smo leads to depletion of CML stem cells (the cells that propagate leukemia), whereas persistently active Smo increases the number of CML stem cells and accelerates disease progression. As a possible mechanism of Smo action, we found that the cell fate determinant Numb is increased in depleted CML stem cells in the absence of Smo activity. Furthermore, pharmacological inhibition of Hh signaling impairs not only the dissemination of wild-type BCR-ABL1-driven CML but also the growth of imatinib-resistant mouse and human CML. These data demonstrate that Hh pathway activity is required for the maintenance of normal hematopoietic and cancer stem cells and raise the possibility of avoiding drug resistance and disease relapse associated with imatinib treatment of CML by targeting this important stem cell maintenance pathway. sex.

Considerable variability exists in the level of molecular response achieved by patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) treated with imatinib. These differences may be due to differential treatment compliance. Eighty-seven patients with chronic-phase CML treated with imatinib 400 mg/d for a median of 59.7 months (range, 25 to 104 months) who had achieved complete cytogenetic response had adherence monitored during a 3-month period by using a microelectronic monitoring Device. Compliance is related to the degree of molecular response. Other factors that may have affected the results were also analyzed. Median compliance rate was 98% (range, 24% to 104%). Compliance was < or = 90% in 23 patients (26.4%); 12 of these patients (14%) had compliance ≤80%. There is a strong correlation between adherence rates (< or = 90% or > 90%) and the odds of a 3-log reduction at 6 years (also known as major molecular response [MMR]) in BCR-ABL1 transcripts ( 28.4 % v 94.5%; P < .001) and complete molecular response (CMR; 0% v 43.8%; P = .002). Multivariate analysis identified compliance (relative risk [RR], 11.7; P = .001) and expression of human organic cation transporter 1 molecule (RR, 1.79; P = .038) as the only independent predictors of MMR. Adherence was the only independent predictor of CMR. No molecular response was observed when compliance was < or = 80% (P < .001). Patients with increased doses of imatinib had poorer compliance (86.4%). In the latter group, adherence was the only independent predictor of failure to achieve MMR (RR, 17.66; P = .006). In CML patients who have been treated with imatinib for many years, poor compliance may be a major reason for failure to achieve adequate molecular responses.

Imatinib is a selective BCR-ABL1 kinase inhibitor that improves outcomes in patients with chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). We performed an efficacy and safety analysis of patients with CML who were followed for more than 10 years with imatinib as initial therapy. In this open-label, multicenter trial with a crossover design, we randomly assigned patients with newly diagnosed chronic-phase CML to receive either imatinib or interferon alfa plus cytarabine. Long-term analyzes included overall survival, treatment response, and serious adverse events. Median follow-up time was 10.9 years. Given the high crossover rate among patients randomly assigned to receive interferon alfa plus cytarabine (65.6%) and the short duration of treatment before crossover among these patients (median 0.8 years), the current The analysis focused on patients who received interferon alfa combined with cytarabine. The estimated 10-year overall survival rate for patients in the imatinib group was 83.3%. Approximately half of the patients (48.3%) randomized to imatinib completed study treatment with imatinib, and 82.8% achieved a complete cytogenetic response. Researchers believe serious adverse events related to imatinib are uncommon and most common during the first year of treatment. Nearly 11 years of follow-up showed that the efficacy of imatinib persisted over time and that long-term imatinib administration was not associated with unacceptable cumulative or late toxic effects. (Funded by Novartis; IRIS ClinicalTrials.gov numbers: NCT00006343 and NCT00333840.).

The HER2 gene encoding the growth factor receptor HER2 is amplified and is overexpressed in 25% to 30% of breast cancers, increasing tumor aggressiveness. We evaluated the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab, a recombinant monoclonal antibody directed against HER2, in women with metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We randomly assigned 234 patients to receive standard chemotherapy alone and 235 patients to receive standard chemotherapy plus trastuzumab. Patients who had not previously received adjuvant (postoperative) anthracycline therapy received doxorubicin (or epirubicin, 36 women) and cyclophosphamide alone (138 women) or trastuzumab (143 women) treatment. Patients who had received prior adjuvant anthracycline therapy received paclitaxel alone (96 women) or paclitaxel plus trastuzumab (92 women). Adding trastuzumab to chemotherapy was associated with longer time to disease progression (median 7.4 months vs. 4.6 months; P<0.001) and higher objective response rate (50% vs. 32%, P<0.001). 0.001) and longer relief time. Longer survival (median survival, 25.1 months vs. 20.3 months; P=0.01) was associated with a 20% reduction in the risk of death. The most important adverse event was New York Heart Association class III or IV cardiac dysfunction, which occurred in 27% of patients in the group receiving anthracyclines, cyclophosphamide, and trastuzumab; 8 % received anthracyclines and cyclophosphamide alone; 13% received paclitaxel and trastuzumab; and 1% received paclitaxel alone. Although cardiotoxicity can be severe and in some cases life-threatening, symptoms usually improve with standard medical management. Trastuzumab increases the clinical benefit of first-line chemotherapy in HER2-overexpressing metastatic breast cancer.

Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody directed against human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2; also known as ERBB2), is being studied in combination with chemotherapy as first-line treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. ToGA (Trastuzumab in Gastric Cancer) was an open-label, international phase 3 randomized controlled trial conducted at 122 centers in 24 countries. Patients with gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer were eligible if their tumors showed overexpression of HER2 protein by immunohistochemistry or fluorescent in situ hybridization gene amplification. Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive a chemotherapy regimen of capecitabine plus cisplatin or fluorouracil plus cisplatin, given every 3 weeks for six cycles, or chemotherapy plus intravenous trastuzumab. Allocation was by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group block randomization stratified by performance status, chemotherapy regimen, disease extent, primary cancer site, and disease measurability, implemented through a central interactive voice recognition system. The primary endpoint was overall survival among all randomized patients who received at least one dose of study drug. The trial is registered with ClinicalTrials.gov, number NCT01041404. 594 patients were randomly assigned to receive study treatment (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, n=298; chemotherapy alone, n=296), of whom 584 were included in the primary analysis (n=294; n=290). Median follow-up was 18.6 months (IQR 11-25) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 17.1 months (9-25) in the chemotherapy-alone group. Median overall survival was 13.8 months (95% CI 12-16) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 11.1 months (10-13) in the chemotherapy alone group (hazard ratio 0.74 ;95% CI 0.60-0.91; p= 0.0046). The most common adverse events in both groups were nausea (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, 197 [67%] vs chemotherapy alone, 184 [63%]), vomiting (147 [50%] vs 134 [46%]), and leukopenia (157 [53%] vs. 165 [57%]). The rates of overall grade 3 or 4 adverse events (201 [68%] vs. 198 [68%]) and cardiac adverse events (17 [6%] vs. 18 [6%]) were higher among groups. There is no difference between them. Trastuzumab plus chemotherapy may be considered a new standard option for patients with HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. F. Hofmann-LaRoche.

We present combined results from two trials comparing adjuvant chemotherapy with or without trastuzumab in women with surgically removed HER2-positive breast cancer. The National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Program trial B-31 compared doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by paclitaxel every 3 weeks (arm 1) with the same regimen plus 52 weeks of paclitaxel starting with the first dose Trastuzumab (group 2). North Central Cancer Therapeutics Group trial N9831 compared three treatment regimens: doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide, followed by weekly paclitaxel (Arm A), and the same regimen of paclitaxel followed by 52 weeks of trastuzumab (B group), and the same treatment regimen plus trastuzumab initiated for 52 weeks concurrently with paclitaxel (group C). These studies were modified to include a combined analysis comparing Arms 1 and A (control group) with Arms 2 and C (trastuzumab arm). Arm B was excluded because trastuzumab was not given concurrently with paclitaxel. As of March 15, 2005, 394 events (relapse, second primary cancer, or death before recurrence) had been reported, triggering the first scheduled interim analysis. Of these, 133 were in the trastuzumab group and 261 were in the control group (hazard ratio, 0.48; P<0.0001). This result crosses the line into early stopping. The absolute difference in three-year disease-free survival between the trastuzumab and control groups was 12%. Trastuzumab treatment was associated with a 33% reduction in the risk of death (P=0.015). The three-year cumulative incidence of grade III or IV congestive heart failure or death from cardiac causes in the trastuzumab group was 4.1% in trial B-31 and 2.9% in trial N9831. Trastuzumab plus paclitaxel improves outcomes in women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer after doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide. (ClinicalTrials.gov numbers: NCT00004067 and NCT00005970.)

Trastuzumab is a recombinant monoclonal antibody directed against HER2 with clinical activity in HER2-overexpressing advanced breast cancer. We studied efficacy and safety after resection and completion of chemotherapy for early-stage breast cancer. This international, multicenter, randomized trial compared trastuzumab given every three weeks for one or two years in patients with HER2-positive and node-negative or node-positive breast cancer who had completed local therapy and at least four cycles of neoadjuvant or lymph node metastasis. observations were compared. 1694 women were randomly assigned to receive trastuzumab for two years, 1694 to one year of trastuzumab, and 1693 to observation. We report here only the results of one year of trastuzumab treatment or observation. At the first planned interim analysis (median follow-up of one year), 347 events (breast cancer recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, second nonbreast malignancy, or death) were observed: 127 incidents, and the observation group has 220 incident groups. The unadjusted hazard ratio for events in the trastuzumab group compared with the observation group was 0.54 (95% confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.67; log-rank test P<0.0001, crossing the interim analysis boundary), representing two years without The absolute benefit in disease survival increased by 8.4 percentage points. There was no significant difference in overall survival between the two groups (29 deaths in the trastuzumab group and 37 deaths in the observation group). Serious cardiotoxicity occurred in 0.5% of women treated with trastuzumab. One year of treatment with trastuzumab after adjuvant chemotherapy significantly improves disease-free survival in women with HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00045032.)

The clinical success of selective kinase inhibitors, such as imatinib and erlotinib, as therapeutics for a variety of human cancers has led to the further development and clinical use of such inhibitors against a variety of malignancies. Strong interest in testing. While most efforts have focused on receptor tyrosine kinases, including EGFR, HER2, PDGF receptors, c-KIT, and MET, serine/threonine kinase inhibitors are also beginning to appear in the discovery pipeline. Among these kinases, RAF and MEK kinases have received considerable attention, mainly due to the relatively high frequency of activating mutations in RAS (accounting for approximately 20% of all human cancers), and RAS is the initiator of the mature RAF-MEK-ERK signaling cascade. Upstream activators and BRAF kinases have frequent activating mutations (approximately 7% of all human cancers). Here, we summarize the current status of the development of kinase inhibitors targeting this signaling pathway, some of which have shown favorable toxicity profiles as well as promising activity in early clinical studies.

Targeted therapy through compounds that inhibit specific target molecules represents a new perspective in cancer treatment. In contrast to traditional chemotherapy, which acts on all dividing cells, causing toxic effects and damaging normal tissue, targeted drugs can attack in a more specific manner subpopulations of cells directly involved in tumor progression. Molecules that control cell proliferation and death, such as receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) for growth factors, are among the best targets for such treatments. Two classes of compounds targeting RTKs are currently in clinical use: monoclonal antibodies and tyrosine kinase inhibitors. The era of targeted therapy began with the approval of trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody targeting HER2, for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer, and imatinib, a small tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting BCR-Abl agent) is approved for the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia. Despite initial enthusiasm for the efficacy of these treatments, clinicians soon had to face the problem of relapse, as cancer patients almost always develop drug resistance, often due to activation of the alternative RTK pathway. From this perspective, the rationale for targeted medicine is undergoing a fundamental shift. In the past, major efforts have been devoted to the development of highly specific inhibitors acting on a single RTK. It is now widely accepted that molecules that interfere with multiple RTKs simultaneously may be more effective than single-target drugs. With the recent FDA approvals of sorafenib and sunitinib (targeting VEGFR, PDGFR, FLT-3, and c-Kit), a different scenario has emerged in which a new generation of anticancer drugs capable of inhibiting multiple pathways may Play an important role.

The growing field of personalized medicine plays an increasingly important role in cancer prevention, diagnosis, prognosis and treatment. The importance in clinical management has been demonstrated by the recent introduction into routine clinical practice of various individualized molecularly targeted therapies that have the effect of improving efficacy and/or reducing toxicity. The identification of cancer susceptibility genes, such as the BRCA gene in breast cancer, allows screening programs to identify patients "at risk" for cancer and help them make decisions about personal risk modification behaviors. Personalized medicine also plays an increasingly important role in cancer treatment. It is increasingly clear that there are molecularly distinct subtypes of various common cancers, each requiring a different treatment approach, e.g., monoclonal antibodies (trastuzumab and cetuximab) in HER2-positive Use in breast cancer and wild-type KRAS colorectal cancer; tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib, gefitinib, erlotinib, and crizotinib) to treat chronic myelogenous leukemia, gastrointestinal interstitial malignant tumors and non-small cell lung cancer, intracellular drugs (vemurafenib and olaparib) for the treatment of metastatic malignant melanoma and ovarian, breast and prostate cancer. The efficacy of various targeted therapies in these diverse tumors suggests that we are entering an era in which treatment decisions will be based on tumor molecular abnormalities or "signatures" rather than tumor tissue type or anatomic site of origin. Improve patient outcomes and quality of life. This mini-review focuses on the role of personalized medicine in cancer prevention and treatment and its future directions in oncology.

The robust clinical activity of imatinib and trastuzumab in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors, and breast cancer suggests that blocking pathogenic tyrosine kinases can alter the natural history of human tumors. EGF receptor inhibitors, on the other hand, showed modest activity overall. These contrasts in drug development mean that molecular target dependence and patient selection are critical to the successful outcome of this process. We will compare lessons learned from the development of Abl, c-Kit, HER2/neu (erbB2), and EGFR inhibitors, highlight successes and limitations in the field, and propose new approaches to the clinical development of tyrosine kinase inhibitor treatments.

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, the two main types of chronic inflammatory bowel disease, are multifactorial conditions of unknown etiology. The susceptibility locus for Crohn's disease has been mapped to chromosome 16. coding variant and two missense variants in NOD2, encoding a member of the Apaf-1/Ced-4 superfamily of apoptosis regulators expressed in monocytes. These NOD2 variants alter the structure of the protein's leucine-rich repeat domains or adjacent regions. NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kB; this activating function is mediated by a carboxyl-terminal leucine-rich repeat domain that has inhibitory effects and also serves as an intracellular receptor for components of microbial pathogens. These observations document the pathogenesis of Crohn's disease by suggesting that the NOD2 gene product confers susceptibility to Crohn's disease by altering the recognition of these components and/or by overactivating NF-kB in monocytes. Molecular model of the mechanism, which can now be studied further.

Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract thought to be caused by the impact of environmental factors on genetically susceptible hosts. Multiple linkage studies have identified the location of a gene in the pericentromeric region of chromosome 16 IBD1 that is associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease, but the specific gene has not yet been identified. NOD2, a gene encoding a protein homologous to the product of a plant disease resistance gene, is located in the linkage peak region on chromosome 16 (ref. 7). Here, we show by using transmission imbalance testing and case-control analysis that the frameshift mutation 3020insC, caused by a cytosine insertion (predicted to encode a truncated NOD2 protein), is associated with Crohn's disease. Wild-type NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kappaB in response to bacterial lipopolysaccharide; however, this induction is defective in mutant NOD2. These results implicate NOD2 in susceptibility to Crohn's disease and suggest a link between the innate immune response to bacterial components and the development of the disease.

Nod2 activates the NF-kappaB pathway upon intracellular stimulation by bacterial products. Recently, mutations in Nod2 have been shown to be associated with Crohn's disease, suggesting that bacterial-host interactions play a role in the etiology of this disease. We show here that Nod2 serves as a universal sensor of peptidoglycan by recognizing muramyl dipeptide (MDP), the minimal bioactive peptidoglycan motif shared by all bacteria. Furthermore, the 3020insC frameshift mutation, the most common Nod2 variant associated with Crohn's disease patients, completely abolishes Nod2-dependent peptidoglycan and MDP detection. Taken together, these results impact the understanding of Crohn's disease development. Furthermore, the characterization of Nod2 as the first pathogen recognition molecule to detect MDP will help reveal the well-known biological activities of this immunomodulatory compound.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis are chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. Tremendous progress has been made recently in understanding the pathogenesis of these diseases. Through studies in patients and mouse models, it has been found that Crohn's disease is driven by the production of interleukin 12 (IL-12) and interferon gamma (IFN-γ), while ulcerative colitis may be driven by the production of IL Driven-13. A second area of ​​progress is in identifying the specific genetic abnormalities that cause disease. The most important finding was the identification of mutations in the gene encoding the NOD2 (nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 2) protein in a subgroup of Crohn's disease patients. Here, we discuss these recent findings and their implications for treatment.

CARD15/NOD2 mutations are associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease (CD) and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). CD and GVHD are suspected to be associated with dysfunction of Peyer's lymph nodes (PP) and solitary lymphoid follicles (LF). Using a new mouse model that is null for Card15/Nod2 (KO), we analyzed the impact of this gene on the formation of these lymphoid tissues and on the development of experimental colitis. PP and LF numbers were higher in KO mice at 4, 12, and 52 weeks, but no differences were observed at birth. The size and cellular composition of PP were analyzed by flow cytometry and immunohistochemistry at 4 and 12 weeks. KO mice had larger PP and increased proportions of M cells and CD4(+) T cells. KO mice were also characterized by higher concentrations of TNFα, IFNγ, IL12, and IL4 as measured by ELISA. In contrast, few differences were found in the ileum without PP and the spleens of KO mice. Using in-house experiments, we found that this PP phenotype is associated with increased paracellular permeability and yeast/bacterial translocation. Finally, KO mice were more susceptible to TNBS-induced colitis. Card15/Nod2 deficiency leads to abnormalities in PP development and function, characterized by an exaggerated immune response and increased permeability. These observations provide a comprehensive link between molecular defects and human CARD15/NOD2-related diseases (CD and GVHD).

GATA3 is a transcription factor that regulates cytokine production by T cells. We investigated the role of GATA3 in the development of colitis in mice. We performed quantitative polymerase chain reaction and immunofluorescence analyzes on colonic tissue from patients with Crohn's disease (n = 61) or ulcerative colitis (UC, n = 74) or without inflammatory bowel disease (n = 22) , to measure GATA3 levels. Control mice, mice with T cell-specific deletion of GATA3, and mice with tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) 1 and TNFR2 deletion ( TNFR double knockout) induces colitis); some mice were given a GATA3-specific DNAzyme (hgd40) or a control DNAzyme via intrarectal administration or systemic injection of TNF antibodies before or during the sensitization and challenge phases of colitis induction. . Colon tissue was collected and subjected to immunofluorescence and histochemical analyses. Isolate and analyze lamina propria monocytes and T cells by flow cytometry or cytokine assay. Colonic distribution and inflammation of labeled DNAzyme were monitored by in vivo imaging (endoscopy) in mice. Levels of GATA3 messenger RNA were higher in colon tissue from patients with UC but not in colon tissue from patients with ileal Crohn's disease compared with control tissue. GATA3 levels correlate with levels of inflammatory cytokines (interleukin [IL] 9, IL17A, IL6, IL5, IL4, IL13, and TNF). We observed increased expression of GATA3 on lamina propria T cells in mice with colitis compared with controls. Mice with T cell-specific deletion of GATA3 do not develop colitis and their colon tissue does not produce inflammatory cytokines (IL6, IL9, or IL13). DNAzyme hgd40 inhibits GATA3 messenger RNA expression by unstimulated and stimulated T cells and is distributed in the inflamed colon of mice with colitis. Expression of GATA3 messenger RNA was reduced in the colon tissue of mice given hgd40 compared with mice given control DNAzyme. Mice given hgd40 did not develop colitis after administration of oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzene sulfonic acid; lamina propria cells of these mice expressed lower levels of IL6, IL9, and IL13 than those given control DNAzyme of mouse cells. Microendoscopic imaging shows that hgd40 and anti-TNF drugs reduce colon inflammation over 3 days; hgd40 reduces colitis in TNFR double knockout mice. GATA3 levels are elevated in UC patients and are associated with the production of inflammatory cytokines in mice and humans. A DNAzyme that blocks GATA3 expression reduces colitis in mice independently of TNF and reduces cytokine levels in the colon. This DNAzyme may be developed to treat UC patients.

Geographic and racial differences in the frequency of ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease suggest that environmental factors influence disease risk. Prevention of parasites (worms) through improved hygiene practices may be one of the factors contributing to the increased prevalence of the disease. Helmins alter host mucosal and systemic immunity. Animals exposed to helminths are protected from experimental colitis and other immune diseases, and helminth colonization can be used to treat persistent murine and human diseases. Worms induce Th2 and regulatory cytokine production from mucosal T cells. Helminth-induced mucosal IL4, TGFbeta, and IL10 may be part of the protective process. Worms affect innate immune pathways such as TLR4 expression and function. C. elegans also induces various regulatory T cell subsets in the intestine, thereby limiting the growth and function of effector T cells. These effects of once-existing worms may protect people from immune-mediated diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease.

Approximately 70 loci have been associated with Crohn's disease (CD) susceptibility, particularly in innate immunity, autophagy, and pathogen recognition pathways. Phenotype-genotype associations are inconsistent. CD susceptibility polymorphism ATG16L1 rs2241880, ICAM1 rs5498, IL4 rs2070874, IL17F rs763780, IRGM rs13361189, ITLN1 rs2274910, LRRK2 1961189, ITLN1 rs2274910, LRRK2 11175 496117540972 69496, 626 controls) and evaluate their association with clinical features of CD. CD was significantly associated with single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in ATG16L1 (odds ratio [OR] for allele G 1.36 [1.15-1.60], P = 2.7 × 10(-6)), IRGM ( OR 1.56 [1.21] -1.93], P = 3.9 × 10(-4) for allele C and ITLN1 (OR 1.55 [1.28-1.88], P = 4.9 × 10(-4) for allele C) . These SNPs were associated with ileal location (ORs 1.49, 1.52, and 1.70, respectively), ileocolic location (ORs 1.31, 1.57, and 1.68, respectively), and upper gastrointestinal tract involvement (ORs ATG16L1 and IRGM, respectively).
