The comparison of ASA+DP and clopidogrel is based on an initial assessment of non-inferiority followed by an assessment of superiority, while for telmisartan we will assess its superiority over placebo. With more than 20,000 randomized patients using a 2 x 2 factorial design, the PRoFESS study is the largest stroke study examining the prevention of recurrent stroke. The mean age was 66.1 +/- 8.6 years, and 36.0% of patients were women. The median time from qualifying event to randomization was 15 days, with 39.9% of patients randomized within 10 days. According to TOAST criteria, 28.5% of strokes were due to large vessel disease, 52.1% to small vessel disease, 1.8% to cardioembolism, 2.0% to other known etiology, and 15.5% to unknown etiology. PRoFESS is the largest secondary stroke prevention study to date and will directly compare two antiplatelet therapy regimens and the benefits of telmisartan versus placebo.

The risk of bleeding during and after early hip fracture surgery in patients taking clopidogrel and other anticoagulants has not been determined. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the risk of perioperative bleeding and clinical outcomes after early hip fracture surgery in patients taking clopidogrel (Plavix) and other oral anticoagulants. The study design was a retrospective cohort analysis using data obtained from hospital and state death records. Regional Medical Center (II degree traumatology). Data from 1118 patients aged ≥60 years who underwent hip fracture surgery between 2004 and 2008 were analyzed. Eighty-two patients who underwent late surgery (>3 days after admission) were excluded from the study. Patients taking clopidogrel were compared with those not taking clopidogrel. In addition, patients taking clopidogrel alone were compared with cohorts of patients taking both clopidogrel and aspirin, aspirin only, warfarin only, or no anticoagulants. Seventy-four of 1036 patients (7%) were taking clopidogrel, although controls included 253 patients taking aspirin only, 90 patients taking warfarin, and 619 patients not taking anticoagulants. There were no significant differences between patients taking clopidogrel and those not taking clopidogrel in estimated blood loss, need for blood transfusion, final blood count, hematoma evacuation, length of stay (LOS) or mortality during hospital stay or after 1 year. A higher American Society of Anesthesiologists score was observed in the clopidogrel and warfarin groups (P = 0.05 each), increased LOS in the clopidogrel group (P = 0.05), and a higher incidence of deep vein thrombosis was observed in patients taking warfarin (P = 0). .05). Clopidogrel alone versus aspirin, versus aspirin and clopidogrel, versus no anticoagulant versus warfarin showed no significant differences in estimated blood loss, blood transfusion requirement, final blood count, bleeding, or perioperative complications or mortality. Patients who have had early hip fracture surgery and are taking clopidogrel, aspirin, or warfarin (adjusted international normalized ratio) are not at significantly increased risk of bleeding, bleeding complications, or mortality. Comorbidities and American Society of Anesthesiologists scores were significantly higher in the clopidogrel group, which may have led to increased postoperative LOS in this group.

Several new anticoagulants are in clinical development. Recently two of them, Dabigatran etexilate/Pradaxa. and Rivaroxaban/Xarelto have received marketing authorization in Europe and Canada for the prevention of thromboembolic complications after major orthopedic surgeries such as total hip and knee replacements. The results of phase III clinical trials on thromboprophylaxis in major orthopedic surgeries are highlighted and discussed in detail. Ongoing phase II and III clinical trials are evaluating their effectiveness in the secondary prevention and treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, as well as long-term stroke prevention in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation and in combination with aspirin and clopidogrel in patients. in acute coronary syndromes. Many other small antithrombotic molecules, including a new generation of low molecular weight heparins, are currently in various stages of clinical development. In addition to oral administration, new anticoagulants have a more balanced benefit/risk ratio and a wider therapeutic window. They have a rapid onset of action, a predictable anticoagulant effect that does not require routine laboratory monitoring. They have minor interactions with food and drugs, including cytochrome P450 and P.gp. They are highly specific and target a single clotting factor and may carry a similar or lower risk of hemorrhage compared to older anticoagulants. Finally, they can be used in a wider range of patients, especially in patients with advanced cancer and the elderly, without any dose adjustment, regardless of the patient's age, gender, body weight or in patients with mild renal impairment. We hope their use around the world will confirm the promising results from clinical trials.

Allopurinol, often prescribed for gout and hyperuricemia, is a common cause of severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs), which include drug hypersensitivity syndrome, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis. Adverse events are unpredictable and carry significant morbidity and mortality. To identify genetic markers of allopurinol-SCAR, we performed a case-control association study. We included 51 allopurinol-SCAR patients and 228 controls (135 allopurinol-tolerant subjects and 93 healthy subjects from the general population), and genotyped 823 SNPs in genes associated with drug metabolism and immune response. Initial screening revealed a strong association between allopurinol-SCAR and SNPs in the MHC region, including BAT3 (HLA-B associated transcript 3), MSH5 (mutS homolog 5), and MICB (MHC class I polypeptide-related sequence B) (P < 10(-7)). We then determined the alleles of the HLA A, B, C, and DRB1 loci. The HLA-B*5801 allele was present in all (100%) of the 51 patients with allopurinol-SCAR, but in only 20 (15%) of the 135 tolerant patients [odds ratio 580.3 (95% confidence interval, 34.4-9780, 9); adjusted P value = 4.7 x 10(-24)] and in 19 (20%) of 93 healthy subjects [393.51 (23.23-6665.26); adjusted P value = 8.1 x 10 (-18)]. The HLA alleles A*3303, Cw*0302 and DRB1*0301 were in linkage disequilibrium and formed an extended haplotype with HLA-B*5801. Our results showed that allopurinol-SCAR is closely related to genetic susceptibility in Han Chinese. In particular, the HLA-B*5801 allele is an important genetic risk factor for this life-threatening condition.

Develop evidence-based recommendations for the treatment of gout. The multidisciplinary guideline development group included 19 rheumatologists and one evidence-based medicine expert, representing 13 European countries. Key management proposals were formulated using a Delphi consensus approach. Research was carried out systematically for each proposal. Where possible, effect size (ES), number needed to treat, relative risk, odds ratio and incremental cost-effectiveness ratio were calculated. The quality of the evidence was graded according to the level of evidence. Strength of recommendation (SOR) was assessed using the EULAR visual analogue and ordinal scales. After three rounds of Delphi, 12 key proposals were generated. Suggestions included both non-pharmacological and pharmacological treatments and focused on symptomatic control of acute gout, urate-lowering therapy (ULT) and prevention of acute attacks. The importance of patient education, modification of adverse lifestyle behaviors (weight loss for obesity, reduction of alcohol consumption, low purine diet in animals) and treatment of associated diseases and risk factors was emphasized. Recommended treatments for acute attacks were oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), oral colchicine (ES = 0.87 (95% CI 0.25 to 1.50)), or combined aspiration and injection of a corticosteroid. ULT is indicated for patients with recurrent acute attacks, arthropathy, tophi, or radiographic changes of gout. Allopurinol was confirmed to be an effective long-term ULT (ES = 1.39 (0.78–2.01)). If allopurinol toxicity occurs, options include other xanthine oxidase inhibitors, allopurinol desensitization, or uricosurics. The uricosuric benzbromarone is more effective than allopurinol (ES = 1.50 (0.76 to 2.24)) and can be used in patients with mild to moderate renal impairment but may be hepatotoxic. If gout is associated with diuretic use, diuretics should be discontinued if possible. For the prevention of acute attacks, either colchicine 0.5–1 mg per day or NSAIDs (if gastroprotection is available) is recommended. Based on a combination of scientific evidence and expert consensus, 12 key recommendations for the treatment of gout have been developed. The evidence was assessed and an SOR was provided for each proposal.

Febuxostat, a novel non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is a potential alternative to allopurinol for patients with hyperuricemia and gout. We randomly assigned 762 patients with gout and a serum urate concentration of at least 8.0 mg per deciliter (480 micromol per liter) to receive febuxostat (80 mg or 120 mg) or allopurinol (300 mg) once daily at within 52 weeks; 760 received the study drug. Prevention of gout exacerbations was carried out from weeks 1 to 8 with naproxen or colchicine. The primary endpoint was a serum urate concentration of less than 6.0 mg per deciliter (360 micromol per liter) at the last three monthly measurements. Secondary endpoints included reduction in gout flares and reduction in tophi area. The primary endpoint was met in 53 percent of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 62 percent of patients receiving 120 mg febuxostat, and 21 percent of patients receiving allopurinol (P<0.001 for comparison of each febuxostat group with the allopurinol group). . Although the incidence of gout flares decreased with continued treatment, the overall incidence over weeks 9 to 52 was similar in all groups: 64 percent of patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat, 70 percent of patients receiving 120 mg febuxostat, and 64 percent of patients receiving 120 mg febuxostat . those receiving allopurinol (P=0.99 for febuxostat 80 mg versus allopurinol; P=0.23 for febuxostat 120 mg versus allopurinol). The median reduction in tophi area was 83 percent in patients receiving 80 mg febuxostat and 66 percent in patients receiving 120 mg febuxostat, compared with 50 percent in patients receiving allopurinol (P = 0.08 for 80 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol ; P =0.16 for 120 mg febuxostat versus allopurinol). More patients in the high-dose febuxostat group than in the allopurinol group (P=0.003) or in the low-dose febuxostat group discontinued the study. Four of 507 patients in the two febuxostat groups (0.8 percent) and none of 253 patients in the allopurinol group died; all deaths were from causes that the investigators (although they were still unaware of the treatment) considered unrelated to the study drugs (P = 0.31 for the comparison between the febuxostat combination group and the allopurinol group). Febuxostat at a daily dose of 80 or 120 mg was more effective than allopurinol at the commonly used fixed daily dose of 300 mg in reducing serum urate levels. Similar reductions in gout flares and tophi area were observed in all treatment groups.

The prototypic xanthine oxidase (XO) inhibitor allopurinol has been a cornerstone of the clinical treatment of gout and hyperuricemia-related conditions for several decades. More recent evidence suggests that CO also plays an important role in various forms of ischemic and other types of tissue and vascular damage, inflammatory diseases and chronic heart failure. Allopurinol and its active metabolite oxypurinol have shown significant promise in the treatment of these conditions, both in experimental animals and in small clinical studies in humans. Although some of the beneficial effects of these compounds may not be due to XO inhibition, the encouraging results have renewed significant interest in the development of additional, new series of XO inhibitors for various therapeutic indications. Here we present a critical review of the effects of XO inhibitors in various pathophysiological conditions and also review the various new therapeutic strategies offered by this approach.

To evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in patients with primary fibromyalgia, with or without current major depressive disorder. This study was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted at 18 outpatient research sites in the United States. A total of 207 subjects meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for primary fibromyalgia were included (89% women, 87% white, mean age 49 years, 38% with current major depressive disorder). After single-blind treatment with placebo for 1 week, subjects were randomly assigned to receive duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (n = 104) or placebo (n = 103) for 12 weeks. Co-primary outcome measures were the Fibromyalgia Impact Questionnaire (FIQ) total score (score range 0 to 80, with 0 indicating no impact) and FIQ pain scale score (score range 0 to 10). Secondary outcomes included mean tender point pain threshold, number of tender points, FIQ fatigue, awakening fatigue and stiffness scores, Clinical Global Impression of Severity (CGI-Severity) scale, Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-Improvement) scale, Short Inventory Pain (Short Form), Medical Outcomes Study Short Form 36, Depression Quality of Life Scale, and Sheehan Disability Scale. Compared with subjects taking placebo, subjects taking duloxetine had a significantly greater improvement (P=0.027) in FIQ total score, with a treatment difference of -5.53 (95% CI -10.43, -0.63 ), but not significantly more according to FIQ Pain Score (P = 0.130). Compared with subjects taking placebo, subjects taking duloxetine had significantly greater reductions in mean Brief Pain Questionnaire pain severity score (P = 0.008), mean Brief Pain Questionnaire pain impact score (P = 0.004), and number of tender points. (P = 0.002) and FIQ stiffness score (P = 0.048), and also had significantly greater improvements in mean tender point pain threshold (P = 0.002), CGI severity (P = 0.048), and PGI improvement (P = 0.033). and several measures of quality of life. Treatment with duloxetine reduced fibromyalgia symptoms and pain, regardless of baseline major depressive disorder status. Compared with women taking placebo (n = 92), women taking duloxetine (n = 92) showed significantly greater improvement on most efficacy measures, while male subjects taking duloxetine (n = 12) failed significantly improve any efficiency. measure. The treatment effect on significantly reducing pain in women was independent of the effect on mood or anxiety. Duloxetine was used safely and was well tolerated. In this randomized, controlled, 12-week trial (with a 1-week placebo run-in phase), duloxetine was found to be an effective and safe treatment for many symptoms associated with fibromyalgia in patients with or without major depressive disorder, especially women. , who showed significant improvement on most outcome measures.

This was a 12-week, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of duloxetine, a selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, in 354 female patients with primary fibromyalgia, with or without current major depressive disorder. Patients (90% Caucasian; mean age 49.6 years; 26% with current major depressive disorder) received duloxetine 60 mg once daily (QD) (N=118), duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (2 times daily) (N=116) or placebo (N=120). The primary outcome was the average Brief Pain Inventory pain severity score. Response to treatment was defined as a decrease in this parameter by > or = 30%. Compared with placebo, both duloxetine groups showed significantly greater improvement (P<0.001) in the Brief Pain Inventory mean pain severity score. A significantly higher percentage of patients taking duloxetine had a > or = 30% reduction in duloxetine (duloxetine 60 mg once daily (55%; P < 0.001); duloxetine 60 mg twice daily (54%; P = 0.002); placebo (33%)). The therapeutic effect of duloxetine on pain reduction was independent of the effect on mood and the presence of major depressive disorder. Compared with patients taking placebo, patients taking duloxetine 60 mg once daily or duloxetine 60 mg twice daily had significantly greater improvements in the remaining measures of pain severity and interference on the Brief Pain Questionnaire, Pain Questionnaire. impact of fibromyalgia, clinical global impression of severity, patient global impression of improvement, and several quality of life measures. Both doses of duloxetine were used safely and well tolerated. In conclusion, both duloxetine 60 mg once daily and duloxetine 60 mg twice daily were effective and safe in the treatment of fibromyalgia in patients with or without major depressive disorder.

The primary objectives of this study were to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of duloxetine for reducing pain severity in fibromyalgia patients with or without current major depressive disorder. This was a 6-month, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study. A total of 520 patients meeting American College of Rheumatology criteria for fibromyalgia were randomized to receive duloxetine (20 mg/day, 60 mg/day, or 120 mg/day) or placebo given once daily for 6 months (after 3 months in the duloxetine 20 mg/day group, the dose was titrated to 60 mg/day). Co-primary outcome measures were mean Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) pain severity score and Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I) score. Safety was assessed by treatment-emergent adverse events, as well as changes in vital signs, laboratory values, and ECG findings. Compared with patients taking placebo, patients taking duloxetine 120 mg/day had significantly greater improvements in the co-primary outcome at 3 months (change in BPI [-2.31 vs -1.39, P<0.001] and PGI-I [2.89 vs. 3.39, P=0.004]) and at 6 months (change in BMI [-2.26 vs. -1.43, P=0.003] and PGI-I [2.93 vs. 3. 37, P=0.012]). Compared with placebo, treatment with duloxetine 60 mg/day also significantly improved primary treatment scores at 3 months and BMI at 6 months. Duloxetine was effective in patients with and without major depressive disorder. There were no clinically significant differences between treatment groups in changes in vital signs, laboratory values, or ECG parameters. The study results showed that duloxetine at doses of 60 mg/day and 120 mg/day is safe and effective in patients with fibromyalgia.

Duloxetine is a balanced serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor licensed for the treatment of major depressive disorders, stress urinary incontinence, and the treatment of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy. A number of studies have been conducted examining the use of duloxetine in neuropathic and nociceptive disease conditions. This is the first update to a review first published in 2010. Objective: To evaluate the benefits and harms of duloxetine in the treatment of painful neuropathy and various types of chronic pain. On November 19, 2013, we searched the Cochrane Neuromuscular Group Specialized Register, CENTRAL, DARE, HTA, NHSEED, MEDLINE, and EMBASE. We searched ClinicalTrials.gov for ongoing studies in April 2013. We also searched reference lists of identified publications investigating duloxetine for the treatment of painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain. We selected all randomized or quasi-randomized studies of any form of duloxetine used to treat painful peripheral neuropathy or chronic pain in adults. We used standard methodological procedures expected by the Cochrane Collaboration. We identified 18 trials involving 6407 participants. We found 12 such studies in our literature search for this update. Eight studies included a total of 2728 participants with painful diabetic neuropathy, and six studies included a total of 2249 participants with fibromyalgia. Three studies included participants with depression and painful physical symptoms, and one included participants with central neuropathic pain. The studies generally had a low risk of bias, although significant exclusions, imputation methods, and nearly every study conducted or sponsored by a drug manufacturer increase the risk of bias in some areas. Duloxetine 60 mg daily is effective in the treatment of painful diabetic peripheral neuropathy in the short term, with a hazard ratio (HR) for ≥50% pain reduction at 12 weeks of 1.73 (95% CI 1.44 to 2. 08). The corresponding NNTB is 5 (95% CI 4 to 7). Duloxetine 60 mg daily is also effective for fibromyalgia over 12 weeks (RR for pain relief ≥50% 1.57, 95% CI 1.20 to 2.06; NNTB 8, 95% CI 4 to 21) and more than 28 weeks (RR 1.58, 95). % CI 1.10 to 2.27) and for painful physical symptoms in depression (RR 1.37, 95% CI 1.19 to 1.59; NNTB 8, 95% CI 5 to 14). One small, high-quality study observed no effect on central neuropathic pain. Across all conditions, adverse events were common in both the treatment and placebo groups, but more common in the treatment group, and the effect was dose dependent. Most side effects were minor, but 16% of participants stopped taking the drug due to side effects. Serious adverse events were rare. In eight studies conducted by the manufacturers of duloxetine, there was sufficient moderate-quality evidence that doses of 60 mg and 120 mg per day are effective for treating pain in diabetic peripheral neuropathy, but lower daily doses are not. No further testing is required. For fibromyalgia, there is lower quality evidence that duloxetine is effective at doses similar to those used for diabetic peripheral neuropathy and with similar magnitude of effect. The effect in fibromyalgia may be achieved through greater improvement in mental symptoms than in somatic physical pain. There is low to moderate quality evidence that pain relief is also achieved for pain associated with depressive symptoms, but an NNTB score of 8 for fibromyalgia and depression does not indicate significant effectiveness. Additional studies (preferably studies conducted by independent investigators) in these indications are needed to achieve optimal information and convincing conclusions about effectiveness. Minor side effects are common and are more common with duloxetine 60 mg and especially with 120 mg per day than with 20 mg per day. , but serious side effects are rare. It would be worthwhile to conduct improved head-to-head comparisons of duloxetine with other antidepressants and other drugs such as pregabalin, which have already been shown to be effective for neuropathic pain. Unbiased economic comparisons could further aid decision making, but no high-quality studies include economic data.

Peripheral artery disease is considered a manifestation of systemic atherosclerosis with associated adverse cardiovascular and limb events. Data from previous studies have shown that patients receiving clopidogrel monotherapy had a lower risk of cardiovascular events than those receiving aspirin. We wanted to compare clopidogrel with ticagrelor, a potent antiplatelet agent, in patients with peripheral artery disease. In this double-blind, event-driven study, we randomly assigned 13,885 patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease to monotherapy with ticagrelor (90 mg twice daily) or clopidogrel (75 mg once daily). Patients were eligible for study participation if they had an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.80 or less or if they had previously undergone lower extremity revascularization. The primary efficacy endpoint was a composite of adjudicated cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, or ischemic stroke. The primary safety endpoint was major bleeding. The average follow-up period was 30 months. The mean age of the patients was 66 years, 72% were men; 43% were included based on ABI and 57% based on prior revascularization. The average baseline ABI for all patients was 0.71, 76.6% of patients had claudication, and 4.6% had critical limb ischemia. The primary efficacy endpoint occurred in 751 of 6930 patients (10.8%) receiving ticagrelor and 740 of 6955 (10.6%) receiving clopidogrel (hazard ratio 1.02; 95% confidence interval [CI] of 0 .92 to 1.13; P=0.65). . In each group, acute limb ischemia occurred in 1.7% of patients (hazard ratio 1.03; 95% CI 0.79 to 1.33; P=0.85) and major bleeding in 1.6% (hazard ratio 1 .10; 95% CI from 0.84 to 1.43; P = 0.49). In patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease, ticagrelor was not superior to clopidogrel in reducing cardiovascular events. Major bleeding occurred at similar rates among patients in the two study arms. (Funded by AstraZeneca; ClinicalTrials.gov EUCLID number, NCT01732822.)

Peripheral artery disease (PAD) affects approximately 20% of adults over 55 years of age and is a powerful predictor of myocardial infarction, stroke, and death from vascular causes. The goal of treatment is to prevent future serious coronary and cerebrovascular events and improve leg symptoms. Review of the best evidence for drug treatment of PAD. MEDLINE and the Cochrane Database were searched from 1990 to November 2005 for randomized trials and meta-analyses of drug treatments for PAD. References from these articles were also searched. Search keywords included, individually and in combination: peripheral arterial disease, peripheral arterial disease, PAD, randomized controlled trial, controlled trial, randomized trial, and meta-analysis. Particular attention was paid to randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses of clinically relevant treatments for PAD. Outcome measures included leg symptoms (claudication and walking distance), death, and major coronary and cerebrovascular events. Symptoms of lame legs, increased walking distance, and quality of life can be improved by smoking cessation (physician advice, nicotine replacement therapy, and bupropion), a structured exercise program, statin medications, cilostazol, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors. The risk of serious coronary and cerebrovascular events can be reduced by lowering blood pressure with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and other antihypertensive drugs, use of statin drugs, antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel, and possibly smoking cessation. The substantial and growing burden of PAD, as well as its local and systemic complications, can be reduced by lifestyle changes (smoking cessation, exercise) and drug therapy (nicotine replacement therapy, bupropion, antihypertensive drugs, statins, and antiplatelet agents).

Incomplete inhibition of thromboxane production by platelets, as measured by increased urinary concentrations of 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2), is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events. We sought to determine the external validity of this association in aspirin-treated patients enrolled in the Clopidogrel for High Risk Atheothrombotic and Stabilization, Treatment and Prevention of Ischemia (CHARISMA) trial, and to determine whether there are any modifiable factors or interventions that reduce level 11-11 in urine. concentrations of dehydrothromboxane B(2), which could thereby reduce cardiovascular risk. Urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations were measured in 3261 patients taking aspirin at least 1 month after they were randomly assigned to placebo or clopidogrel. Baseline urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentrations in the highest quartile were associated with an increased risk of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death compared with the lowest quartile (adjusted hazard ratio 1.66, 95% CI 1.66). 06 to 2.61, P = 0.03). Age, female sex, history of peripheral arterial disease, current smoking, and oral hypoglycemic therapy or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor therapy were independently associated with higher urinary concentrations of 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2), whereas aspirin dose > or = 150 mg /day, history of treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, history of hypercholesterolemia, and treatment with statins were associated with lower concentrations. Randomization to clopidogrel (versus placebo) did not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients with the highest quartile of urinary 11-dehydrothromoxane B(2) levels. In patients receiving aspirin, urinary 11-dehydrothromboxane B(2) concentration is an externally valid and potentially modifiable determinant of stroke, myocardial infarction, or cardiovascular death in patients at risk for atherothrombotic events.

This guideline focuses on antithrombotic drug therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease and for the relief of lower extremity symptoms and critical ischemia in individuals with peripheral artery disease (PAD). The methods in this guideline are consistent with those described in the Guidelines for the Development of Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention: Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention, 9th ed.: Evidence-based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Physicians in this appendix. The most important of our 20 recommendations are as follows. For patients aged ≥ 50 years with asymptomatic PAD or asymptomatic carotid stenosis, we offer aspirin (75–100 mg/day) instead of no therapy (Level 2B) for primary prevention of cardiovascular events. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic PAD (including patients before and after peripheral arterial bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), we recommend long-term use of aspirin (75–100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Class 1A). We do not recommend the use of the combination of warfarin and aspirin in patients with symptomatic PAD (Grade 1B). For patients undergoing percutaneous transluminal peripheral artery angioplasty with stenting, we offer single rather than dual antiplatelet therapy (Level 2C). For patients with refractory claudication despite exercise therapy and smoking cessation, we suggest adding cilostazol (100 mg twice daily) to aspirin (75–100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Level 2C). In patients with critical limb ischemia and pain at rest who cannot undergo revascularization, we suggest the use of prostanoids (level 2C). For patients with acute limb ischemia due to acute thrombosis or embolism, we recommend surgery over peripheral arterial thrombolysis (Grade 1B). Guidelines continue to favor monoantipembocytic therapy for primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular events in most patients with asymptomatic PAD, symptomatic PAD, and asymptomatic carotid stenosis. Additional treatments for relief of extremity symptoms should be considered only after exercise therapy, smoking cessation, and evaluation of peripheral arterial revascularization.

The methods in this guideline are consistent with those described in the Guidelines for the Development of Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention: Antithrombotic Therapy and Thrombosis Prevention, 9th ed.: Evidence-based Clinical Practice Guidelines of the American College of Physicians in this appendix. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease in patients with symptomatic PAD (including patients before and after peripheral arterial bypass surgery or percutaneous transluminal angioplasty), we recommend long-term use of aspirin (75–100 mg/day) or clopidogrel (75 mg/day) (Class 1A). We do not recommend the use of the combination of warfarin and aspirin in patients with symptomatic PAD (Grade 1B). Bleeding, a common complication of treatment for acute myocardial infarction (AMI), is associated with worse outcomes. A modern model of major bleeding associated with AMI treatment can stratify patients at increased risk of bleeding and is needed to adjust AMI practice and outcomes based on risk. Using the Registry-Get With the Guidelines (ACTION Registry-GWTG) network database of acute coronary treatment and intervention outcomes, an in-hospital model of the risk of major bleeding was developed in a population of patients with ST-segment elevation and non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. myocardial infarction with elevation of the segment. The model used outcome variables only and was developed (n = 72,313) and validated (n = 17,960) in patients with AMI (at 251 US sites from January 2007 to December 2008). The 12 most statistically and clinically significant variables were included in the final regression model. Calibration plots are shown, and model recognition is demonstrated in the derivation and validation cohorts, as well as key subgroups. The incidence of major bleeding in the general population was 10.8%. The 12 factors associated with major bleeding in the model were heart rate, baseline hemoglobin, female gender, baseline serum creatinine, age, electrocardiographic changes, heart failure or shock, diabetes, peripheral arterial disease, body weight, systolic blood pressure, and taking warfarin at home. use. The risk model discriminated well between the derivation (C-statistic = 0.73) and validation (C-statistic = 0.71) cohorts. The risk score for major bleeding corresponded well with the observed bleeding: very low risk (3.9%), low risk (7.3%), moderate risk (16.1%), high risk (29.0%), and very high risk ( 39.8%). In conclusion, the ACTION Registry-GWTG in-hospital major bleeding model stratifies the risk of major bleeding using variables at the time of presentation and allows for risk-adjusted bleeding outcomes for quality improvement initiatives and clinical decision making.

Combination anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy is more effective than antiplatelet therapy alone for the initial and long-term treatment of acute coronary syndromes, but increases the risk of bleeding. Antiplatelet therapy is often combined with oral anticoagulants in patients with an indication for warfarin therapy (eg, atrial fibrillation) who also have an indication for antiplatelet therapy (eg, coronary artery disease), but the appropriateness of this approach has not been decided. Anticoagulants appear to be as effective as antiplatelet therapy in the long-term treatment of acute coronary syndrome and stroke, and possibly peripheral arterial disease, but cause more bleeding. Thus, in such patients who develop atrial fibrillation, switching from antiplatelet therapy to anticoagulants may be all that is required. The combination of anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy has been shown to provide additional benefit compared with anticoagulant monotherapy in patients with prosthetic heart valves. The combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is not as effective as oral anticoagulants in patients with atrial fibrillation, while the combination of aspirin and clopidogrel is more effective than oral anticoagulants in patients with coronary stents. The question of whether the benefits of triple therapy outweigh the risks in patients with atrial fibrillation and coronary stents requires evaluation in randomized trials.

Vascular disease is included in the risk scoring system for predicting stroke in patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation (AF). This post hoc ROCKET AF analysis aimed to determine the absolute incidence of stroke and bleeding and the relative efficacy and safety of rivaroxaban compared with warfarin in patients with and without peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Peripheral arterial disease was defined in the medical record as the presence of intermittent claudication, amputation for arterial insufficiency, vascular reconstruction, bypass or percutaneous extremity surgery, or a previously documented abdominal aortic aneurysm. ROCKET AF was a double-blind, double-placebo, randomized-controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of rivaroxaban and warfarin in the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism. A total of 839 (5.9%) patients in ROCKET AF had PAD. Patients with and without PAD had similar rates of stroke or systemic embolism [RR: 1.04, 95% CI (0.72, 1.50), P = 0.84] and major or minor clinically significant (NMCR) bleeding [ HR: 1.11, 95% CI (0.96, 1.28), P = 0.17], respectively. The effectiveness of rivaroxaban compared with warfarin for the prevention of stroke or systemic embolism was similar in patients with PAD (RR: 1.19, 95% CI: 0.63–2.22) and without PAD (RR: 0.86, 95% CI : 0.73–1.02). interaction P = 0.34). There was a significant association between major bleeding or NMCR bleeding in patients with PAD treated with rivaroxaban versus warfarin (RR: 1.40, 95% CI: 1.06–1.86) compared with patients without PAD (RR : 1.03, 95% CI: 0.95–1.11). interaction P = 0.037). Patients with PAD in the ROCKET AF group did not have a statistically significantly higher risk of stroke or systemic embolism than patients without PAD, and patients treated with rivaroxaban and warfarin had similar efficacy results. Patients with PAD had a higher risk of major bleeding or NMCR bleeding with rivaroxaban compared with warfarin (interaction P = 0.037). Further studies are needed to confirm this subgroup analysis and determine optimal treatment in this cohort of patients with high-risk AF and PAD.

Management of warfarin therapy is complicated by wide variations in patient response to the drug. Variants in the gene encoding vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1) may influence response to warfarin. We conducted a retrospective study of European American patients receiving long-term maintenance warfarin therapy. Multiple linear regression analysis was used to determine the effect of VKORC1 haplotypes on warfarin dose. We determined VKORC1 haplotype frequencies in African American, European American, and Asian American populations, as well as VKORC1 messenger RNA (mRNA) expression in human liver samples. We identified 10 common noncoding single nucleotide polymorphisms of VKORC1 and defined five major haplotypes. We defined a low-dose haplotype group (A) and a high-dose haplotype group (B). The mean (+/-SE) maintenance dose of warfarin varied significantly between the three haplotype group combinations: 2.7+/-0.2 mg per day for A/A, 4.9+/-0.2 mg per day for A/ B and 6.2 mg per day. +/-0.3 mg per day for B/B (P<0.001). VKORC1 haplotype groups A and B explained approximately 25 percent of the dose difference. Asian Americans had a higher proportion of group A haplotypes, and African Americans had a higher proportion of group B haplotypes. VKORC1 mRNA levels varied depending on the combination of haplotypes. VKORC1 haplotypes can be used to stratify patients into low-, medium-, and high-dose warfarin groups and may explain differences in dose requirements among patients of different backgrounds. The molecular mechanism of warfarin dose response appears to be regulated at the transcriptional level.

Coumarin derivatives such as warfarin are the therapy of choice for long-term treatment and prevention of thromboembolic complications. Coumarins affect blood clotting by inhibiting the vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR) multiprotein complex. This complex converts vitamin K 2,3-epoxide into vitamin K hydroquinone, a cofactor that is required for the post-translational gamma carboxylation of several coagulation factors. Despite extensive efforts, the components of the VCOR complex have never been identified. The complex is thought to be involved in two hereditary human diseases: combined vitamin K-dependent coagulation factor type 2 deficiency (VKCFD2; Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) 607473) and resistance to coumarin-type anticoagulants (warfarin). resistance, WR 122700). Here we identify, using linkage information from three species, the vitamin K epoxide reductase complex subunit 1 (VKORC1) gene, which encodes a small endoplasmic reticulum transmembrane protein. VKORC1 contains missense mutations in both human disease and a warfarin-resistant rat strain. Overexpression of wild-type VKORC1, but not VKORC1 carrying the VKCFD2 mutation, results in a marked increase in VKOR activity, which is sensitive to inhibition by warfarin.

Current dosing algorithms do not take into account genetic and environmental factors when determining the dose of warfarin. This study examined the effects of age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and body size on warfarin dose requirements. We observed 297 patients on stable anticoagulant therapy with a target international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.0 to 3.0. Genetic analysis of CYP2C9 (alleles *2 and *3) and VKORC1 (polymorphism -1639) was performed, and venous INR and plasma concentrations of R- and S-warfarin were determined. The mean daily dose of warfarin was highest in wild-type patients homozygous for CYP2C9 compared with patients with variant alleles *2 and *3 (P < 0.001) and highest in patients with the VKORC1 GG genotype (position -1639) compared with those with GA genotype and AA genotype (P < 0.001). The average daily warfarin dose requirement decreased by 0.5 to 0.7 mg per decade from ages 20 to 90 years. Age, height, and CYP2C9 genotype significantly contributed to S-warfarin clearance and total warfarin clearance, whereas only age and body size significantly affected R-warfarin clearance. A multivariate regression model including the variables age, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genotype, and height produced the best model for estimating warfarin dose (R2 = 55%). Based on the data obtained, a new warfarin dosage regimen was developed. The validity of the dosing regimen was confirmed in a second group of patients receiving warfarin therapy.

Initiating warfarin therapy through trial and error is problematic. Our goal was to develop and validate a pharmacogenetic algorithm. In a derivation cohort of 1015 participants, independent predictors of therapeutic dose were: VKORC1 -1639/3673 G>A polymorphism (-28% per allele), body surface area (BSA) (+11% per 0.25 m2(2)), CYP2C9 (*)3 (-33% per allele), CYP2C9(*)2 (-19% per allele), age (-7% per decade), target international normalized ratio (INR) (+11% per 0.5 unit ). increase), amiodarone use (-22%), smoking status (+10%), race (-9%) and current thrombosis (+7%). This pharmacogenetic equation explained 53-54% of the variability in warfarin dose between the acquisition and validation groups (N = 292). In comparison, the clinical equation explained only 17–22% of dose variability (P < 0.001). In the validation cohort, we prospectively used a pharmacogenetic dosing algorithm in patients starting warfarin therapy, two of whom had major bleeding. To facilitate the use of these pharmacogenetic and clinical algorithms, we have developed a non-profit website, http://www.WarfarinDosing.org.

Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying people who are at greater risk of harm from certain medications. Regular implementation of pharmacogenetic tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The purpose of this review is to systematically review published economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at preventing or reducing the incidence of adverse reactions. We conducted a systematic review of the literature on economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at reducing the incidence of adverse drug reactions. A literature search was conducted using Embase, MEDLINE and the National Health Service (NHS) economic evaluation database using keywords related to pharmacogenetic testing, adverse drug reactions, economic evaluations and pharmaceuticals. Titles were independently screened by two reviewers. Articles considered to meet the inclusion criteria were independently screened by abstract and full texts reviewed. We identified 852 articles, of which 47 met the inclusion criteria. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58:01 ( before taking allopurinol) and CYP2C19 (before treatment with clopidogrel). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptoputine, azathioprine and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (to inform dosing of coumarin derivatives based on genotype), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate) and Leiden factor V test (before treatment) . oral contraception). Testing for A1555G before prescribing aminoglycosides is not cost-effective. Our systematic review found strong evidence for the cost-effectiveness of pre-treatment genotyping for a number of common medications. However, further analysis and/or availability of reliable clinical data is required to make recommendations to others.

This article summarizes the discussions at the 3rd European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Conference on Biomedicine, Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, which took place in June 2010 in Spain. The focus was on practical application in everyday medical practice. We provide practical recommendations for ten different clinical situations that have been approved or not approved by regulatory authorities. We suggest some comments that might accompany the results of these tests, indicating the best drug and the doses that should be prescribed. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, HLA-B*5701-flucloxacillin , SLCO1B1-statins and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. We hope these practical recommendations will help doctors, biologists, scientists and other healthcare professionals order, perform and interpret these genetic tests.

Serious adverse drug reactions represent the sixth leading cause of death in the United States, are the leading cause of drug discontinuation after market launch, and represent a cost of billions of dollars each year in all developed countries. Some of these serious adverse drug reactions can be avoided by systematic screening of pharmacogenomic risk factors. Over the past few years, regulatory agencies have introduced pharmacogenomic labeling for several drugs, but while a priori genetic testing is still encouraged or recommended, it is rarely mandatory due to weak knowledge of evidence-based medicine. Recently published pharmacogenomic randomized controlled trials and ongoing studies will gradually make genotyping tests such as tests for HLA-B*5701 (abacavir), TPMT (6-mercaptopurine), CYP2C9 plus VKORC1 (warfarin) and CYP3A5 (tacrolimus) mandatory. The parallel development of pharmacogenomic bedside tests will certainly lead to the emergence of genetically based prescriptions in everyday medical practice.

Pharmacogenomics seeks to explain individual variability in drug response due to genetic variations. Although technological advances have provided us with relatively simple and cheap genotyping methods, the promise of personalized medicine has not yet lived up to our high expectations. Successful results achieved to date in the field of pharmacogenomics include, but are not limited to, HLA-B*5701 screening to avoid hypersensitivity to the antiretroviral drug abacavir, thiopurine-S-methyltransferase (TPMT) genotyping to avoid thiopuric acid toxicity, and CYP2C9 and genotyping VKORC1 for better dosing of the anticoagulant warfarin. However, few examples of pharmacogenetics have found their way into clinical practice for the treatment of complex diseases. Unfortunately, lack of reproducibility in observational studies involving many genes and diseases appears to be a common pattern in pharmacogenomic studies. In this article, we review some methodological and statistical issues related to study design, gene and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) selection, and data analysis that should be considered in future pharmacogenomic studies. We first discuss some issues related to the design of epidemiological studies specific to pharmacogenomic studies. Second, we describe some of the pros and cons of the candidate gene approach (including gene and SNP selection) and the genome-wide scanning approach. Finally, traditional as well as several innovative approaches to the analysis of large pharmacogenomic data sets are proposed that address the challenges of multiple testing and systems biology in different ways.

Cytochrome P450 2C19 (CYP2C19) is the main (or partial) cause of large differences in the pharmacokinetics of a number of clinically relevant drugs. Based on their ability to metabolize (S)-mephenytoin or other CYP2C19 substrates, individuals can be classified as extensive metabolizers (EM) or poor metabolizers (PM). Eight variant alleles have been identified (from CYP2C19*2 to CYP2C19*8) that predict PM. The distribution of EM and PM genotypes and phenotypes demonstrates wide interethnic differences. Non-genetic factors such as enzyme inhibition and induction, old age and cirrhosis may also modulate CYP2C19 activity. In patients with PM, approximately 80% of doses of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) omeprazole, lansoprazole and pantoprazole are eliminated by CYP2C19, whereas CYP3A is more important in patients with PM. PMs experience five times higher levels of exposure to these drugs than EMs, with further increases occurring during inhibition of alternative metabolic pathways catalyzed by CYP3A in PMs. As a result, PMs with CYP2C19 experience more effective acid suppression and better healing of duodenal and gastric ulcers during treatment with omeprazole and lansoprazole compared to EMs. The pharmacoeconomic value of CYP2C19 genotyping remains unclear. Our calculations indicate that CYP2C19 genotyping could save approximately US$5000 for every 100 Asian patients tested, but not for Caucasian patients. However, genotyping of common CYP2C19 alleles before initiation of PPIs for the treatment of reflux disease and H. pylori infection is a cost-effective tool for determining appropriate treatment duration and dosing regimens. Altering CYP2C19 activity does not appear to increase the risk of adverse drug reactions/PPI interactions. Phenytoin plasma concentrations and toxicity have been shown to be increased in patients taking CYP2C19 inhibitors or having variant alleles, and due to the narrow therapeutic index, genotyping of CYP2C19 in addition to CYP2C9 may be required to optimize the dose of phenytoin. An increased risk of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity is likely in patients whose CYP2C19 and/or CYP2D6 activity is reduced. CYP2C19 is the primary enzyme for the activation of proguanil to cycloguanil, but there is no clinical evidence to suggest that CYP2C19 PMs are at greater risk of failure in the prevention or treatment of malaria. The clearance of diazepam is clearly reduced during PM or when CYP2C19 inhibitors are coadministered, but the clinical consequences are generally minimal. Finally, many studies have attempted to identify the relationship between CYP2C19 genotype and phenotype and susceptibility to xenobiotic-induced diseases, but none are conclusive.

Voriconazole is the treatment of choice for aspergillosis and a new treatment option for candidiasis. The metabolism of voriconazole is affected by liver disease, age, genetic polymorphism of cytochrome CYP2C19 and concomitant medications. Large differences in voriconazole pharmacokinetics may be due to decreased efficacy or toxicity. This study was conducted to evaluate the utility of measuring voriconazole blood levels with individual dose adjustments. A total of 181 high-pressure liquid chromatography measurements were performed in 52 patients over 2388 days of treatment. There was significant variability in voriconazole blood trough levels, ranging from <or=1 mg/L (the minimum inhibitory concentration at which 90% of isolates are susceptible to most fungal pathogens) in 25% of cases to >5.5 mg/L. L (level possibly related to toxicity) in 31% of cases. Failure to respond to therapy was more common in patients with voriconazole levels < or = 1 mg/L (6 [46%] of 13 patients, including 5 patients with aspergillosis, 4 of whom received an average oral dose of 6 mg/L. kg per day) than in patients with voriconazole levels >1 mg/L (15 [12%] of 39 patients; P=0.02). Blood levels >1 mg/L were achieved after voriconazole dose escalation, with complete resolution of infection in all 6 cases. Among 16 patients with trough voriconazole blood levels >5.5 mg/L, 5 patients (31%) experienced encephalopathy, including 4 patients treated intravenously with a mean voriconazole dose of 8 mg/kg per day, whereas none One of the patients with levels <or=5.5 mg/L exhibited neurological toxicity (P=0.002). Combination use of omeprazole may have contributed to voriconazole accumulation in 4 patients. In all cases, cessation of therapy resulted in rapid and complete neurological recovery. Drug monitoring of voriconazole improves the effectiveness and safety of therapy for seriously ill patients with invasive mycoses.

Many drugs, including proton pump inhibitors and some antidepressants, are metabolized by the cytochrome P450 polymorphic enzyme (CYP) 2C19. A significant proportion of extensive metabolizers do not reach appropriate drug levels, and our goal was to investigate any genetic basis. The 5' flanking region of the CYP2C19 gene was sequenced in subjects who were extensive metabolizers of omeprazole, and the phenotype-genotype associations of CYP2C19 were analyzed in Swedish (n = 107) and Ethiopian (n = 126) extensive metabolizers. The relationship of the metabolic ratio of omeprazole (omeprazole/5-hydroxyomeprazole in plasma 3 hours after dosing) with the area under the plasma concentration-time curve was used for predictive studies. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays were performed using human nuclear protein extracts. Liver reporter vector transfection was performed in CD1 mice. We identified a new allele (CYP2C19*17) carrying -806C>T and -3402C>T with a frequency of 18% in both Swedes and Ethiopians and 4% in Chinese. In Swedes, the metabolic rate of omeprazole was higher in subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.50 [interquartile range, 0.37–0.73]) than in subjects homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0.25 [interquartile range, 0.37–0.73]). 0.15-0.33]). (P = 0.010). In Ethiopians, a similar difference in the S/R-mephenytoin ratio was observed between individuals homozygous for CYP2C19*1 (median, 0.20 [interquartile range, 0.12–0.37]) and homozygous for CYP2C19*17 (median, 0. 05 [interquartile range, 0.03-0.06]) (P = 0.013). Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific binding of human liver nuclear proteins to the element bearing -806T, but not -806C. Experiments with a reporter vector showed increased transcriptional activity of the CYP2C19*17 allele in vivo in mice. Predictions indicated that CYP2C19*17 homozygotes would have 35–40% lower plasma concentration-time curve omeprazole area than CYP2C19*1 homozygotes receiving standard doses of omeprazole. CYP2C19*17 is likely to cause therapeutic failure with drug treatments such as proton pump inhibitors and antidepressants.

Human CYP2Cs are an important subfamily of P450 enzymes that metabolize approximately 20% of clinically used drugs. There are four members of the subfamily: CYP2C8, CYP2C9, CYP2C19 and CYP2C18. Of these, CYP2C8, CYP2C9 and CYP2C19 are of clinical importance. CYP2C also metabolizes some endogenous compounds such as arachidonic acid. Each member of this subfamily has been found to be genetically polymorphic. The best known of these polymorphisms is in CYP2C19. Poor metabolizers (PM) of CYP2C19 comprise approximately 3–5% of Caucasians, a similar percentage of African Americans, and 12–100% of Asian groups. The polymorphism affects the metabolism of the anticonvulsant mephenytoin, proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole, the anxiolytic drug diazepam, some antidepressants, and the antimalarial drug proguanil. Toxic effects may occur in PMs exposed to diazepam, and the effectiveness of some proton pump inhibitors may be greater in PMs than in EMs at low doses of these drugs. There are a number of mutant alleles that can be detected using genetic testing. CYP2C9 metabolizes a wide range of drugs, including the anticoagulant warfarin, antidiabetic agents such as tolbutamide, anticonvulsants such as phenytoin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. The frequency of functional polymorphisms is much lower and is 1/250 in Caucasians and lower in Asians. However, the clinical consequences of these rarer polymorphisms can be severe. Severe and life-threatening bleeding episodes have been reported in CYP2C9 PMs exposed to warfarin. Phenytoin has been reported to cause severe toxicity in PM. New polymorphisms have been discovered in CYP2C8, which metabolizes taxol (paclitaxel). Genetic testing is available for all known variant alleles of CYP2C.

Pharmacogenetics offers the potential to improve health outcomes by identifying people who are at greater risk of harm from certain medications. Regular implementation of pharmacogenetic tests requires evidence of their cost-effectiveness. The purpose of this review is to systematically review published economic evaluations of pharmacogenetic tests aimed at preventing or reducing the incidence of adverse reactions. There was evidence to support the cost-effectiveness of testing for HLA-B*57:01 (before abacavir), HLA-B*15:02 and HLA-A*31:01 (before carbamazepine), HLA-B*58:01 ( before taking allopurinol) and CYP2C19 (before treatment with clopidogrel). Economic evidence was inconclusive for TPMT (before treatment with 6-mercaptoputine, azathioprine and cisplatin), CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (to inform dosing of coumarin derivatives based on genotype), MTHFR (before treatment with methotrexate) and Leiden factor V test (before treatment) . oral contraception). This article summarizes the discussions at the 3rd European Science Foundation-University of Barcelona (ESF-UB) Conference on Biomedicine, Pharmacogenetics and Pharmacogenomics, which took place in June 2010 in Spain. The focus was on practical application in everyday medical practice. We provide practical recommendations for ten different clinical situations that have been approved or not approved by regulatory authorities. We suggest some comments that might accompany the results of these tests, indicating the best drug and the doses that should be prescribed. Examples discussed include KRAS, cetuximab, panitumumab, EGFR-gefitinib, CYP2D6-tamoxifen, TPMT-azathioprine-6-mercaptopurine, VKORC1/CYP2C9-warfarin, CYP2C19-clopidogrel, HLA-B*5701-abacavir, HLA-B*5701-flucloxacillin , SLCO1B1-statins and CYP3A5-tacrolimus. During HIV infection and/or antiretroviral therapy (ART), monocytes and macrophages exhibit a wide range of dysfunctions that contribute significantly to HIV pathogenesis and therapy-related complications. However, the molecular components that contribute to these dysfunctions remain elusive. We therefore used a parallel approach of genome-wide microarray analysis and targeted gene expression profiling on monocytes from patients at different stages of HIV infection and/or ART to further characterize these dysfunctions. Processes involved in apoptosis, cell cycle, lipid metabolism, proteasome function, protein transport, and transcriptional regulation have been identified as areas of monocyte dysfunction in HIV infection. The individual genes potentially contributing to these monocyte dysfunctions include several novel factors. One of these is the adipocytokine NAMPT/visfatin, which we show is capable of inhibiting HIV early in its life cycle. Approximately half of all genes identified were restored to control levels on ART, while the remainder represented persistent dysregulation. In addition, several candidate biomarkers (notably CCL1 and CYP2C19) have been proposed for the development of hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir. Previously described areas of monocyte dysfunction in HIV infection were confirmed and new themes were identified. In addition, individual genes associated with these dysfunctions and ART-related disorders have been identified. These genes provide a useful basis for further functional studies regarding the contribution of monocytes/macrophages to HIV pathogenesis. One such gene, NAMPT/visfatin, represents a possible new HIV restriction factor.

Pharmacogenomic studies contribute to our understanding of interindividual differences in response to antiretroviral drugs. Genetic polymorphisms in major histocompatibility complex genes predict the likelihood of hypersensitivity reactions in individuals prescribed abacavir and possibly nevirapine. Recent studies have shown that CYP2B6 gene polymorphisms are associated with higher plasma concentrations of efavirenz and increased central nervous system side effects of efavirenz. Polymorphisms in the MDR1 gene encoding the drug pump, P-glycoprotein, may predict nevirapine-associated hepatotoxicity and long-term virological response to efavirenz. CYP2C19 polymorphism predicts nelfinavir plasma levels and possibly the risk of virological failure with this drug. European mitochondrial haplogroup may predict an increased risk of peripheral neuropathy associated with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor use. Increasing and refining knowledge of the relationship between human genetics and response to antiretroviral drugs may ultimately allow genotyping-based individualization of therapy. This article summarizes a presentation by David Haas, MD, on HIV therapy and pharmacogenomics given at the International AIDS Society USA course in Atlanta in March 2005.

Several long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) are natural ligands of the non-ruminant peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPARG), which, along with its lipogenic target genes, is activated in bovine mammary tissue during lactation. Thus, PPARG may represent an important control point for fat synthesis in cow's milk. We tested lipogenic gene network expression by qPCR of 19 genes in bovine mammary epithelial cells cultured with 16:0, 18:0, cis-9 18:1, trans-10 18:1, trans-10, cis -12 18:2 [t10c12 conjugated linoleic acid (CLA)], 20:5, ethanol (control) and the PPARG agonist rosiglitazone (ROSI). Triplicate cultures were maintained for 12 h with 50 μM ROSI or 100 μM LCFA. Responses common to 16:0 and 18:0 relative to controls included significantly greater expression of INSIG1 (+298%, +92%), AGPAT6 (+137%, +169%), FABP3 (+755%, +338%) . ) and FABP4 (+171%, 157%). This was combined with greater formation of intracellular lipid droplets and ACSS2, LPIN1, SCD, and SREBF2 mRNA in response to 16:0, as well as an increase in DGAT1 and THRSP from 18:0. Trans-10 18:1 and t10c12 CLA reduced the expression of FASN (-60%, -31%), SCD (-100%, -357%) and SREBF1 (-49%, -189%). In addition, t10c12 CLA suppressed the expression of ACSS2, FABP3, INSIG1, SREBF2, and THRSP. SREBF1 expression was lower in cis-9 18:1 (-140%) and 20:5 (-125%) compared to control. This latter LCFA also reduced the expression of SCD, SREBF2, and LPL. No effect of LCFA or ROSI on PPARG was observed, but ROSI increased (+39% to +269%) the expression of ACACA, FASN, LPIN1, AGPAT6, DGAT1, SREBF1, SREBF2, and INSIG1. Thus, these genes are putative target genes of PPARG in bovine mammary gland cells. This is the first report demonstrating a direct effect of trans-10 18:1 on lipogenic gene expression in bovine mammary gland cells. Coordinated activation of lipogenic gene networks in response to ROSI and saturated LCFA supports PPARG activation in regulating fat synthesis in bovine milk.

In adipose tissue, muscle, liver, and macrophages, nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-γ (PPAR-γ) signaling is a determinant of insulin sensitivity, and this receptor mediates the insulin-sensitizing effects of thiazolidinediones (TZDs). Because PPAR-γ is also expressed in neurons, we generated neuron-specific Pparg knockout mice (brain-derived Pparg knockout (BKO)) to determine whether PPAR-γ signaling in neurons promotes weight gain or insulin sensitivity. During high-fat diet (HFD) feeding, food intake decreased and energy expenditure increased in Pparg-BKO mice compared with Pparg(f/f) mice, resulting in decreased weight gain. Pparg-BKO mice also responded better to leptin administration than Pparg(f/f) mice. When treated with rosiglitazone TZD, Pparg-BKO mice were resistant to rosiglitazone-induced hyperphagia and weight gain and, compared with rosiglitazone-treated Pparg(f/f) mice, showed only modest improvements in glucose metabolism. Hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp studies showed that the increase in hepatic insulin sensitivity induced by rosiglitazone treatment during HFD feeding was completely abolished in Pparg-BKO mice, and this effect was due to the inability of rosiglitazone to improve insulin receptor signaling in the liver. We conclude that excess weight gain induced by HFD feeding is partially dependent on the effect of PPAR-γ neuronal signaling to limit thermogenesis and increase food intake. Neuronal PPAR-γ signaling is also required for the sensitizing effect of TZD on insulin in the liver.

Nuclear hormone receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR gamma) is an important regulator of lipid and glucose homeostasis and cellular differentiation. In vitro and in vivo studies on many cell types have shown that activation of PPAR-gamma can reduce cell proliferation. Here we show that PPAR gamma activation is sufficient to reduce proliferation of cultured insulinoma cell lines. We created a mouse model in which PPARG gene expression in beta cells was ablated (beta gamma KO mice), and these mice showed significant islet hyperplasia on a regular diet. Interestingly, the normal increase in beta cell mass that occurs in control mice in response to a high-fat diet was markedly blunted in these animals. Despite this change in beta cell mass, no effect on glucose homeostasis was noted in beta gamma KO mice. Additionally, although thiazolidinediones enhanced insulin secretion from cultured wild-type islets, administration of rosiglitazone to insulin-resistant control and beta-gamma KO mice showed that PPAR-gamma in beta cells was not required for the antidiabetic effects of these compounds. These data demonstrate a critical physiological role for PPAR gamma function in beta cell proliferation and also indicate that the mechanisms that control beta cell hyperplasia in obesity are different from those that regulate initial cell mass in the islet.

Nocturnine (NOC) is a circadian-regulated protein belonging to a family of yeast transcription factors involved in the cellular response to nutrient status. In mammals, NOC functions as a deadenylase but lacks a transcriptional activation domain. It is highly expressed in bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs), hepatocytes and adipocytes. In BMSCs exposed to the PPAR-gamma (peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma) agonist rosiglitazone, Noc expression increased 30-fold. We previously reported that Noc(-/-) mice had low body temperature, were protected from diet-induced obesity, and, most importantly, exhibited a lack of Pparg circadian rhythmicity on a high-fat diet. Consistent with its role in influencing BMSC distribution, Noc(-/-) mice have reduced bone marrow adiposity and high bone mass. Similarly, overexpression of NOC enhances adipogenesis in 3T3-L1 cells but negatively regulates osteogenesis in MC3T3-E1 cells. NOC and the mutated form lacking deadenylase activity bind to PPAR-gamma and markedly enhance PPAR-gamma transcriptional activity. Both WT and mutant NOC promote PPAR-gamma nuclear translocation. Importantly, NOC-mediated nuclear translocation of PPAR-gamma is blocked by a short peptide fragment of NOC, which inhibits its physical interaction with PPAR-gamma. The inhibitory effect of this NOC peptide was partially reversed by rosiglitazone, suggesting that the effect of NOC on PPAR-gamma nuclear translocation may be independent of ligand-mediated PPAR-gamma activation. Overall, Noc plays a unique role in regulating mesenchymal stem cell lineage distribution by modulating PPAR-gamma activity through nuclear translocation. These data illustrate a unique mechanism by which a nutrient-sensing gene influences BMSC differentiation, adipogenesis, and ultimately body composition.

In this study, we aimed to test the hypothesis that genetic factors may influence antidepressant drug response to fluoxetine. The study focused on seven candidate serotonergic pathway genes involved in serotonin synthesis, transport, recognition and degradation. Our clinical sample consisted of 96 patients with unipolar major depression treated with fluoxetine, with response variables assessed after a 12-week study. Patient data was also collected to study drug response patterns. Using a high-throughput single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotyping platform and capillary electrophoresis, we genotyped patients for 110 SNPs and four repeat polymorphisms located in seven candidate genes (HTR1A, HTR2A, HTR2C, MAOA, SLC6A4, TPH1, and TPH2). Statistical tests performed included single-locus-haplotype association tests and linkage disequilibrium (LD) assessment. In a sample with 20 random SNPs using a genomic control procedure, little evidence of population stratification was observed. Our most intriguing finding included three SNPs in the TPH1 gene and one SNP in the SLC6A4 gene that showed significant single-locus association when comparing response to fluoxetine with non-response (P = 0.02–0.04). All odds ratios indicated an increased risk of failure to respond to fluoxetine. When comparing specific response, nonspecific response, and no response, three SNPs in the TPH2 gene (P=0.02-0.04) were positively associated and one SNP in the HTR2A gene (P=0.02) was negatively associated. When comparing the specific response with the nonspecific response, we found significant negative associations in three SNPs of the HTR2A gene (P=0.001-0.03) and two SNPs of the MAOA gene (P=0.03-0.05). We observed variable, albeit strong, LD in each gene and an unexpectedly low number of putative haplotypes formed from tagged SNPs. Significant haplotype associations were found in all genes except HTR1A and HTR2C. Although these data should be interpreted with caution due to the small sample size, these results indicate the involvement of TPH1 and SLC6A4 in the overall response, and HTR2A, TPH2 and MAOA in the specificity of the response to fluoxetine. Interestingly, we observed that a number of less frequent alleles of many SNP markers were associated with nonresponse and nonspecific phenotypes.

The serotonin transporter is a molecular target of many antidepressants, and the gene (SLC6A4) encoding this protein is associated with response to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). We sought to further test the hypothesis that SLC6A4 is associated with response to SSRIs by resequencing this gene in subjects with major depression. The sequence of all exons, parts of all introns, and a promoter region containing a polymorphism of polymorphic repeats (HTTLPR) previously associated with response to SSRIs was determined for 96 subjects, and variants were tested for association with response to fluoxetine treatment. We screened a total of 712 kb of sequence and found 27 SLC6A4 variants, 21 of which have not been previously described. Seventeen were found on one chromosome each, including three of the five exonic variants. One polymorphism (rs25531), located immediately upstream of HTTLPR, has shown evidence of association with treatment response, and biochemical experiments have shown that this polymorphism alters the binding of nuclear extracts to the transcription factor activator protein 2 consensus sequence, which is believed to be a critical factor in regulation of neural gene expression in mammals. These results support an association between response to SSRIs and deoxyribonucleic acid variations at the serotonin transporter locus. We also identified a potentially important functional variant that contributes to this association and a possible biological mechanism that may mediate its effect.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by repetitive and intrusive thoughts that cause distress (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors or mental actions that a person feels compelled to perform (compulsions). OCD has a partial genetic basis. OCD is treated with powerful serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SRI) drugs (clomipramine (Anafranil), fluvoxamine (Luvox), fluoxetine (Prozac), sertraline (Zoloft) and paroxetine (Paxil)), which act on the serotonin transport protein. uniquely effective. Recently, a polymorphism in the promoter region of the gene (SLC6A4) encoding this protein was reported to affect protein expression and to be associated with measures of anxiety and depression, as well as autism (using the family-controlled transmission disequilibrium test (TDT) method). . In summary, SLC6A4 has strong a priori support for a potential impact on OCD risk: the protein it encodes is a drug target; gene polymorphism affects function; and polymorphisms have been shown to be associated with behavioral phenotypes. We used TDT with a set of 34 European-American family trios, 30 unrelated and four taken from an extended pedigree, to test for linkage disequilibrium between OCD and alleles at the polymorphic SLC6A4 promoter locus. Of the 35 heterozygous parents, 24 transmitted the “l” allele of SLC6A4 and 11 transmitted the “s” allele (chi 2 TDT = 4.83; P < 0.03). Considering only 13 patients who did not respond to the SRI drug, there were 13 heterozygous parents, of whom 10 transmitted the “l” allele and three transmitted the “s” allele (chi 2 TDT = 3.77; P < 0.052). These data provide preliminary support for the association and linkage disequilibrium between the SLC6A4 'l' allele and OCD.

Recent important results from studies of SLC6A4 and its corresponding protein, serotonin (5-HT) transporter (SERT) in humans, rodents, and non-human primates indicate that combinations of SLC6A4 noncoding 5'-UTR, 3'-UTR and intronic regions plus coding variants acting together can alter 5HT transport 40-fold in vitro. In vivo, SLC6A4 variants in humans and other species result in marked physiological changes, despite attenuated neurodevelopmental adaptations in 5-HT receptors as well as compensatory changes in 5-HT synthesis and metabolism. SLC6A4 polymorphisms are associated with differences in emotional, endocrine and personality characteristics, as well as with many diseases. This gene, in combination with gene×gene (G×G) and gene×environment (G×E) interactions, however, remains incompletely understood, and some conclusions about the association remain controversial. Given its primary importance in the regulation and function of the entire serotonergic system (as evidenced by the effects of SERT-mediated reuptake inhibition by SRIs such as fluoxetine in humans, as well as genetically engineered alterations in mice and rats), it is likely that SLC6A4 and SERT will remain areas of increased interest in our field's efforts to better understand and treat 5-HT disorders.

Hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir are closely associated with the presence of the HLA-B*5701 allele. The aim of this study was to determine the effectiveness of prospective screening for HLA-B*5701 in preventing hypersensitivity reactions to abacavir. This double-blind, prospective, randomized study enrolled 1,956 patients from 19 countries infected with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 who had not previously received abacavir. We randomly assigned patients to undergo prospective HLA-B*5701 screening with exclusion of HLA-B*5701-positive patients from abacavir treatment (prospective screening group) or to undergo the standard abacavir approach without prospective treatment. HLA-B*5701 screening (control group). All patients who started treatment with abacavir were monitored for 6 weeks. To provide immunological confirmation and increase the specificity of the clinical diagnosis of hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir, we performed epidermal patch testing using abacavir. The prevalence of HLA-B*5701 was 5.6% (109 of 1956 patients). Among patients receiving abacavir, 72% were men, 84% were white, and 18% had not previously received antiretroviral therapy. Screening eliminated immunologically confirmed hypersensitivity reactions (0% in the prospective screening group vs. 2.7% in the control group, P<0.001), with a negative predictive value of 100% and a positive predictive value of 47.9%. Hypersensitivity reaction was clinically diagnosed in 93 patients, and the incidence in the prospective screening group (3.4%) was significantly lower than in the control group (7.8%) (P<0.001). HLA-B*5701 screening reduced the risk of hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. In a predominantly white population, as in this study, 94% of patients do not carry the HLA-B*5701 allele and are at low risk of a hypersensitivity reaction to abacavir. Our results indicate that a pharmacogenetic test can be used to prevent drug-specific toxicity. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00340080.)

The use of abacavir, a potent HIV-1 nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor, is complicated in approximately 5% of cases by a potentially life-threatening hypersensitivity syndrome. Genetic factors influencing the immune response to abacavir may contribute to susceptibility. We sought to find an association between MHC alleles and hypersensitivity to abacavir in HIV-1-positive individuals treated with abacavir. MHC region typing was performed on the first 200 participants in the Western Australia HIV Cohort Study exposed to abacavir. Definite hypersensitivity to abacavir was identified in 18 cases and excluded in 167 individuals who took the drug for more than 6 weeks (abacavir tolerance). Fifteen people had some symptoms but did not meet the criteria for abacavir hypersensitivity. P values ​​were adjusted for comparisons of multiple HLA alleles (p(c)) by multiplying the original p value by the estimated number of HLA alleles present at the loci examined. HLA-B*5701 was present in 14 (78%) of 18 abacavir hypersensitive patients and four (2%) of 167 abacavir tolerant patients (odds ratio 117 [95% CI 29-481], p(c) <0.0001), and the combination of HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 was found in 13 (72%) hypersensitive and five (3%) tolerant patients (73 [20-268], p(c)<0.0001). HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 were present in combination in 13 (72%) hypersensitive patients and in none of the tolerant patients (822 [43–15,675], p(c)<0.0001) . Other MHC markers also present in the ancestral haplotype 57.1, to which the above three markers belong, confirmed the presence of haplotype-specific linkage disequilibrium and mapped potential susceptibility loci to the region restricted by C4A6 and HLA-C. In the entire abacavir-exposed cohort (n = 200), the presence of HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7 and HLA-DQ3 had a positive predictive value for hypersensitivity of 100% and a negative predictive value of 97%. Genetic predisposition to hypersensitivity to abacavir is transmitted in the hereditary haplotype 57.1. In our population, withholding abacavir in patients with HLA-B*5701, HLA-DR7, and HLA-DQ3 should reduce the prevalence of hypersensitivity from 9% to 2.5% without inappropriately withholding abacavir from any patient.

Hypersensitivity to abacavir is observed in about 4% of patients receiving the drug for HIV-1 infection. We conducted a retrospective case-control study to identify multiple markers in the vicinity of HLA-B associated with hypersensitivity reactions.
