HLA-B57 was present in 39 (46%) of 84 patients compared with four (4%) of 113 control patients (p<0, small midpoint0001). However, due to the small number of women and other ethnic groups participating, these results mainly concern white men. The lower sensitivity of HLA-B57 for predicting abacavir hypersensitivity found in this study compared with the previous report highlights that the predictive value of the markers will vary among populations. Clinical monitoring and treatment of hypersensitivity reactions in patients receiving abacavir should remain unchanged.

Human leukocyte antigens (HLA) are highly polymorphic proteins that initiate immunity by presenting pathogen-derived peptides to T cells. HLA polymorphisms are mainly localized in the antigen-binding cleft, thereby diversifying the repertoire of self- and pathogen-derived peptide antigens selected by different HLA allotypes. An increasing number of immunological drug reactions, including abacavir hypersensitivity syndrome (AHS) and carbamazepine-induced Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), are associated with specific HLA alleles. However, little is known about the mechanisms underlying these associations, including AHS, the prototypical HLA-associated drug reaction occurring exclusively in individuals with the common histocompatibility allele HLA-B*57:01 and with a relative risk greater than 1000 (refs 6, 7) . We show that unmodified abacavir binds noncovalently to HLA-B*57:01, positioning across the bottom of the antigen-binding cleft and reaching the F pocket where the carboxy-terminal tryptophan typically anchors HLA-B-bound peptides. *57:01. Abacavir binds to HLA-B*57:01 with exceptional specificity, altering the shape and chemistry of the antigen-binding cleft, thereby altering the repertoire of endogenous peptides that can bind HLA-B*57:01. Thus, abacavir drives the selection of new endogenous peptides, causing noticeable changes in “immunological self-awareness.” The resulting peptidocentric “altered self” activates abacavir-specific T cells, thereby causing polyclonal activation of CD8 T cells and a systemic response manifesting as AGS. We also show that carbamazepine, a widely used antiepileptic drug that causes hypersensitivity reactions in people with HLA-B*15:02, binds to this allotype, causing changes in the repertoire of self-peptides presented. Our results both highlight the importance of HLA polymorphisms in the evolution of pharmacogenomics and provide a general mechanism for some of the growing number of HLA-linked hypersensitivities associated with small molecule drugs.

Advances in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, especially with regard to tyrosine kinase inhibitors, require regular updating of treatment concepts and methods. The European LeukemiaNet expert panel reviewed previous and new research to update recommendations made in 2009. We recommend imatinib, nilotinib, or dasatinib as initial treatment. Response is assessed using standardized real-world quantitative polymerase chain reaction and/or cytogenetics at 3, 6 and 12 months. BCR-ABL1 transcript levels ≤10% at 3 months, <1% at 6 months, and ≤0.1% at 12 months define optimal response, whereas >10% at 6 months and >1% at 12 months define failure requiring change in treatment. Similarly, partial cytogenetic response (PCyR) at 3 months and complete cytogenetic response (CCyR) starting at 6 months define optimal response, whereas absence of CyR (Philadelphia chromosome positive [Ph+] >95%) at 3 months is less than PCyR at 6 months. months. months or less of CCyR starting at 12 months defines failure. Between optimal and failure, there is an intermediate warning zone that requires more frequent monitoring. Similar definitions are given for response to second-line therapy. Special recommendations are given for patients in the accelerated and blast phases, as well as for allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Patients with an optimal response should continue therapy indefinitely with close monitoring or may be enrolled in controlled studies to discontinue treatment once a deeper molecular response has been achieved.

Although the role of Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in embryonic patterning is well established, its functions in the renewal and maintenance of adult tissues remain unclear, and the relationship of these functions to cancer development is uncertain. Here we show that loss of Smoothened (Smo), an important component of the Hh pathway, impairs hematopoietic stem cell turnover and reduces the induction of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) by the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein. Loss of Smo causes depletion of CML stem cells—the cells that propagate leukemia—while constitutively active Smo increases the number of CML stem cells and accelerates the disease. As a possible mechanism of action of Smo, we show that the cell fate determinant Numb, which depletes CML stem cells, is increased in the absence of Smo activity. Moreover, pharmacological inhibition of Hh signaling impairs not only the spread of wild-type BCR-ABL1-driven CML, but also the growth of imatinib-resistant CML in mice and humans. These data indicate that Hh pathway activity is required for the maintenance of normal and neoplastic hematopoietic stem cells and raise the possibility that drug resistance and disease relapse associated with imatinib treatment for CML could be avoided by targeting this important pathway for stem cell maintenance .

There is significant variability in the level of molecular responses achieved with imatinib therapy in patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These differences may be the result of different adherence to therapy. Eighty-seven patients with chronic phase CML treated with imatinib 400 mg/day for an average of 59.7 months (range, 25 to 104 months) who achieved a complete cytogenetic response were monitored for adherence over a 3-month period. using microelectronic monitoring. device. Adherence was correlated with the level of molecular response. Other factors that could influence the results were also analyzed. The mean adherence rate was 98% (range, 24% to 104%). Twenty-three patients (26.4%) had <or=90% adherence; 12 of these patients (14%) had <or= 80% adherence. There was a strong correlation between the rate of adherence (<or=90% or >90%) and the 6-year probability of a 3-log decline (also known as major molecular response [MMR]) of BCR-ABL1 transcripts (28.4%). v 94.5%; P < 0.001), as well as complete molecular response (CMR; 0% v 43.8%; P = 0.002). Multivariate analysis identified adherence (relative risk [RR] 11.7; P = 0.001) and human molecular organic cation transporter-1 expression (HR 1.79; P = 0.038) as the only independent predictors of MMR. Adherence was the only independent predictor of CMR. No molecular responses were observed when adherence was < or = 80% (P < 0.001). Patients whose imatinib doses were increased had poor adherence (86.4%). In the latter group, medication adherence was the only independent predictor of failure to achieve MMR (RR 17.66; P = 0.006). In patients with CML treated with imatinib for several years, poor adherence to treatment may be the main reason for failure to achieve an adequate molecular response.

Imatinib, a selective BCR-ABL1 kinase inhibitor, has improved the prognosis of patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). We performed an efficacy and safety analysis based on more than 10 years of follow-up in patients with CML who received imatinib as initial therapy. In this open-label, multicenter, crossover study, we randomized patients with newly diagnosed chronic-phase CML to receive either imatinib or interferon alfa plus cytarabine. Long-term analyzes included overall survival, response to treatment, and serious adverse events. The average follow-up period was 10.9 years. Given the high crossover rate among patients who were randomized to interferon alfa plus cytarabine (65.6%) and the short duration of therapy before switching in these patients (median 0.8 years), the current analysis focused on patients who were randomized assigned to receive imatinib. Among patients in the imatinib group, the estimated overall survival at 10 years was 83.3%. Approximately half of the patients (48.3%) randomized to receive imatinib completed study imatinib treatment, and 82.8% had a complete cytogenetic response. Serious adverse events considered by investigators to be related to imatinib were rare and most often occurred during the first year of treatment. Nearly 11 years of follow-up showed that the effectiveness of imatinib was maintained over time and that long-term use of imatinib was not associated with unacceptable cumulative or late toxic effects. (Funded by Novartis Pharmaceuticals; ClinicalTrials.gov IRIS numbers NCT00006343 and NCT00333840.)

The HER2 gene, which encodes the HER2 growth factor receptor, is amplified and HER2 is overexpressed in 25 to 30 percent of breast cancers, increasing tumor aggressiveness. We assessed the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab, a recombinant anti-HER2 monoclonal antibody, in women with metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We randomly assigned 234 patients to receive standard chemotherapy alone and 235 patients to receive standard chemotherapy plus trastuzumab. Patients who had not previously received adjuvant (postoperative) anthracycline therapy were treated with doxorubicin (or epirubicin in the case of 36 women) and cyclophosphamide (138 women) or trastuzumab (143 women) alone. Patients previously treated with an adjuvant anthracycline were treated with paclitaxel alone (96 women) or paclitaxel with trastuzumab (92 women). The addition of trastuzumab to chemotherapy was associated with longer time to disease progression (median 7.4 vs. 4.6 months; P<0.001), higher objective response rate (50 percent vs. 32 percent, P<0.001), longer duration of response (median 9.1 vs. 6.1 months; P<0.001), lower 1-year mortality rate (22 percent vs. 33 percent, P=0.008), better survival (median survival 25.1 vs. 20.3 months; P=0.01) and a 20 percent reduction in the risk of death. The most important adverse event was New York Heart Association class III or IV cardiac dysfunction, which occurred in 27 percent of the anthracycline, cyclophosphamide, and trastuzumab group; 8 percent of the group received anthracycline and cyclophosphamide only; 13 percent of the group received paclitaxel and trastuzumab; and 1 percent of the group receiving paclitaxel alone. Although cardiotoxicity was potentially severe and in some cases life-threatening, symptoms generally improved with standard medical treatment. Trastuzumab increases the clinical benefit of first-line chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2.

Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody against human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2; also known as ERBB2), has been studied in combination with chemotherapy for the first-line treatment of HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. ToGA (trastuzumab in gastric cancer) was an open-label, international, phase 3 randomized controlled trial conducted at 122 centers in 24 countries. Patients with gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer were eligible for inclusion if their tumors demonstrated overexpression of HER2 protein by immunohistochemistry or gene amplification by fluorescence in situ hybridization. Participants were randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive a chemotherapy regimen consisting of capecitabine plus cisplatin or fluorouracil plus cisplatin every 3 weeks for six cycles or chemotherapy in combination with intravenous trastuzumab. Allocation was performed by block randomization stratified by Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group performance status, chemotherapy regimen, disease extent, primary cancer site, and disease measurability implemented using a central interactive voice recognition system. The primary endpoint was overall survival in all randomized patients who received at least one study drug. This study is registered at ClinicalTrials.gov under number NCT01041404. 594 patients were randomized to study treatment (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, n=298; chemotherapy alone, n=296), of whom 584 patients were included in the primary analysis (n=294; n=290). Median follow-up was 18.6 months (IQR 11–25) in the trastuzumab plus chemotherapy group and 17.1 months (9–25) in the chemotherapy alone group. Median overall survival was 13.8 months (95% CI 12–16) in patients receiving trastuzumab plus chemotherapy compared with 11.1 months (10–13) in patients receiving chemotherapy alone (hazard ratio 0.74 ; 95% CI 0.60–0.91; p = 0.0046). The most common adverse events in both groups were nausea (trastuzumab plus chemotherapy, 197 [67%] vs. chemotherapy alone, 184 [63%]), vomiting (147 [50%] vs. 134 [46%]), and neutropenia (157 [53%] vs. 165 [57%]). The rates of overall grade 3 or 4 adverse events (201 [68%] vs. 198 [68%]) and cardiac adverse events (17 [6%] vs. 18 [6%]) did not differ between groups. Trastuzumab in combination with chemotherapy can be considered as a new standard treatment option for patients with HER2-positive advanced gastric or gastroesophageal junction cancer. F. Hoffmann-La Roche.

We present the pooled results of two studies that compared adjuvant chemotherapy with or without concurrent trastuzumab in women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer. The National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project study B-31 compared doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by paclitaxel every 3 weeks (arm 1) with the same regimen plus 52 weeks of trastuzumab starting with the first dose of paclitaxel (arm 2). The North Central Cancer Treatment Group trial N9831 compared three treatment regimens: doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide followed by weekly paclitaxel (arm A), the same regimen followed by trastuzumab for 52 weeks after paclitaxel (arm B), and the same regimen plus 52 weeks. initiation of treatment with trastuzumab. simultaneously with paclitaxel (group C). The studies were amended to include a conjoint analysis comparing Groups 1 and A (control group) with Groups 2 and C (trastuzumab group). Group B was excluded because trastuzumab was not coadministered with paclitaxel. By March 15, 2005, 394 events (recurrence, second primary cancer, or death before recurrence) had been reported, prompting the first planned interim analysis. Of these, 133 were in the trastuzumab group and 261 in the control group (hazard ratio, 0.48; P<0.0001). This result crossed the early stop border. The absolute difference in disease-free survival between the trastuzumab group and the control group was 12 percent at three years. Treatment with trastuzumab was associated with a 33 percent reduction in the risk of death (P=0.015). The cumulative incidence of class III or IV congestive heart failure or death from cardiac causes in the trastuzumab group at three years was 4.1 percent in Study B-31 and 2.9 percent in Study N9831. Trastuzumab combined with paclitaxel after doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide improves outcomes among women with surgically resected HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov numbers: NCT00004067 and NCT00005970.)

Trastuzumab, a recombinant anti-HER2 monoclonal antibody, has clinical activity in advanced breast cancer that overexpresses HER2. We examined its effectiveness and safety after early breast cancer removal and completion of chemotherapy. This international multicenter randomized trial compared one or two years of trastuzumab every three weeks with observation in patients with HER2-positive and either node-negative or node-positive breast cancer who had completed locoregional therapy and received at least four cycles of neoadjuvant or neoadjuvant therapy. adjuvant chemotherapy. Data were available for 1694 women randomized to two years of trastuzumab, 1694 women assigned to one year of trastuzumab, and 1693 women undergoing observation. We report here only the results of trastuzumab treatment at one year or follow-up. At the first planned interim analysis (median follow-up of one year), 347 events (breast cancer recurrence, contralateral breast cancer, second non-malignant breast disease, or death) were observed: 127 events in the trastuzumab group and 220 in the observation group. group. The unadjusted hazard ratio for an event in the trastuzumab group compared with the observation group was 0.54 (95% confidence interval, 0.43 to 0.67; P < 0.0001 by log-rank test, crossing the intermediate analysis limit), which represents an absolute benefit in terms of disease-free survival at two years of 8.4 percentage points. Overall survival was not significantly different between the two groups (29 deaths with trastuzumab versus 37 with observation). Severe cardiotoxicity occurred in 0.5 percent of women receiving trastuzumab. One year of trastuzumab treatment after adjuvant chemotherapy significantly improves disease-free survival among women with HER2-positive breast cancer. (ClinicalTrials.gov number, NCT00045032.)

The clinical success of selective kinase inhibitors such as imatinib and erlotinib as therapeutic agents in several human cancers has generated significant interest in further development and clinical testing of such inhibitors in a wide range of malignancies. Although most of these efforts have focused on receptor tyrosine kinases, including the EGFR receptor, HER2, PDGF receptor, c-KIT, and MET, serine/threonine kinase inhibitors are also beginning to emerge in the discovery process. Among these kinases, the RAF and MEK kinases have received considerable attention, largely due to the relatively high frequency of activating mutations in RAS (approximately 20% of all human cancers), an upstream activator of the well-known RAF-MEK-ERK signaling cascade. , as well as frequent activating mutations of BRAF kinase (approximately 7% of all human cancers). Here we summarize the current state of development of kinase inhibitors targeting this signaling pathway, some of which have already demonstrated favorable toxicity profiles as well as promising activity in early-stage clinical trials.

Targeted therapy using compounds that inhibit a specific target molecule represents a new perspective in cancer treatment. Unlike traditional chemotherapy, which acts on all dividing cells, causing toxic effects and damage to normal tissues, targeted drugs allow a more specific effect on subpopulations of cells directly involved in tumor progression. Molecules that control cell proliferation and death, such as receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) for growth factors, are among the best targets for this type of therapeutic approach. Currently, two classes of compounds that target RTK are used in clinical practice: monoclonal antibodies and tyrosine kinase inhibitors. The era of targeted therapy began with the approval of trastuzumab, an anti-HER2 monoclonal antibody, for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer, and imatinib, a small tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting BCR-Abl, for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia. Despite initial enthusiasm for the effectiveness of these treatments, clinicians soon had to confront the problem of relapse, as cancer patients almost always developed drug resistance, often due to activation of alternative RTK pathways. From this perspective, the rationale behind drug targeting changes radically. In the past, much of the effort has been focused on developing highly specific inhibitors targeting single RTKs. There is now general agreement that molecules that simultaneously target multiple RTKs may be more effective than single-target agents. With the recent FDA approval of sorafenib and sunitinib, which target VEGFR, PDGFR, FLT-3, and c-Kit, another scenario has emerged in which a new generation of anticancer drugs is capable of inhibiting more than one pathway. , will likely play a major role.

The emerging field of personalized medicine plays an increasingly important role in the prevention, diagnosis, prognosis and therapy of cancer. Its importance in clinical management is demonstrated by the recent introduction into routine clinical practice of various individualized molecular targeted therapies with increased efficacy and/or decreased toxicity. Identification of cancer susceptibility genes, such as the BRCA genes in breast cancer, allows screening programs to identify patients “at risk” for developing cancer and helps them make decisions about individual risk-modifying behaviors. Personalized medicine is also playing an increasingly important role in cancer treatment. It is becoming increasingly clear that there are molecularly distinct subtypes of various common cancers, and each subtype requires different therapeutic approaches, such as the use of monoclonal antibodies (trastuzumab and cetuximab) in HER2-positive breast cancer and KRAS wild-type colorectal cancer. cancer; Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (imatinib, gefitinib, erlotinib and crizotinib) for chronic myeloid leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors and non-small cell lung cancer, as well as intracellular drugs (vemurafenib and olaparib) for metastatic malignant melanoma and ovarian, breast and prostate cancer. The effectiveness of various targeted therapies for such disparate tumors suggests that we are entering an era in which treatment decisions will be based on the profile or “characteristic” of a tumor's molecular abnormalities rather than on tumor tissue type or anatomical site of origin, thereby improving prognosis and quality of treatment patients. life. This mini-review focuses on the role of personalized medicine in cancer prevention and treatment, as well as its future direction in oncology.

The strong clinical activity of imatinib and trastuzumab in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, gastrointestinal stromal tumors and breast cancer has demonstrated that blocking pathogenic tyrosine kinases can alter the natural history of human tumors. On the other hand, EGF receptor inhibitors showed generally moderate activity. The contrast in the development of these agents means that both molecular target dependence and patient selection are important to the successful outcome of this process. We will compare lessons learned from the development of Abl, c-Kit, HER2/neu (erbB2), and EGFR inhibitors, highlight advances and limitations in the field, and propose new approaches for the clinical development of tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapies.

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, the two main types of chronic inflammatory bowel diseases, are multifactorial conditions of unknown etiology. The susceptibility locus for Crohn's disease has been mapped to chromosome 16. Here, we used a positional cloning strategy based on linkage analysis followed by linkage disequilibrium mapping to identify three independent associations for Crohn's disease: a frameshift variant and two missense NOD2 variants. encoding a member of the Apaf-1/Ced-4 apoptosis regulator superfamily that is expressed in monocytes. These NOD2 variants alter the structure of either the leucine-rich repeat domain of the protein or the adjacent region. NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kB; this activating function is regulated by a leucine-rich repeat domain at the carboxy terminus, which plays an inhibitory role and also acts as an intracellular receptor for components of microbial pathogens. These observations suggest that the NOD2 gene product confers susceptibility to Crohn's disease by altering the recognition of these components and/or overactivating NF-κB in monocytes, thereby documenting a molecular model of the pathogenic mechanism of Crohn's disease that can now be explored further. investigated.

Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract that is believed to result from exposure to environmental factors in a genetically predisposed host. A gene location in the pericentromeric region of chromosome 16, IBD1, that contributes to susceptibility to Crohn's disease has been established through numerous linkage studies, but the specific gene(s) have not been identified. NOD2, a gene that encodes a protein homologous to plant disease resistance gene products, is located in the linkage peak region on chromosome 16 (ref. 7). Here we show, using a transmission disequilibrium test and case-control analysis, that a frameshift mutation caused by the cytosine insertion 3020insC, which is expected to encode a truncated NOD2 protein, is associated with Crohn's disease. Wild-type NOD2 activates nuclear factor NF-kappaB, making it sensitive to bacterial lipopolysaccharides; however, this induction was insufficient in the NOD2 mutant. These results implicate NOD2 in Crohn's disease susceptibility and suggest a link between the innate immune response to bacterial components and disease development.

Nod2 activates the NF-kappaB pathway after intracellular stimulation with bacterial products. Mutations in Nod2 have recently been shown to be associated with Crohn's disease, suggesting a role for bacterium-host interactions in the etiology of this disease. Here we show that Nod2 is a general peptidoglycan sensor through recognition of muramyl dipeptide (MDP), the minimal bioactive peptidoglycan motif common to all bacteria. Moreover, the frameshift mutation 3020insC, the most common Nod2 variant associated with Crohn's disease patients, completely abolishes Nod2-dependent detection of peptidoglycan and MDP. Taken together, these results have implications for understanding the development of Crohn's disease. In addition, characterization of Nod2 as the first pathogen recognition molecule to detect MDP will help unravel the well-known biological activity of this immunomodulatory compound.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. Recently, enormous progress has been made in understanding the pathogenesis of these diseases. From studies of patients and mouse models, Crohn's disease appears to be driven by the production of interleukin-12 (IL-12) and interferon gamma (IFN-gamma), whereas ulcerative colitis is likely driven by IL production. -13. The second area of ​​progress is in identifying the specific genetic abnormalities responsible for the disease. The most important finding is the identification of mutations in the gene that encodes the NOD2 (nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain 2) protein in a subset of patients with Crohn's disease. Here we discuss these recent findings and their implications for therapy.

CARD15/NOD2 mutations are associated with susceptibility to Crohn's disease (CD) and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). CD and GVHD are thought to be associated with dysfunction of Peyer's patches (PP) and isolated lymphoid follicles (LF). Therefore, using a novel Card15/Nod2 knockout (KO) mouse model, we analyzed the effect of the gene on these lymphoid entities along with the development of experimental colitis. At 4, 12 and 52 weeks, the number of PP and LF were higher in KO mice, whereas no differences were observed at birth. At weeks 4 and 12, the size and cellular composition of the PP were analyzed by flow cytometry and immunohistochemistry. The PPs of KO mice were larger with an increased proportion of M cells and CD4(+) T cells. KO mice also had higher concentrations of TNF-alpha, IFN-gamma, IL12, and IL4 measured by ELISA. In contrast, small differences were found in the ileum and spleen of PP-null KO mice. Using chamber experiments, we found that this PP phenotype is associated with an increase in both paracellular permeability and yeast/bacterial translocation. Finally, KO mice were more susceptible to TNBS-induced colitis. Card15/Nod2 deficiency causes abnormal PP development and function, characterized by increased immune response and increased permeability. These observations provide a comprehensive link between the molecular defect and the human CARD15/NOD2-related disorders: CD and GVHD.

GATA3 is a transcription factor that regulates cytokine production by T cells. We investigated the role of GATA3 in the development of colitis in mice. We performed quantitative polymerase chain reaction and immunofluorescence analysis of colon tissue from patients with Crohn's disease (n=61) or ulcerative colitis (UC, n=74) or patients without inflammatory bowel disease (n=22) to measure GATA3 levels. . Colitis was induced by administering oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid to control mice, mice with T cell-specific deletion of GATA3, and mice with deletion of tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) 1 and TNFR2 (TNFR double knockout). ); some mice were treated with GATA3-specific DNAzyme (hgd40) or control DNAzyme via intrarectal or systemic injections of anti-TNF antibody before or during the sensitization and challenge phase of colitis induction. Colon tissues were collected and immunofluorescence and histochemical analyzes were performed. Lamina propria mononuclear cells and T cells were isolated and analyzed by flow cytometry or cytokine assay. The distribution of labeled DNAzyme in the colon and inflammation were monitored using in vivo imaging (endoscopy) of mice. GATA3 messenger RNA levels were higher in colon tissues from patients with UC, but not ileal Crohn's disease, than in control tissues; GATA3 levels correlated with levels of inflammatory cytokines (interleukin [IL] 9, IL17A, IL6, IL5, IL4, IL13, and TNF). We observed increased expression of GATA3 by lamina propria T cells in mice with colitis compared to controls. Mice with a T cell-specific deletion of GATA3 did not develop colitis, and their colon tissue did not produce inflammatory cytokines (IL6, IL9, or IL13). The hgd40 DNAzyme inhibited GATA3 messenger RNA expression by unstimulated and stimulated T cells and was distributed throughout the inflamed colon of mice with colitis. Colon tissue from mice treated with hgd40 had reduced expression of GATA3 messenger RNA compared to mice treated with the control DNAzyme. Mice treated with hgd40 did not develop colitis after administration of oxazolone or 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid; Cells from the lamina propria of these mice expressed lower levels of IL6, IL9, and IL13 than cells from mice treated with control DNAzyme. Mini-endoscopic images showed that hgd40 and anti-TNF reduced colon inflammation within 3 days; hgd40 reduced colitis in TNFR double knockout mice. GATA3 levels are elevated in UC patients and correlate with the production of inflammatory cytokines in mice and humans. A DNAzyme that prevents GATA3 expression reduces colitis in mice independently of TNF and reduces colonic cytokine levels. This DNAzyme could be developed to treat patients with UC.

Geographic and ethnic differences in the incidence of ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease suggest that environmental factors influence disease risk. Prevention of parasitic worms (helminths) through improved hygiene may be one of the factors leading to increased disease prevalence. Helminths change the mucous membrane and systemic immunity of the host. Animals exposed to helminths are protected from experimental colitis and other immunological diseases, and helminth colonization can be used to treat ongoing diseases in mice and humans. Helminths induce mucosal T cells to produce Th2 and regulatory cytokines. Helminth-induced mucosal IL4, TGFbeta and IL10 are likely part of the protective process. Helminths influence innate immune pathways such as TLR4 expression and function. Worms also induce distinct subsets of regulatory T cells in the intestine that limit the growth and function of effector T cells. These effects of once ubiquitous helminths may have protected humans from immune-mediated diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease.

About 70 loci are associated with Crohn's disease (CD) susceptibility, particularly in the innate immune, autophagy, and pathogen recognition pathways. Phenotype-genotype associations are controversial. The CD susceptibility polymorphisms ATG16L1 rs2241880, ICAM1 rs5498, IL4 rs2070874, IL17F rs763780, IRGM rs13361189, ITLN1 rs2274910, LRRK2 rs11175593 and TLR4 rs4986790 were genotyped. in a Portuguese population (511 CD patients, 626 controls) and assessed the association with clinical characteristics of CD. There is a significant association of CD with single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in ATG16L1 (odds ratio [OR] 1.36 [1.15–1.60], P = 2.7 × 10(-6) for the G allele), IRGM (OR 1.56 [1.21] -1.93], P = 3.9 × 10(-4) for allele C) and ITLN1 (OR 1.55 [1.28–1.88], P = 4, 9 × 10(-4) for allele C). These SNPs are associated with ileal location (OR, respectively, 1.49, 1.52, and 1.70), ileocolic location (OR, respectively, 1.31, 1.57, and 1.68), and upper sections of the digestive tract (OR, respectively for ATG16L1 and IRGM). , 1.96 and 1.95). The GG risk genotype in ATG16L1 is associated with patients who respond to steroids (OR 1.89), respond to immunosuppressants (OR 1.77), and respond to biological therapy (OR 1.89). Both SNPs in ITLN1 and IRGM are associated with positive response to biological therapy. The risk of ileal, ileocolic, and upper gastrointestinal tract sites increases with the number of risk alleles (OR for the three alleles, respectively, 7.10, 3.54, and 12.07); The OR for a positive response to biological therapy is 3.66. A multilocus approach using autophagy-related genes provides insight into CD phenotype-genotype associations and genetic markers to predict therapeutic responses.

Schizophrenia is a highly heritable disease. Genetic risk is due to a large number of alleles, including common alleles with small effects that can be detected by genome-wide association studies. Here we report a multistage genome-wide association study of schizophrenia involving up to 36,989 cases and 113,075 controls. We identify 128 independent associations spanning 108 conservedly defined loci of genome-wide significance, 83 of which have not been previously reported. Associations were enriched between genes expressed in the brain, providing biological plausibility to the findings. Many of the findings may provide entirely new insights into etiology, but the associations of DRD2 and several genes involved in glutamatergic neurotransmission highlight molecules of known and potential therapeutic importance in schizophrenia and are consistent with leading pathophysiological hypotheses. Regardless of the genes expressed in the brain, the associations were enriched for genes expressed in tissues that play important roles in immunity, supporting the proposed link between the immune system and schizophrenia.

In an attempt to identify potential genetic risk factors for schizophrenia, research groups around the world have published more than 1,000 genetic association studies with highly inconsistent results. To facilitate the interpretation of these results, we have created a regularly updated online database of all published genetic association studies of schizophrenia (“SzGene”). For all polymorphisms for which genotype data were available in at least four independent case-control samples, we systematically performed random-effects meta-analyses using allelic contrasts. A total of 24 genetic variants were identified in 16 different genes (APOE, COMT, DAO, DRD1, DRD2, DRD4, DTNBP1, GABRB2, GRIN2B, HP, IL1B, MTHFR, PLXNA2, SLC6A4, TP53, and TPH1) across 118 meta-analyses. nominally significant effects with a mean pooled odds ratio of approximately 1.23. Seven of these variants have not previously been meta-analyzed. According to recently proposed criteria for assessing cumulative evidence in genetic association studies, four of the significant results could be characterized as showing “strong” epidemiological significance. Our project provides the first comprehensive online resource containing systematically synthesized and categorized evidence from genetic association studies in schizophrenia. Thus, it may serve as a model for field surveys of genetic associations in other common and genetically complex diseases.

Although changes in nucleotide sequence affecting the composition and structure of proteins are well known, functional changes resulting from nucleotide substitutions cannot always be inferred from simple DNA sequence analysis. Because a strong synonymous codon usage bias in the human DRD2 gene, suggesting selection for synonymous positions, was identified by the relative independence of G+C content at third codon positions from isochoric G+C frequencies, we decided to examine the functional effects of six known natural synonymous variations (C132T, G423A, T765C, C939T, C957T and G1101A) in human DRD2. We report here that several synonymous mutations in human DRD2 have functional effects and suggest a novel genetic mechanism. 957T, rather than being silent, altered predicted mRNA folding, resulted in decreased mRNA stability and translation, and dramatically reversed the dopamine-induced increase in DRD2 expression. 1101A showed no effect on its own, but abolished the above effects of 957T in the 957T/1101A composite clone, demonstrating that combinations of synonymous mutations can have functional consequences radically different from those of each isolated mutation. C957T was found to be in linkage disequilibrium in a European-American population with the -141C Ins/Del and TaqI 'A' variants, which have been reported to be associated with schizophrenia and alcoholism, respectively. These results challenge some of the assumptions made about synonymous variation in molecular population genetics and gene mapping studies of diseases with complex inheritance, and indicate that synonymous variation may have effects of potential pathophysiological and pharmacogenetic importance.

- It was previously reported that the A1 allele of the Taq I polymorphism of the dopamine D2 receptor gene (DRD2) occurs in 69% of alcoholics compared with 20% of controls. Other studies have found no significant difference in the prevalence of the A1 allele in alcoholics compared with controls, and have also found no evidence that the DRD2 gene is associated with alcoholism. We hypothesized that these seemingly contradictory results may be due to the fact that the increased prevalence of the A1 allele may not be specific to alcoholism. Thus, we examined other disorders often associated with alcoholism or associated with defects in dopaminergic neurotransmission. -- Comparative study. To minimize the influence of racial differences in gene frequency, the study was limited to non-Hispanic whites. --Outpatient and hospitalized patients. --Among all known controls (n = 314), 77 (24.5%) carried the A1 allele. Of the 69 controls known to be non-alcoholics, 10 (14.5%) carried the A1 allele. The prevalence of the A1 allele was significantly increased in patients with Tourette syndrome (44.9%, n = 147), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (46.2%, n = 104), autism (54.5%, n = 33), alcoholism (42.3%, n = 104) and post-traumatic stress disorder (45.7%, n = 35). After adjusting for multiple comparisons (requiring P less than 0.0009 for significance), all remained significant except PTSD. The prevalence of the A1 allele was not significantly increased in patients with depression, panic attacks, Parkinson's disease, or obesity. The prevalence of the A1 allele in drug dependence and schizophrenia was significant only when compared with that in non-alcoholic controls, and no adjustments were made for multiple comparisons. -These results suggest that the A1 allele of the DRD2 gene is associated with a number of behavioral disorders in which it may act as a modifying gene rather than as a primary etiological agent.

Velocardiofacial syndrome (VCFS), a syndrome characterized by an increased incidence of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, is associated with small interstitial deletions of chromosome 22q11. We assessed 50 adults with VCFS using a structured clinical interview (Clinical Assessment Schedule in Neuropsychiatry or Psychiatric Assessment Schedule for Adults with Developmental Disabilities if IQ <50) to establish DSM-IV diagnosis. The schizophrenia phenotype of individuals with VCFS and schizophrenia was compared with a matched series of individuals with schizophrenia and without VCFS (n = 12). The King Schizotypy Questionnaire was administered to individuals with VCFS (n = 41), their first-degree relatives (n = 68), and a number of unrelated healthy controls (n = 316). All individuals with deleted VCFS using the N25 probe (n = 48) were genotyped for a genetic polymorphism in the COMT gene that results in variations in enzymatic activity. Fifteen individuals with VCFS (30%) had a psychotic disorder, with 24% (n = 12) meeting DSM-IV criteria for schizophrenia. In addition, 6 (12%) had major depression without psychotic features. Individuals with schizophrenia had fewer negative symptoms and a relatively later age of onset compared with individuals with schizophrenia and without VCFS. We found no evidence that the presence of a low-activity COMT allele was associated with schizophrenia in our sample of people with VCFS. The high prevalence of schizophrenia in this group suggests that chromosome 22q11 may contain a gene or genes relevant to the etiology of schizophrenia in the wider population.

Traditionally, psychiatric research, including the search for predisposing genes, has been conducted on the assumption that schizophrenia and bipolar disorder are separate diseases with different etiologies. They represent Emil Kraepelin's traditional dichotomous classification of so-called "functional" psychoses and form the basis of modern diagnostic practice. However, the results obtained in many areas of psychiatric research do not fit this model very well. In particular, results from genetic studies show increasing evidence of overlap in genetic susceptibility between traditional classification categories, including association results for DAOA (G72), DTNBP1 (dysbindin), COMT, BDNF, DISC1, and NRG1. Emerging evidence suggests the possibility of relatively specific relationships between genotype and psychopathology. For example, DISC1 and NRG1 may confer susceptibility to a particular form of the disease with mixed manifestations of schizophrenia and mania. Elucidation of genotype-phenotype relationships is at an early stage, but current findings highlight the need to consider alternative approaches to classifying and conceptualizing psychiatric research rather than continuing to rely heavily on the traditional Kraepelinian dichotomy. As psychosis susceptibility genes are identified and characterized over the next few years, this will have a major impact on our understanding of the pathophysiology of the disease and will lead to changes in the classification and clinical practice of psychiatry.

Variability of phenotypic manifestations and inconsistency of genetic associations in mental illness remain a major challenge in molecular psychiatry. Recently, it has become increasingly clear that altered promoter DNA methylation may play a critical role in mediating differential gene regulation and facilitating short-term adaptation in response to the environment. Here we report an investigation of differential membrane-bound catechol-O-methyltransferase (MB-COMT) activity due to altered promoter methylation and the nature of the contribution of the Val158Met COMT polymorphism as risk factors for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder by analyzing 115 post-mortem brain samples from the frontal lobe. These studies showed for the first time that MB-COMT promoter DNA is often hypomethylated in patients with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder compared with controls (methylation rate: 26 and 29 vs. 60%; P = 0.004 and 0.008, respectively), especially in control patients . left frontal lobes (methylation rate: 29 and 30 vs. 81%; P = 0.003 and 0.002, respectively). Quantitative gene expression analysis showed a corresponding increase in MB-COMT transcript levels in patients with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder compared with controls (P = 0.02), with a concomitant inverse correlation between MB-COMT and DRD1 expression. In addition, patients tended to be enriched in the Val allele of the Val158Met COMT polymorphism with MB-COMT hypomethylation. These data suggest that overexpression of MB-COMT due to promoter hypomethylation and/or a hyperactive COMT allele may increase dopamine degradation in the frontal lobe, providing a molecular basis for the common symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.

We used a translational convergent functional genomics (CFG) approach to identify and prioritize genes involved in schizophrenia by integrating gene-level data from genome-wide association studies with other genetics and gene expression studies in human and animal models. Using this polyevidence assessment and pathway analysis, we identify major genes (DISC1, TCF4, MBP, MOBP, NCAM1, NRCAM, NDUFV2, RAB18, as well as ADCYAP1, BDNF, CNR1, COMT, DRD2, DTNBP1, GAD1, GRIA1, GRIN2B, HTR2A , NRG1, RELN, SNAP-25, TNIK), brain development, myelination, cell adhesion, glutamate receptor signaling, G-protein coupled receptor signaling, and cAMP-mediated signaling as clues to pathophysiology and as targets for therapeutic intervention. Overall, the data are consistent with a model of impaired connectivity in schizophrenia resulting from exposure to environmental neurodevelopmental stress in the context of genetic vulnerability. In addition, we show how the top candidate genes identified by CFG can be used to create a genetic risk prediction score (GRPS) to aid in schizophrenia diagnosis with predictive power in independent cohorts. GRPS also differentiates the classic age of onset of schizophrenia from early-onset and late-onset illnesses. We also show, across three independent cohorts, two European American and one African American, increasing overlap, reproducibility, and consistency of findings from single nucleotide polymorphisms to genes, then genes prioritized by CFG, and ultimately at the level of biological pathways and mechanisms. Finally, we compared our top candidate genes for schizophrenia from this analysis with the top candidate genes for bipolar disorder and anxiety disorders from previous CFG analyzes we conducted, as well as results in autism and Alzheimer's disease. Overall, our work maps the genomic and biological landscape of schizophrenia, providing a path toward better understanding of the disease, diagnosis, and treatment. It also reveals significant genetic overlap with other major areas of mental disorder, indicating the need for improved nosology.

The fine tuning of neural connections during development is regulated through interaction with the environment. Some fine tuning occurs through changes in gene expression and/or gene-specific epigenetic DNA methylation states. DNA methylation occurs by transfer of a methyl group from S-adenosylmethionine to cytosine residues in the CpG dinucleotide sequence. Although CpG sequences distributed throughout the genome are typically highly methylated, those found in CpG islands in gene promoter regions are less methylated. In most cases, the degree of DNA methylation correlates with the degree of gene inactivation. Other known epigenetic mechanisms include histone deacetylation and chromatin remodeling, RNA inhibition, RNA modification, and DNA rearrangement. Impact memory, expressed in the form of epigenetic modifications of DNA, ensures genomic plasticity and short-term adaptation of each generation to the environment. Environmental factors that influence DNA methylation include diet, proteins, medications, and hormones. Induced methylation changes may lead to altered gene responses upon subsequent hormonal stimulation. Gene-specific DNA methylation state can be maintained during transmission through mitosis and meiosis. Increasing evidence points to a role for DNA methylation in multifactorial psychiatric disorders. For example, treatment with L-methionine may worsen psychosis; while valproate, a drug that produces hypomethylated DNA, reduces such symptoms. Hypermethylation of the promoter region of the RELN gene correlates with decreased gene expression. The gene's protein Reelin, which is essential for neuronal migration and synaptogenesis, is decreased in schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, suggesting hypermethylation of the promoter region in these disorders. Some evidence suggests that methylation of the promoter regions of the DRD2 and HTR2A genes is also associated with schizophrenia and mood disorders. DNA methylation generally increases with age, although hypomethylation of the promoter region of the amyloid A4 precursor gene during aging may play a role in Alzheimer's disease. More research is needed to determine the role of methylomics and other epigenetic phenomena in the nervous system.

No specific gene has been identified for any major mental disorder, including schizophrenia, despite compelling evidence supporting a genetic basis for these complex and devastating disorders. There are several likely reasons for this failure, ranging from poor study design with low statistical power to genetic mechanisms such as polygenic inheritance, epigenetic interactions, and pleiotropy. Most currently used study designs are insufficient to uncover these mechanisms. However, to date, genetic research has provided valuable information about the causes and potential treatments for mental disorders. Increasing evidence suggests that understanding the genetic etiology of mental illnesses, including schizophrenia, will benefit from integrative approaches that consider both genetic and epigenetic factors. For example, several genes, including those encoding dopamine receptors (DRD2, DRD3, and DRD4), serotonin receptor 2A (HTR2A), and catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT), have been implicated in the etiology of schizophrenia and related disorders, according to a meta-analysis. disorders. large multicenter studies. There is also growing evidence for the role of DRD1, NMDA receptor genes (GRIN1, GRIN2A, GRIN2B), brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and dopamine transporter (SLC6A3) in both schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. Recent studies have shown that epigenetic modification of the Reelin (RELN), BDNF and DRD2 promoters increases susceptibility to clinical psychiatric diseases. Pharmacological therapies for psychiatric disorders are likely to become more effective if the molecular pathogenesis is known. For example, hypoactive DRD2 alleles and hyperactive COMT alleles, which destroy dopamine in the synaptic cleft, are associated with schizophrenia. It is likely that deficient dopaminergic transmission in the frontal lobe plays a role in the development of negative symptoms associated with this disorder. Antipsychotic therapy with a partial dopamine D2 agonist effect may be a plausible alternative to current treatments and would be effective in reducing symptoms in psychotic people. It is also possible that therapy using dopamine D1/D2 receptor agonists or COMT inhibitors would be beneficial for patients with negative symptoms of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The complex etiology of schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders requires consideration of both genetic and epigenetic systems, as well as careful design of experiments to elucidate the genetic mechanisms responsible for these disorders and the benefits of existing and new treatments.

ZNF804a was identified in a genome-wide association study (GWAS), in which a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP rs1344706) in ZNF804a reached genome-wide statistical significance for association with a combined diagnosis of schizophrenia (SZ) and bipolar disorder. Although the molecular function of ZNF804a is unknown, the amino acid sequence is predicted to contain a C2H2-type zinc finger domain, suggesting that ZNF804a plays a role in DNA binding and transcription. Here, we confirm that ZNF804a directly contributes to transcriptional control by regulating the expression of several SZ-associated genes and directly interacts with chromatin located proximal to the promoter regions of PRSS16 and COMT, two genes that we found to be activated by ZNF804a. Using immunochemistry, we established that ZNF804a localizes to the nucleus of rat neural progenitor cells in culture and in vivo. We demonstrate that expression of ZNF804a results in a significant increase in PRSS16 and COMT transcript levels compared to GFP-transfected controls and a statistically significant decrease in PDE4B and DRD2 transcript levels. In addition, we show using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays that both epitope-tagged and endogenous ZNF804a directly interact with the promoter regions of PRSS16 and COMT, indicating a direct transcriptional enhancement of ZNF804a on the expression of these genes. These results are the first to confirm that ZNF804a regulates transcription levels of four SZ-associated genes and binds to chromatin proximal to the promoters of two SZ genes. These results suggest a model in which ZNF804a may modulate the transcriptional network of SZ-associated genes.

In probands with osteogenesis imperfecta, a hereditary disease of children characterized by fragility of bones and other tissues rich in type I collagen, more than 70 mutations were found in two structural genes of type I procollagen (COL1A1 and COL1A2). Mutations include deletions, insertions, RNA splicing mutations, and single-base substitutions that convert a glycine codon to an amino acid codon with a larger side chain. With a few exceptions, the most severe phenotypes of the disease are attributed primarily to the synthesis of structurally defective pro-alpha chains of type I procollagen that prevent either triple helix folding or self-assembly of collagen into fibrils. The results highlight the extent to which the zipper folding of the collagen triple helix and the self-assembly of collagen fibrils depend on the principle of nucleated growth, whereby multiple subunits form a nucleus and the nucleus then spreads out to form a large structure with a precisely defined architecture. The principle of nucleated growth is a highly efficient mechanism for the assembly of large structures, but biological systems that rely heavily on nucleated growth are very vulnerable to mutations that cause the synthesis of structurally abnormal but partially functional subunits. Recently, several mutations in three other collagen genes (COL2A1, COL3A1, and COL4A5) have been discovered in probands with genetic diseases affecting tissues rich in these collagens. Most probands have rare genetic diseases, but some appear to have phenotypes that are difficult to distinguish from more common diseases such as osteoarthritis, osteoporosis, and aortic aneurysms. Thus, the results suggest that mutations in procollagen genes can cause a wide range of both rare and common human diseases.

Immunosuppressants play a critical role in preventing the harmful immune responses associated with allogeneic organ transplantation, but they often cause side effects in a number of biological systems, including the skeletal system. The calcineurin inhibitors FK506 and cyclosporine A inhibit the activity of nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) and cause severe immunosuppression. Among the NFAT proteins, NFATc1 is critical for the differentiation of bone-resorbing osteoclasts. Here we show that administration of FK506 causes a decrease in bone mass despite blockade of osteoclast differentiation. This reduction is caused by severe impairment of bone formation, suggesting that NFAT transcription factors also play an important role in the osteoblast transcriptional program. In fact, bone formation is inhibited in Nfatc1- and Nfatc2-deficient cells as well as in FK506-treated osteoblasts. Overexpression of NFATc1 stimulates Osterix-dependent activation of the Col1a1 promoter (encoding type I collagen) but not Runx2-dependent activation of the Bglap1 promoter (encoding osteocalcin). NFAT and Osterix form a complex that binds to DNA, and this interaction is important for the transcriptional activity of Osterix. Thus, NFAT and Osterix jointly control osteoblast formation. These results may provide important insights into the treatment of post-transplant osteoporosis as well as a new strategy to promote bone regeneration in osteopenic disease.

Osteoporosis is a common disease with a strong genetic component. We previously described a polymorphic Sp1 binding site in the COL1A1 gene that has been associated with osteoporosis in several populations. Here we explore the molecular mechanisms underlying this association. A meta-analysis showed a significant association between COL1A1 “s” alleles and bone mineral density (BMD), body mass index (BMI), and osteoporotic fractures. The association with fractures was stronger than expected based on observed differences in BMD and BMI, suggesting an additional effect on bone strength. Gel shift assays showed increased binding affinity of the "s" allele for the Sp1 protein, and primary RNA transcripts derived from the "s" allele were approximately three times more abundant than transcripts derived from the "S" allele in "Ss" heterozygotes " Collagen produced from osteoblasts cultured from “Ss” heterozygotes had an increased ratio of alpha 1(I) protein compared to alpha 2(I), and this was accompanied by an increased ratio of COL1A1 mRNA compared to COL1A2. Finally, the yield strength of bones obtained from “Ss” individuals was reduced compared to bone obtained from “SS” subjects. We conclude that the COL1A1 Sp1 polymorphism is a functional genetic variant that predisposes to osteoporosis through complex mechanisms involving changes in bone mass and bone quality.

Type I collagen is the most abundant and ubiquitous of the collagen family of proteins. It is a heterotrimer containing two alpha1(I) chains and one alpha2(I) chain, which are encoded by the unlinked COL1A1 and COL1A2 loci, respectively. Mutations at these loci lead primarily to connective tissue disorders of osteogenesis imperfecta and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome types VIIA and VIIB. Two cases of osteoporosis and one case of Marfan syndrome also result from mutations at these loci. Mutation data is available on the World Wide Web at http://www.le.ac.uk/depts/ge/collagen/collagen.html.

Celiac disease is a genetically determined chronic inflammatory bowel disease caused by the environmental trigger gluten. Patients with this disease may have primarily non-gastrointestinal symptoms, and as a result, patients present to a variety of healthcare practitioners. Epidemiological studies have shown that celiac disease is very common, affecting approximately one in 250 people. The disease is associated with an increased incidence of osteoporosis, infertility, autoimmune diseases and malignancies, especially lymphomas. The mechanism of the intestinal immune-mediated response is not entirely clear but involves an HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 limited T cell immune response in the lamina propria as well as an immune response in the intestinal epithelium. An important component of the disease are intraepithelial lymphocytes, which can proliferate clonally in refractory sprue and T-cell lymphoma associated with enteropathy. Studying the mechanism of the immune response in celiac disease may provide insight into the mechanism of inflammatory and autoimmune reactions and lead to innovations in treatment.

Until a few years ago, celiac disease (CD) was considered a rare food intolerance common in childhood and characterized by severe malabsorption and flat intestinal mucosa. CD is now considered an autoimmune disease that is common in the general population (affecting 1 in 100 people), with possible onset at any age and a variety of possible manifestations. Identifying CD is challenging because it can begin not only with diarrhea and weight loss, but also with atypical gastrointestinal (constipation and recurrent abdominal pain) and extraintestinal symptoms (anemia, increased transaminases, osteoporosis, recurrent miscarriages, aphthous stomatitis and related autoimmune diseases). disorder), or it may be completely asymptomatic. Over the past 20 years, the diagnostic accuracy of CD serology has gradually increased with the development of highly reliable tests such as the detection of tissue transglutaminase IgA and anti-endomysial peptide antibodies and anti-gliadin anti-desamidated peptide IgG. The routine use of antibody markers has allowed investigators to detect a very large number of “borderline” cases, characterized by positive serology and mild intestinal lesions or normal small intestinal architecture, that can be classified as potential CD. Thus, it is clear that “old celiac disease” with flat mucosa is only part of the spectrum of CD. It is possible that serology will identify CD in the early stages, before the onset of severe intestinal damage. In cases with positive serology but mild or no intestinal involvement, detection of HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 can help confirm or rule out the diagnosis of gluten sensitivity.

Celiac disease is a lifelong intolerance to gluten found in wheat, barley and rye, and some patients are also sensitive to oats. The disease is genetically determined: 10% of first-degree relatives are affected and 75% of monozygotic twins are concordant. Of patients with celiac disease, 95% are positive for human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8. Characteristically, the jejunal mucosa is damaged by a T cell-mediated autoimmune response believed to be initiated by the 33-mer peptide fragment of gliadin A2, and patients with this disease have elevated levels of anti-endomysium and tissue transglutaminase antibodies in the body. their blood. Celiac disease is the main type of food intolerance diagnosed and, with the advent of a simple blood test to identify cases, its prevalence is thought to be approximately 1:100. Classically, the condition presents with malabsorption and failure to thrive in infancy, but this picture has now been superseded by a much more common presentation in adults, usually with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue and anemia, bowel dysfunction, or stool retention. impact bone fractures. Small bowel biopsy is necessary for diagnosis and shows a characteristic flat appearance with crypt hypoplasia and infiltration of the epithelium by lymphocytes. Diet is the key to treatment, and a gluten-free diet effectively treats this condition. However, this commitment lasts for life, and many supermarket aisles are effectively closed to people with celiac disease. Compliance can be monitored by measuring antibodies in the blood, which become negative after 6–9 months. Patients with minor symptoms who are accidentally diagnosed with celiac disease often wonder whether they need to follow a diet. It is now recommended to follow a diet to avoid long-term complications, which are mainly osteoporosis and small intestinal lymphoma. However, the risk of these complications is significantly reduced in patients following a gluten-free diet.

Public concern about gluten has led to widespread demand for gluten-free foods, but celiac disease remains underdiagnosed and there remains some confusion about optimal diagnostic methods. Small intestinal histology is the gold standard for diagnosis. High-quality commercial enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for transglutaminase immunoglobulin A and deamidated gliadin immunoglobulins A and G are sensitive screening tools, but nearly 10% of celiac disease cases are seronegative, and serological testing is unreliable in very young people and in people who have already had vaccinations. gluten-reduced diets and those taking immunosuppressants. HLA DQA and DQB genotyping, showing the absence of alleles encoding HLA DQ2 and DQ8, virtually rules out celiac disease. Confirmation of histological remission reduces the risk of subsequent complications such as osteoporosis and cancer. Monitoring remission using serology is unreliable. Because gluten is an exogenous antigen and the small intestine is easily accessible, the immunopathogenesis of celiac disease is better studied than other MHC class II diseases such as type 1 diabetes. Therapeutic targets have been identified and medications are in development to complement or even replace the gluten-free diet. With increased awareness and non-dietary treatment options, the diagnosis and treatment of celiac disease will become an increasingly important part of medical practice.

To investigate the in vivo role of IL-4 in allergic asthma, we developed a mouse model of allergen-induced airway inflammation. Repeated daily exposure of actively immunized C57BL/6 mice to aerosolized ovalbumin (OVA) caused peribronchial inflammation and increased numbers of eosinophils and lymphocytes in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL). IL-4-deficient (IL4-/-) mice treated in the same manner had significantly fewer eosinophils in the BAL fluid and much less peribronchial inflammation compared with wild-type mice. In this model, mast cell-deficient (W/Wv) mice developed the same degree of BAL eosinophilia and peribronchial inflammation as wild-type mice, demonstrating that mast cells are not required for the induction of chronic airway inflammation. In contrast, BAL eosinophilia and airway inflammation were absent in OVA-treated MHC class II-deficient (B6.Aa-/-) mice, which lack mature CD4+ T cells. In conclusion, these results indicate that IL-4 is a central mediator of allergic airway inflammation by regulating antigen-induced recruitment of eosinophils to the airways through a T cell-dependent mechanism.

IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13 are thought to play a central role in the allergic asthmatic response. Previous work suggested that the main source of these cytokines is CD4(+) T(H)2 cells. However, more recent studies have suggested that other innate production of type 2 cytokines may be equally important. Nuocytes are a novel population of IL-13-producing innate cells that are critical for protective immunity during Nippostrongylus brasiliensis infection. With this in mind, we investigated the potential existence and functional significance of nuocytes in experimental allergic asthma. We generated Il4(+/eGFP)Il13(+/Tomato) dual reporter mice to study cytokine-producing cells during allergic inflammation. We adoptively transferred innate IL-13-producing cells to investigate their role in airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR). We show that allergen-induced nuocytes infiltrate the lungs and are the major innate source of IL-13. CD4(+) T cells in the lung almost exclusively express IL-13 alone, whereas IL-4-producing T cells are restricted to draining lymph nodes. Intranasal administration of IL-25 or IL-33 induced IL-13-producing nuocytes in BAL fluid. Strikingly, adoptive transfer of wild-type nuocytes, but not Il13(-/-) nuocytes, into Il13(-/-) mice, which are normally resistant to IL-25-induced AHR, restored airway resistance and lung cell infiltration. These data identify nuocytes as a novel cell type in allergic lung inflammation and an innate source of IL-13 that can directly induce AHR in the absence of IL-13-producing CD4(+) T cells. These data highlight that nuocytes are an important new factor in the development of future therapies for allergic asthma.

Asthma is a common respiratory disease characterized by various airway obstructions caused by acute and chronic inflammation of the bronchi; associated phenotypes include bronchial hyperresponsiveness (BHR), elevated levels of total serum immunoglobulin E (IgE), and positive skin tests for common allergens. Binding of interleukin-13 (IL13) or interleukin-4 (IL4) to the IL4 receptor (IL4R) induces an initial Th2 lymphocyte polarization response. Both IL13 and IL4 are produced by Th2 cells and are capable of inducing B cell isotype class switching to produce IgE following allergen exposure. These cytokines also share a receptor component, IL4R-alpha. We examined five IL4RA single nucleotide polymorphisms in a Dutch family population identified in a proband with asthma. Considering probands and their spouses as an unrelated sample, we observed a significant association of atopy- and asthma-related phenotypes with several IL4RA polymorphisms, including S478P and total serum IgE levels (P = 0.0007). A significant gene-gene interaction was found between S478P in IL4RA and the −1111 promoter variation in IL13, which was previously shown to be associated with BHR (P = 0.003). Individuals with risk genotypes for both genes had nearly five times the risk of developing asthma compared with individuals with both non-risk genotypes (P = 0.0004). These data suggest that IL4RA variations contribute to increased total serum IgE levels, and the interaction between IL4RA and IL13 markedly increases an individual's susceptibility to asthma.

A three-gene signature of periostin, chloride channel accessory 1 (CLCA1), and serpin β2 (SERPINB2) in airway epithelial clearance is used to classify asthma into high-TH2 and low-TH2 endotypes. Little is known about the utility of sputum gene profiling as a molecular phenotyping technique. We sought to determine whether gene profiling in sputum cells could identify high T(H)2 and low T(H)2 subtypes of asthma. In induced sputum cell sediments from 37 patients with asthma and 15 healthy control subjects, PCR was used to profile the expression of epithelial cell genes responsible for IL-13 activation (periostin, CLCA1 and SERPINB2), TH2 genes (IL4, IL5 and IL13). ) and other genes associated with TH2 airway inflammation. Expression levels of the CLCA1 and periostin genes, but not SerpinB2, were significantly higher than normal in sputum cells from asthmatic patients. Expression levels of IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13 were also significantly increased in patients with asthma and were highly correlated within individual subjects. Combining the expression levels of IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13 into one quantitative measure (“mean T(H)2 gene value”), 26 (70%) of 37 patients with asthma were found to have T(H)2- high asthma, which was characterized by a more severe course of bronchial asthma and increased eosinophilia of blood and sputum. Mean TH2 gene values ​​tended to be stable when starting values ​​were very high or very low, but fluctuated above or below the T(H)2 threshold when starting values ​​were intermediate. IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13 transcripts are readily detected in sputum cells of patients with asthma, and their expression levels can be used to classify asthma into T(H)2-high and T(H)2-low endotypes. .

Chitin is an important structural polysaccharide of fungal pathogens and parasites, but its role in human immune responses remains largely unknown. It is the second most abundant polysaccharide in nature after cellulose, and its derivatives are widely used today for medicinal and industrial purposes. We analyzed the immunological properties of purified chitin particles obtained from the opportunistic human fungal pathogen Candida albicans, which leads to the selective secretion of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. We identified NOD2, TLR9, and the mannose receptor as important fungal chitin recognition receptors for inducing this response. Chitin reduces LPS-induced inflammation in vivo and may therefore contribute to the resolution of the immune response once the pathogen is defeated. Fungal chitin also induced eosinophilia in vivo, confirming its ability to induce asthma. Polymorphisms of the identified chitin receptors, NOD2 and TLR9, predispose individuals to inflammatory conditions, and dysregulated expression of chitinases and chitinase-like binding proteins, the activity of which is required for the generation of IL-10-inducing fungal chitin particles in vitro, is also associated with inflammatory conditions and asthma. Thus, chitin recognition is critical for immune homeostasis and likely plays a significant role in infectious and allergic diseases.

Interaction with microbial pathogens is critical for the maturation of the immune system. Nucleotide-binding oligomerization domain protein 1 (NOD1) is a cytosolic muropeptide-sensing receptor found primarily on Gram-negative bacterial peptidoglycans. NOD1 is located on chromosome 7p14-p15, a region associated with atopy. Recently, polymorphisms in the closely related NOD2 have been associated with atopy-related traits. Within a large population-based cohort of German adults (n = 1417), a case-control group of atopic eczema (n = 454), and a large cohort of parent-child trios with atopic eczema (189 trios), we assessed 11 NOD1 polymorphisms for association with atopic eczema. phenotypes. Methods. Subjects were phenotyped using standardized questionnaires and interviews, skin examination, and serum IgE measurements. Genotyping was performed using matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization and time-of-flight mass spectrometry. Analyzes revealed a significant association of one NOD1 haplotype with atopic eczema in the population-based cohort (P = 0.004) and case-control population (P = 0.003). A different NOD1 haplotype was associated with decreased total IgE (P = 0.008). Additionally, significant associations with total serum IgE levels were observed for the rs2907748 (P = 0.006), rs2907749 (P = 0.012), and rs2075822 (P = 0.018) polymorphisms. These polymorphisms were significantly associated with atopic eczema and asthma in familial association analysis (P = 0.001–0.043). Seven polymorphisms showed significant biases in the transmission of total IgE levels (P values ​​<0.0001–0.029). These data indicate that NOD1 genetic variants are important determinants of susceptibility to atopy.

NOD-like receptors (NLRs) with an oligomerization and nucleotide binding domain are highly conserved cytosolic pattern recognition receptors that perform critical functions in probing the intracellular environment for infection, noxious substances, and metabolic disorders. Perception of these danger signals by NLRs leads to their oligomerization into large macromolecular scaffolds and rapid deployment of effector signaling cascades to restore homeostasis. While some NLRs act by recruiting and activating inflammatory caspases to inflammasomes, others drive inflammation through alternative pathways, including nuclear factor-κB, mitogen-activated protein kinase, and regulatory factor pathways. The critical role of NLRs in development and physiology is supported by their apparent impact on human disease. Mutations in the genes encoding NLRP3 or NLRP12 lead to hereditary periodic fever syndromes, while mutations in CARD15, encoding NOD2, are associated with Crohn's disease or Blau syndrome. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified a range of risk alleles spanning NLR genes in a variety of diseases, including allergic rhinitis, multiple sclerosis, inflammatory bowel disease, asthma, multibacillary leprosy, vitiligo, early menopause and bone problems. loss of density in older women. Animal models have allowed the underlying effector mechanisms to be characterized in some cases. In this review, we highlight the functions of NLRs in health and disease and discuss how characterization of their molecular mechanisms provides new insights into therapeutic strategies for treating inflammatory pathologies.

In affluent, developed parts of the world, there is a sustained and concurrent increase in at least three groups of diseases: (1) allergies, (2) inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD; eg, Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis), and (3) autoimmunity (eg, diabetes 1 type and multiple sclerosis). Because the medical world is so divided, it took some time before the connection between this growth was noticed and understood. There is now evidence that the concurrent increase in these immunodysregulatory diseases is at least in part due to malfunctioning regulatory T cells (Tregs). This article reviews relevant work in each of these areas of medicine (albeit with a focus on allergic disorders) and concludes that the increasing ineffectiveness of Tregs is a consequence of decreased exposure to certain microorganisms that are “old friends.” , due to their constant presence throughout mammalian evolution. These organisms, which include saprophytic mycobacteria, helminths, and lactobacilli, are recognized by the innate immune system as harmless and serve as adjuvants for Treg induction. Polymorphisms in components of the innate immune system, such as TLR2 and NOD2, appear to define subgroups of the population that will develop immunoregulatory disorders while living in the modern environment. A further role of “old friends” and the Tregs they induce may be to maintain levels of IL-10-secreting regulatory macrophages and antigen-presenting cells that are depleted in asthma and Crohn's disease. These concepts lead to new treatments based on harmless organisms or their components. Phase I/II clinical trials have produced some statistically significant results, and phase II studies are ongoing.

The action of tissue transglutaminase (TGase) on specific protein-bound glutamine residues plays a critical role in many biological processes. Here we provide evidence for a novel role for this enzyme in the common HLA-DQ2 (and DQ8)-associated enteropathy, celiac disease (CD). Intestinal inflammation in CD is provoked by dietary exposure to wheat gliadin and is associated with increased mucosal TGase activity. This enzyme has also been identified as a major target of CD-associated endomysial autoantibodies and is known to accept gliadin as one of its few substrates. We explored the possibility that TGase may be involved in modulating the reactivity of gliadin-specific T cells. This could establish a link between previous reports of a role for TGase in CD and the prevailing view of CD as a T cell-mediated disease. We found a specific effect of TGase on gliadin recognition by T cells. This effect was limited to gliadin-specific T cells isolated from intestinal lesions. We demonstrate that TGase mediates its effect through the orderly and specific deamidation of gliadins. This deamidation creates an epitope that binds efficiently to DQ2 and is recognized by intestinal T cells. Generation of epitopes by enzymatic modification is a novel mechanism that may be relevant to the breakdown of tolerance and initiation of autoimmune diseases.

Proteins in wheat, rye and barley cause celiac disease, an autoimmune type of gastrointestinal disorder, in genetically predisposed people. Because the disease may be underdiagnosed, we assessed the prevalence of the disease and tested the hypothesis that serum autoantibody tests can be used to detect untreated celiac disease and that positive results are correlated with specific HLA haplotypes. Serum samples were collected from 3654 students (ages 7 to 16 years) in 1994 and tested in 2001 for endomysial and tissue transglutaminase antibodies. HLA typing was also performed on stored blood samples. In 2001, all subjects testing positive for antibodies were offered a small bowel biopsy. Of the 3,654 subjects, 56 (1.5 percent) had positive antibody tests as determined in 2001. The results of the two antibody tests were largely consistent. As of 1994, no subjects had been clinically diagnosed with celiac disease, but 10 who had positive serum tests for both antibodies obtained in 1994 were diagnosed between 1994 and 2001. Of the 36 other subjects with positive antibody tests who agreed in 2001, 27 subjects who were biopsied had evidence of celiac disease on biopsy. Thus, the estimated biopsy-confirmed prevalence was 1 in 99 children. All but two antibody-positive subjects had either the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotype. The prevalence of the combination of antibody positivity and HLA haplotype associated with celiac disease was 1 in 67.
