The presence of serum tissue transglutaminase and endomysial autoantibodies is predictive of small bowel abnormalities suggestive of celiac disease. There is a good correlation between autoantibody positivity and specific HLA haplotypes. We estimate that the prevalence of celiac disease among Finnish schoolchildren is at least 1 in 99 children.

The vast majority of patients with wheat gluten intolerance due to celiac disease (CD) have human leukocyte histocompatibility antigen (HLA)-DQ2(+), and the remaining few typically express HLA-DQ8. These two class II molecules are primarily responsible for the presentation of gluten peptides to gluten-specific T cells, which are found only in the intestines of CD patients and not in controls. Interestingly, tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-mediated deamidation of gliadin plays an important role in the recognition of this food antigen by intestinal T cells. Here, we used recombinant antigens to demonstrate that the intestinal T cell response to alpha-gliadin in adult CD is centered on two immunodominant DQ2-restricted peptides that overlap a seven-residue fragment of gliadin. We show that tTG converts the glutamine residue in this moiety to glutamic acid and that this process is critical for T cell recognition. All gluten-specific T cell lines from 16 different adult patients responded to one or both of these deamidated peptides, indicating that these epitopes are very important in disease pathology. Binding studies have shown that deamidated peptides exhibit increased affinity for DQ2, a molecule known to preferentially bind peptides containing negatively charged residues. Interestingly, the modified glutamine is located in different DQ2 pockets for different epitopes. These results suggest that modifications of anchor residues lead to improved affinity for the major histocompatibility complex (MHC), and altered conformation of the peptide-MHC complex may be a critical factor leading to T cell responses to gliadin and oral gluten intolerance found in CD.

Despite the increased prescribing of a gluten-free diet for gastrointestinal symptoms in people without celiac disease, there is minimal evidence that gluten is a trigger. The purpose of this study was to determine whether eating gluten can cause symptoms in people without celiac disease and to explore the mechanism. A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled replication study was conducted in patients with irritable bowel syndrome who had been ruled out for celiac disease and who were symptomatic controlled on a gluten-free diet. Participants received either gluten or a placebo in the form of two slices of bread plus one muffin per day on a gluten-free diet for 6 weeks. Symptoms were assessed using a visual analogue scale and markers of intestinal inflammation, damage and immune activation were monitored. 34 patients (aged 29-59 years, 4 men) completed the study according to the protocol. Overall, 56% were positive for human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-DQ2 and/or HLA-DQ8. Adherence to the diet and supplements was very high. Of 19 patients (68%) in the gluten group, 13 reported that symptoms were not well controlled, compared with 6 of 15 (40%) in the placebo group (P=0.0001; generalized estimating equation). On a visual analogue scale, patients on gluten were significantly worsened at 1 week in terms of general symptoms (P=0.047), pain (P=0.016), bloating (P=0.031), satisfaction with stool consistency (P=0.024), and fatigue. (P=0.001). Antibodies to gliadin were not induced. There were no significant changes in fecal lactoferrin, celiac antibody levels, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, or intestinal permeability. There were no differences in any endpoint between those with or without DQ2/DQ8. “Non-celiac gluten intolerance” may exist, but no clues to the mechanism have emerged.

Genomic typing of HLA-DRB1, -DQA1 and -DQB1 was carried out in 50 patients with dermatitis herpetiformis and 290 healthy blood donors. Genes encoding the DQ heterodimer (alpha 1*0501, beta 1*02) were carried by 43 (86%) patients and 72 (25%) controls. Of the remaining seven patients, six (12% of all patients) carried genes encoding a DQ heterodimer (alpha 1*03, beta 1*0302). These HLA associations are very similar to those observed in patients with celiac disease. Thus, we conclude that dermatitis herpetiformis and celiac disease are associated with the same HLA-DQ alpha-beta heterodimers.

The role of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) DQ2 heterodimer (DQA1*0501-DQB1*0201) in the presentation of gluten peptides to effector T cells in celiac disease (CD) is well documented. Because HLA-DQ2 is carried by DR3 haplotypes due to linkage disequilibrium, such haplotypes are more common in patients with autoimmune diseases. This study analyzed 35 children under 15 years of age from North India who were diagnosed with CD according to ESPGAN criteria, which included histopathological changes in duodenal biopsies, clinical response to gluten withdrawal, and the presence of antiendomysial antibodies. HLA class I and class II alleles were determined using polymerase chain reaction, sequence-specific primers, sequence-specific oligonucleotide probe, and line-reverse molecular techniques. Statistically significant positive association of the disease with HLA-DRB1*03 (94.2% versus 22.1% in control, chi(2) = 73.4, p = 7.54E-11) and negative association with DRB1*15 (chi (2) ) = 7.4, p = 6.5E-03) and alleles DRB1*13. HLA-DQB1*0201 was observed in all 35 patients (100%), while the DQ2 alpha(0)beta(0) heterodimer was observed in 97.1% of CD patients (31.4% with double dose, 65.7% with single dose). and revealed a significant deviation from healthy controls (chi(2) = 102.08, p = 7.56E-11). Further analysis revealed the involvement of several DR3+ve haplotypes in CD in Indians, of which A26-B8-DR3 was the most common DR3 haplotype among patients (34.28%, chi(2) = 40.57, p = 2.65E-10 ), followed by Ax-B21-DR3 (11.4%) (chi(2)=13.8, p=2E-04) and the classical Caucasian haplotype A1-B8-DR3 (5.7%). The first two haplotypes are characteristic of Asian Indians and are involved in the development of CD. We conclude that high-risk DR3 haplotypes, which play a critical role in the development of CD, are unique to Asian Indians. Detailed analysis of these haplotypes in Indian patients with autoimmune diseases may help to understand the influence of other intervening genes in the major histocompatibility complex.

From 1991 to 1998, we vaccinated 4835 newborns against hepatitis B virus (HBV) and monitored their humoral response to the recombinant vaccine. In a sample of 184 such children, we examined the association between genomic HLA class I and II polymorphisms and humoral response to the vaccine, as well as the association between response and immune-mediated diseases. A subgroup of 96 infants also underwent HLA class III typing (C4A and C4B). Four levels of humoral response have been identified, each with distinctive MHC restriction. Various HLA products appear to act as agonists (C4AQ0 and HLA-DQB1(*)02) or antagonists (C4AQ0, HLA-DQB1(*)02 and HLA-DRB1(*)11, DQB1(*)0301) in a decrease in the level of humoral response to the HBV vaccine. The responder group was characterized by the absence of “non-responder” alleles rather than the presence of specific “responder” alleles. Tolerance to HBV peptides may have clinical significance, possibly serving as a marker for children at genetic risk for immunopathologies. In fact, many of the poor responders carried two to four alpha-beta heterodimers of HLA-DQ, predisposing to insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus and celiac disease. Two true non-responders had allergies, and two slow responders had transient episodes of hyperglycemia.

The possibility that genetic susceptibility to celiac disease (CD) may be influenced by tumor necrosis factor (TNF) gene polymorphisms has been repeatedly proposed. To date, this has only been studied in case-control studies, and results have been inconsistent. To avoid any possible ethnic mismatch between cases and controls, we approached this problem by studying 71 families with celiac disease, ascertaining parental haplotypes, and comparing CD with control haplotypes (called AFBACs or affected familial controls). We used DNA-based methods to screen for HLA-DRB1, -DQA1, and -DQB1 alleles, TNFalpha promoter polymorphimes, and TNFa and b microsatellites. A guanine-adenine polymorphism at position -308 of the TNF-alpha gene promoter region has been found to be associated with CD, as the frequency of the TNF-308A allele appears to be significantly increased in CD haplotypes and has been shown to be independent of the association between CD and alleles DRB1*0301, DQA1*0501, DQB1*0201. Our results indicate that at least one other gene, in addition to the known association of CD with HLA class II, plays a role in susceptibility to this disease. It must be either TNF-alpha or another polymorphic gene at the telomeric end of the HLA class III region.

Multiple sclerosis is a common disease of the central nervous system in which the interaction of inflammatory and neurodegenerative processes typically results in recurrent neurological impairment followed by progressive accumulation of disability. Epidemiological studies have shown that genetic factors are primarily responsible for the significantly increased incidence of the disease observed in relatives of affected individuals, and systematic attempts to identify associations in multiplex families have confirmed that variations within the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) have the greatest influence. individual influence on risk. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified more than 20 additional risk loci and have shown that multiple variants with modest individual effects play a key role in disease susceptibility. Much of the genetic architecture underlying susceptibility to this disease has not yet been determined and is expected to require analysis of sample sizes that are beyond the size currently available to individual research groups. In a collaborative GWAS study of 9772 cases of European ancestry collected by 23 research groups working in 15 different countries, we replicated almost all previously proposed associations and identified at least an additional 29 new susceptibility loci. Within the MHC, we clarified the identity of the HLA-DRB1 risk alleles and confirmed that HLA-A gene variation underlies the independent protective effect attributed to the class I region. Immunologically relevant genes are significantly overrepresented among those that map close to the identified loci and, in particular, , are involved in the differentiation of T helper cells in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system in which there is a limited cellular immune response. To determine whether such T cell responses might be antigen specific, particularly for myelin basic protein (MBP), we analyzed T cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement directly from MS brain plaques using polymerase chain reaction on reverse transcribed messenger RNA and compared them with the TCRs of previously described MBP-specific T cell clones from multiple sclerosis and a rat model of experimental allergic encephalomyelitis. Rearranged V beta 5.2 genes were detected in the brains of all patients who had HLA DRB1*1501, DQA1*0102, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401. V beta 5.2-D beta-J beta sequences in these MS brain plaques revealed five motifs. One of the common motifs was identical to the motif described for the VDJ region of clone V beta 5.2 T cells. This clone was obtained from a patient with multiple sclerosis, which was HLA DRB1*1501, DQB1*0602, DPB1*0401, and it was cytotoxic to targets containing the MBP 89-106 peptide (ref. 1). The deduced amino acid sequence of this VDJ rearrangement, Leu-Arg-Gly, has also been described in rat T cells cloned from experimental allergic encephalomyelitis lesions that are specific for the MBP 87-99 peptide (ref. 2). VDJ sequences with specificity for this MBP epitope account for the majority (40%) of TCR V beta 5.2 N(D)N rearrangements in multiple sclerosis lesions. The ability of rat T cells with these VDJ sequences to cause experimental allergic encephalomyelitis and the prevalence of such sequences in human demyelinated lesions indicate that T cells with this rearranged TCR may be critical in multiple sclerosis.

There is a striking latitudinal gradient in the prevalence of multiple sclerosis (MS), but exceptions in Mediterranean Europe and northern Scandinavia, as well as some systematic reviews, suggest that this gradient may be an artifact. The authors sought to evaluate the association between MS prevalence and latitude using meta-regression. Studies were retrieved from online databases, reference analyses, and author recommendations. Prevalence estimates were age standardized to the 2009 European population. Analyzes were performed using random effects meta-regression weighted with inverse within-study variance. The authors included 650 prevalence estimates from 321 peer-reviewed studies; 239 were age standardized and 159 provided sex-disaggregated data. The authors found a significant positive association (change in prevalence per degree of latitude) between age-standardized prevalence (1.04, p < 0.001) and latitude, which decreased at high latitudes. Adjustment for year of prevalence strengthened the association with latitude (2.60, p < 0.001). The gradient in the Italian region was reversed by the distribution of HLA-DRB1 alleles associated with multiple sclerosis. Adjusting HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies did not significantly change the gradient in Europe. Adjustment for some potential sources of bias did not change the observed associations. This most comprehensive review of MS prevalence to date confirmed a statistically significant positive association between MS prevalence and latitude worldwide. Exceptions to this gradient in the Italian region and northern Scandinavia are likely the result of genetic and behavioral and cultural differences. The persistence of a positive gradient in Europe after adjusting for HLA-DRB1 allele frequencies strongly supports the role of environmental factors that vary by latitude, with ultraviolet radiation (UVR)/vitamin D being the most prominent candidates.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a complex trait in which allelic variation in the MHC class II region has the strongest impact on genetic risk. Epidemiological data on multiple sclerosis provide compelling evidence that environmental factors operate at the population level to influence the unusual geographic distribution of the disease. Increasing evidence suggests that sunlight or vitamin D is a key environmental factor in the etiology. We hypothesized that this environmental candidate might interact with heritable factors and looked for sensitive regulatory elements in the MHC class II region. Sequence analysis localized one MHC vitamin D response element (VDRE) to the promoter region of HLA-DRB1. Sequencing of this promoter in more than 1000 chromosomes of HLA-DRB1 homozygotes showed absolute conservation of this putative VDRE across HLA-DRB1*15 haplotypes. In contrast, striking differences were observed among non-MS haplotypes. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed specific recruitment of the vitamin D receptor to the VDRE in the HLA-DRB1*15 promoter, which was confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments using lymphoblastoid cells homozygous for HLA-DRB1*15. Transient transfection using a luciferase reporter assay revealed the functional role of this VDRE. B cells transiently transfected with the HLA-DRB1*15 gene promoter showed increased expression upon stimulation with 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 (P = 0.002), which was lost both when the VDRE was deleted and when the homologous “VDRE” sequence found in -Multiple sclerosis-associated HLA-DRB1 haplotypes. Flow cytometric analysis showed a specific increase in HLA-DRB1 cell surface expression upon vitamin D supplementation only in lymphoblastoid cells harboring HLA-DRB1*15. This study also indicates that vitamin D is a strong environmental candidate in multiple sclerosis, demonstrating a direct functional interaction with a major genetic susceptibility locus. These results confirm the connection between the main epidemiological and genetic features of this disease, which is of great practical importance for studying the mechanism of the disease and its prevention.

Across the usual range of LDL cholesterol in Western populations, lower blood concentrations are associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease. Thus, in such populations, lowering LDL cholesterol levels may reduce the development of vascular disease, largely independent of baseline cholesterol concentrations. 20,536 UK adults (aged 40–80 years) with coronary artery disease, other occlusive arterial disease or diabetes were randomized to receive 40 mg simvastatin per day (mean adherence rate: 85%) or matching placebo (mean adherence rate: use of statins outside the study: 17%). ). Analyzes look at the first occurrence of certain events and compare all participants assigned to simvastatin and all participants assigned to placebo. These "intent-to-treat" comparisons estimate the effects of approximately two-thirds (85% minus 17%) taking a statin during the planned 5-year treatment period, which yielded a mean difference in LDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L (about two-thirds of the effect from actual use of 40 mg simvastatin per day). Primary outcomes were mortality (for the overall analysis) and fatal or nonfatal vascular events (for the subcategory analysis), with secondary assessments of cancer and other underlying diseases. All-cause mortality was significantly reduced (1328 [12.9%] deaths among 10,269 patients receiving simvastatin versus 1,507 [14.7%] among 10,267 patients receiving placebo; p=0.0003), due to a highly significant an 18% (SE 5) proportional reduction in cardiovascular disease. mortality rate (587 [5.7%] vs. 707 [6.9%]; p=0.0005), marginally significant reduction in mortality from other vascular diseases (194 [1.9%] vs. 230 [2.2%] ; p=0.07) and a slight reduction in non-vascular mortality (547 [5.3%] vs. 570 [5.6%]; p=0.4). There was a highly significant reduction of approximately one quarter in the rate of first events of nonfatal myocardial infarction or coronary death (898 [8.7%] vs. 1212 [11.8%]; p<0.0001), nonfatal or fatal stroke (444 [4. 3%] vs. 585 [5.7%]; p<0.0001) and for coronary or noncoronary revascularization (939 [9.1%] vs. 1205 [11.7%]; p<0.0001). At the first occurrence of any of these major vascular events, there was a distinct 24% (SE 3; 95% CI 19–28) reduction in event rate (2033 [19.8%] vs 2585 [25.2%] affected individuals; p < 0 .0001). During the first year, the reduction in the incidence of major vascular events was small, but thereafter it was highly significant in each individual year. The proportional reduction in event rates was similar (and significant) in each subcategory of study participants, including: those without diagnosed coronary artery disease, those with cerebrovascular disease, peripheral arterial disease, or diabetes; men and separately women; persons under or over 70 years of age at the time of entry; and, most importantly, even those with LDL cholesterol levels below 3.0 mmol/L (116 mg/dL) or total cholesterol below 5.0 mmol/L (193 mg/dL). The benefits of simvastatin were additive to those of other cardioprotective treatments. The annual excess risk of myopathy with this regimen was approximately 0.01%. There were no significant adverse effects on cancer incidence or hospitalization for any other nonvascular cause. The safe addition of simvastatin to existing treatments provides significant additional benefit to a wide range of high-risk patients, regardless of their baseline cholesterol concentration. Prescribing simvastatin at a dose of 40 mg per day reduced the incidence of myocardial infarction, stroke and revascularization by approximately a quarter. Taking into account non-adherence, actual use of the regimen would likely reduce these rates by about one-third. Thus, among many high-risk individuals studied, 5 years of simvastatin would prevent at least one of these major vascular events in about 70 to 100 people per 1000 (and longer treatment should provide additional benefit). The size of the 5-year benefit depends primarily on the overall risk of major vascular events in such individuals, not just on blood lipid concentrations.

Although treatment of myocardial overload is effective in reducing mortality from progression of heart failure, it is unknown whether slowing the progression of coronary artery disease achieved with lipid-lowering therapy will prevent the occurrence and consequences of heart failure in patients without preexisting symptoms of heart failure. In the Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study, 4444 patients with coronary artery disease without evidence of heart failure were randomized to placebo (n = 2223) or simvastatin 20–40 mg (n = 2221) and followed for more than 5 years. Among placebo-treated patients, 228 (10.3%) were diagnosed with heart failure during follow-up compared with 184 (8.3%) simvastatin-treated patients (P < 0.015). Mortality among patients who developed heart failure was 31.9% in the placebo group and 25.5% in the simvastatin group. By comparison, among patients without heart failure, these rates are 9.2 and 6.6%, respectively. There were 45 hospitalizations for acute heart failure in the placebo group and 23 in the simvastatin (NS) group. Patients who developed heart failure were more likely to have had a recurrent myocardial infarction and to have a history of diabetes, peripheral arterial disease, and hypertension than patients who did not develop congestive heart failure. Long-term prophylaxis with simvastatin reduces the incidence of heart failure in a cohort of patients with coronary artery disease without previous evidence of congestive heart failure.
